p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
STATEMENTS ON INDULGENCE
COVID-19: Parliamentary Procedure

Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General, Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House) (10:01): To commence with, for the information for honourable members, I would like to present the Agreement for Members to Contribute Remotely to Parliamentary Proceedings, which has been made pursuant to the resolution adopted by the House on 23 March 2020.

I'd like to say a few brief words with respect to that. Obviously this is the agreement that has been made between me and the Manager of Opposition Business in relation to allowing members to contribute remotely to parliamentary proceedings. I'd like to thank the Manager of Opposition Business for his consultation and cooperation in the joint design of this agreement, and you, Mr Speaker, for your assistance.

Members will be aware that the agreement will facilitate members contributing remotely via the official parliamentary video system. It's probably useful to clarify here, for the benefit of all members, that where we talk about 'contribution to debate' that includes members' statements, discussions on matters of public importance, statements made by leave and ministerial statements. These will be treated as though they are contributions to the debate, for the purposes of the official parliamentary video facility referred to in the agreement. I might also just note that the words that are used in the agreement, which, from recollection, are, 'essentially impossible, unreasonably impracticable, or give rise to an unreasonable risk for the member', are meant to delineate a distinction between those who are applying to use the facility—between people who have been inconvenienced, indeed, even seriously inconvenienced, and those who can properly apply to use the facilities, which are those who, in all of the circumstances, have found it virtually impossible or simply impractical for whatever reason to attend in person. I'm sure it will work. It will be an innovation that will benefit the House during this very unusual period.
The SPEAKER: I thank the Leader of the House. The Manager of Opposition Business?

Mr BURKE (Watson—Manager of Opposition Business) (10:03): I will say more when we get to the resolution, but the agreement, which has been put in place, has been done with respect to the sessional order, which we carried quite some weeks ago. When we carried it, it referred to the fact that it would be possible for the House to meet in a different manner and form, if circumstances occurred. When we put that in, it was described at the time by one of us—it may have been me—as a break-glass option, which we hoped to never use. Circumstances eventuated, which I will refer to later but are not appropriate to go to during a statement on indulgence, which caused us to hit that break-glass option.

It's important to note that what the Leader of the House and I have agreed on is not a virtual parliament. The parliament is meeting and it is meeting here. There has been capacity for a long time for members' speeches, when members weren't able to be here, to be tabled and effectively incorporated into the Hansard. What we're allowing is effectively an extension of that process where, when members want to make a contribution to a debate or discussion in different ways, they're able to do so via video link. But for all other purposes you have to be here. If you want to move something you have to be here. If you want to vote you have to be here. If you want to raise a matter of public importance or support a matter of public importance when the call for support goes up, standing up in your electorate office doesn't count. You have to physically be here.

So the parliament is not a virtual parliament. The parliament is still here, in Parliament House in Canberra. But, where members of parliament, through no fault of their own, have found themselves in circumstances where they simply can't be here because of COVID-19, we've allowed the video link to make sure that they can contribute—importantly, not for their convenience but for their electorates, to make sure the voices of their electorates are heard here inside the parliament.
STATEMENT BY THE SPEAKER
COVID-19: Parliamentary Procedure

The SPEAKER (10:05): Just before we move on, I might make a detailed statement now, if it suits the Leader of the House and the Manager of Opposition Business, just for clarity of all members. As we know, over the course of this year the House has been adapting to the changing circumstances, as have all Australians, as a result of COVID-19. No doubt we will continue to adapt, but for now I want to inform the House about the arrangements for this sitting fortnight, and in particular the matter we're discussing, to outline how we will enable some members, as both the Leader of the House and the Manager of Opposition Business have said, to participate in proceedings remotely.

On 23 March the House resolved to make the special provisions that you're aware of. I want to thank the Leader of the House, the Manager of Opposition Business, the whips and members on both sides for their cooperative approach during the consultations about how to enable the House to continue its work during this extraordinary period. The Leader of the House has presented a copy of the agreement. That is available for all members to read, and I'd encourage them to. I also wish to thank all of the staff of the House of Representatives and the Department of Parliamentary Services, who have worked tirelessly to ensure that we're able to do this at this time.

As you're aware, the resolution in March provided for a manner in which members may be present for proceedings to be determined by me as Speaker. For this sitting period my determination is that the normal requirements of the House standing orders and practice for quorums and divisions remain in place. However, in addition to the usual opportunities for members to contribute to proceedings in the chamber, members unable to attend for COVID related reasons may seek, as you've heard, and be given the call to speak via the official parliamentary video facility during certain proceedings. Members who have provided satisfactory reasons and notified of their wish to participate remotely will have received the technical information about access.

In terms of procedural requirements, I confirm that the House standing orders and practices will apply to members who participate remotely, to the extent possible, except as affected by my determination and the agreement that's just been tabled. That means members participating remotely must participate with the same degree of formality as is required in the chamber, and that includes regard for the authority of the chair. Any member participating remotely who does not comply with the House rules and directions from the chair may have their remote access suspended or terminated. Members may speak when given the call by the chair as usual, and they will be bound by the usual speech limits. If there are technical difficulties at any time, chairs will of course offer a degree of flexibility. But, if it is clear the member is not able to speak when called, the chair will move to the next member, as we do in general debate, and return to the member later on. The House's formal record, the Votes and Proceedings, will record attendance as usual at the end of each sitting and also identify which members did not attend physically but participated in proceedings remotely.

I also wish to refer to the matter of parliamentary privilege. As members would be aware, the Parliamentary Privileges Act makes clear that participation in proceedings of parliament is protected absolutely by parliamentary privilege. Members would also know that for 20 years the standing orders of the House have empowered parliamentary committees to conduct proceedings using audiovisual or audio-only links, with members of committees not present in one place, while retaining the protection of parliamentary privilege. Following this well-established precedent, it's my understanding that members who are participating remotely in the chamber proceedings—that is, speaking when given the call and otherwise complying with the standing orders—would be considered to be participating in proceedings in parliament and therefore protected by parliamentary privilege in the same way as members participating here in the chamber in person.

I and the President of the Senate issued detailed statements last week that convey very clearly the medical advice that we've provided for members and building occupants. I just want to briefly mention this and remind members to familiarise themselves with those. The medical advice stipulates a number of measures. It also encourages others, such as the wearing of masks in corridors and common areas, particularly those places where you can't be sure of social distancing. I also reiterate that the strong advice is that members of parliament and travelling staff are encouraged to remain in Canberra over the coming weekend to avoid unnecessary travel. For those wishing to have a look at that, it was in the memorandum that went out last Tuesday.

Finally, members would recognise this is an unprecedented period in the life of the House and we're all working together to enable the House to meet and conduct its essential business on behalf of the Australian people. I ask all members to treat each other with courtesy and respect and to be mindful of the flexibility that the trial of the new arrangements may require from time to time. We need to remember that the work of the House is, of course, scrutinised closely by Australians, many of whom are going through very, very difficult times at present. They're entitled to expect the highest standards of all of us in this House. I thank the House.
MOTIONS
COVID-19: Parliamentary Procedure
Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General, Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House) (10:11): by leave—I move:
That:
(1) the House authorises the use of an official video facility in order for a Member not physically present in the Chamber to participate in such proceedings of the House as it prescribes;
(2) a Member who participates through the official facility will be identified in the Members' attendance record in the Votes and Proceedings; and

(3) to the extent possible, the contribution of a Member who participates through the official facility will be recorded, published and broadcast in accordance with the usual processes and rules, as if the contribution had been made by a Member attending in the Chamber of the House.

Mr BURKE (Watson—Manager of Opposition Business) (10:12): I might use this opportunity to explain, first of all, that we support the resolution but also to explain how we've got here and to make some additional comments relating to how we got here that I didn't believe were appropriate to make on indulgence earlier but are, for that reason, relevant to the matter that's before us now.

We support the motion as moved by the Leader of the House, and, given that we have a video link facility, the resolutions are the appropriate resolutions for the House to conclude on. It is important to acknowledge how we got here, though, and why we are now in a situation where we have to have a video link. Members, including the Leader of the House, will remember that Labor was very resistant to having a video link and wanted to find a way to, as much as possible, get all members of parliament here, to the extent that that was going to be possible. For that reason, I had written, together with Senator Katy Gallagher, to both of the Presiding Officers asking for a working group to be established. The reason for that working group was to avoid where we have now landed.

That working group—and I thank the Presiding Officers—was functioning very well. Both managers of opposition business, both Presiding Officers, the Leader of the House and the Manager of Government Business in the Senate were involved. We were working very constructively. You can tell when something is working constructively, because the media keep ringing and saying, 'We can't get any leaks. What's going on?' and they don't get any. We were at the point where that group was ready to put a proposal to the chief medical officers which involved much stricter conditions than what we'll be living under this week but might have found a way for a number of people—in particular, from Victoria—to be able to physically get here. There are some representatives, for example, from border communities where there is currently no community spread, and it might have been possible under the restrictions for them to get here and therefore we wouldn't now be dealing with the video link resolution.

The Prime Minister then unilaterally went to the Acting Chief Medical Officer and got advice, when the Acting Chief Medical Officer didn't know what the proposal was going to be, and asked, 'Will it be safe?' The Acting Chief Medical Officer then did the best that he could with the information. He couldn't know what the proposal was going to be. It might have been iterated back and forth. It might not have been. We'll never know. It effectively created a situation where some members of parliament from Victoria—we have one in the chamber right now—were in a circumstance where they were able to deal with the new restrictions of the two-week lockdown before they got here. But, for many members of parliament from Victoria, that restriction simply made it practically impossible for them. At that moment, it became clear to Labor that we were going to have to support a video link, and it was at that moment that I wrote to the Leader of the House saying that that was the path that Labor would now support, acknowledging that that was a change from where we had previously been.

I want to thank the Speaker for the foresight. It was way back in March, after we'd put the 'break glass' sessional order and voted for that on both sides unanimously, that the Speaker, even though we were saying we weren't going to do a video link, decided to do the preparations anyway. There were meetings here on the floor of the parliament involving senior representatives from government offices and me, where we worked through, if it were to happen, what it would look like. We've now ended up in a circumstance where that's ready to go, and the important thing for those members who are unable to be here for various reasons is to know that, under this resolution, the official record of the Hansard will be recorded identically as if they had physically been within the room. The voices of their electorates being heard will not be disadvantaged in any way, and the Speaker has put the various precautions in place to make sure that it's used to facilitate as closely as possible what it would have been like if the people were here and not so that they can use the facility to basically become a roving mic throughout their electorates in different ways. Some of the formalities of this place are still locked in, which we support, notwithstanding the interesting television coverage we might otherwise have had. Effectively I don't think we could have done more to make it look and work like a parliament, given the circumstances that Australia is now in. To that end, I want to thank both the Presiding Officers—in particular, the Speaker, because we have an extent to which we don't acknowledge the other place—for the work that they have done and thank the Leader of the House for the motion that is before us.
Question agreed to.
PARLIAMENTARY OFFICE HOLDERS
Speaker's Panel

The SPEAKER (10:18): Pursuant to standing order 17(a), I lay on the table my warrant nominating the honourable members for Mackellar, Macarthur and Parramatta to be members of the Speaker's panel to assist the chair when requested to do so by the Speaker or the Deputy Speaker.
COMMITTEES
Selection Committee
Report

The SPEAKER (10:19): I present report No. 17 of the Selection Committee relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private members' business for this sitting. Copies of the report have been placed on the table.
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
SELECTION COMMITTEE
REPORT No. 17
Committee and delegation business
and
private Members' business
24 August 2020
MEMBERS OF THE COMMITTEE
Chair Hon A. D. H. Smith MP, Speaker
Members Mr B van Manen MP (Chief Government Whip)
Mr C Hayes MP (Chief Opposition Whip)
Hon D Drum MP (Chief Nationals Whip)
Mr R Broadbent MP
Ms N Flint MP
Ms P Murphy MP
Mr K O'Dowd
Mr R Ramsey MP
Ms J Ryan MP
Ms R Sharkie MP

Mr L O'Brien MP, Deputy Speaker
Secretary Mr G Worthington
Committee support
Ms F Hall
Mr D Pecar
Mr G Taylor
Report relating to the consideration of committee and delegation business and of private Members' business
1. The committee met in private session on Tuesday, 4 August 2020.

2. The Committee deliberated on items of committee and delegation business that had been notified, and private Members' business items listed on the Notice Paper, and determined the order of precedence and times on the next sitting Monday, as follows:
Items for House of Representatives Chamber (10.10 am to 12 noon)
PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS
Notices
1 Ms Claydon: To move—That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) more than 140,000 Australians were on social housing waitlists in June 2018;
(b) the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute has identified a shortfall of 433,000 social housing dwellings over the next 20 years;
(c) much of Australia's existing social housing stock is in dire need of maintenance and repairs; and

(d) the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has urged the Government to consider investment in social housing as a means of protecting Australia's economy from the impacts of COVID-19;

(2) recognises the success of Labor's $5,638 billion investment to build 20,000 new social housing dwellings and renovate a further 80,000, as a key economic stimulus measure during the global financial crisis; and
(3) calls on the Government to:
(a) ensure that stimulus measures are focused on delivering maximum ongoing public benefit; and
(b) work with the private and community sectors and superannuation funds to invest in more social housing and repair existing social housing.
(Notice given 16 June 2020.)
Time allotted — 60minutes.
Ms Claydon — 5minutes.
Other Members — 5 minutes each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 12 x 5 mins]

span.span: of this matter should continue on a future day.

p.span: 2 Ms Flint: To move—That this House:
(1) notes that cultural and creative activity plays an important role in:
(a) the lives of 98 per cent of Australians, who engage with the arts by making art, viewing, attending or going online to experience arts and culture;

(b) Australia's international tourism industry, with 43 per cent of all international tourists engaging with the arts while in Australia, who are travelling further, staying longer and spending more than other tourists;

(c) Australia's domestic tourism industry, with Australians taking 12.3 million arts day trips and 13.4 million arts overnight trips within Australia that include arts activities—this travel will play a role in helping communities rebuild and recover from disasters by supporting local jobs and economies; and
(d) Australia's economy, contributing more than $112 billion to our economy this year, or over 6 per cent of our gross domestic product, and this has increased by 30 per cent since 2008-09; and
(2) further notes that the Government is providing a record amount of funding to the arts, of around $750 million.
(Notice given 3 March 2020.)
Ms Flint — 5minutes.
Other Members — 5 minutes each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 10 x 5 mins]

span.span: of this matter should continue on a future day.

p.span: Items for Federation Chamber (11 am to 1.30 pm)
PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS
Notices
1 Dr Haines: To move—That this House:
(1) recognises that:

(a) in the 19th century it was regional Australia that led the transition from gas to electricity and that in the 21st century it is again regional Australia that is leading Australia's transition to renewable energy; and
(b) according to the Australian Energy Market Operator's Integrated System Plan, around 15 gigawatts of coal-fired power will retire over the next 20 years;

(2) recalls the analysis from the leaked report of the National COVID-19 Coordination Commission Manufacturing Taskforce indicated that renewables plus storage are the lowest cost form of new electricity generation, and therefore a lowest-cost energy transition will be based on significant investment in renewables;

(3) welcomes the recent comments from the International Energy Agency that 'governments have the opportunity to accelerate renewables deployment by making investment in renewables a key part of stimulus packages designed to reinvigorate their economies. This offers the prospect of harnessing the structural benefits that increasingly affordable renewables can bring, including opportunities for creating jobs and economic development, while reducing emissions and fostering innovation';

(4) notes analysis by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation that projects that up to $1,000 billion will be spent on Australia's electricity system until 2050 and that local communities should benefit from this investment boom;

(5) acknowledges that 'community energy', which is where a renewable energy project is developed by, owned by or delivers benefit to local communities, offers a compelling model for capturing the immense benefits of renewable energy, including jobs and investment, for local communities in regional Australia;

(6) welcomes the findings of Sustainability Victoria into the Victorian Community Power Hub pilot program which found that Government investment into community energy of $1.16 million created 15 projects delivering economic benefits worth $25.6 million; and
(7) calls on the Government to support the development of community-owned renewable energy projects across regional Australia through:
(a) direct financial support for regional communities in the form of grants and concessional loans;
(b) technical support for local communities to develop renewable energy projects based on the Community Power Hub model successfully deployed in Victoria; and
(c) a dedicated national community energy agency to enable capacity-building across the regional community energy network and to administer financial and technical support over the medium‑term.
(Notice given 15 June 2020.)
Time allotted — 35minutes.
Dr Haines — 5minutes.
Other Members — 5 minutes each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 7 x 5 mins]

span.span: of this matter should continue on a future day.

p.span: 2 Mr Connelly: To move—That this House:

(1) notes the Census and Statistics Amendment (Statistical Information) Regulations 2020 tabled in Parliament on 11 February 2020 seek to ask a question in the 2021 census about whether someone has served in the Australian Defence Force (ADF); and
(2) recognises that having a census question around the ADF service will:
(a) for the first time, give a complete picture of the number of veterans in Australia; and
(b) allow governments of all levels to deliver the right services in the right areas to support veterans and their families.
(Notice given 3 March 2020.)
Time allotted — 30minutes.
Mr Connelly — 5minutes.
Other Members — 5 minutes each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins]

span.span: of this matter should continue on a future day.

p.span: 3 Mr Jones: To move—That this House notes:
(1) the purpose of superannuation is to enable Australians to save for a dignified retirement;
(2) superannuation has made an enormous contribution to converting Australia from a nation that borrows to a nation that lends, creating a pool of funds to invest locally and abroad;

(3) Australia is the 16th largest economy in the world, but because of universal superannuation has a pool of savings owned by Australian workers worth $2.8 trillion, which is the fourth largest pool of retirement savings in the world;
(4) before universal superannuation, 68 per cent of Australians and 85 per cent of all women had no retirement savings;
(5) the average superannuation balance at retirement is now approximately $160,000 for women and $280,000 for men;
(6) under current policy settings, the median balance on retirement for full-time workers will be $310,819 for women and $628,634 for men;

(7) over the past decade the average rate of return has been between 6 and 8 per cent—last year it grew by 9.2 per cent and Australia was among only a handful of countries that saw pension fund growth; and
(8) superannuation is critical to Australia's economic growth and resilience and must be strengthened so it can play a pivotal role in Australia's economic recovery from COVID-19.
(Notice given 13 May 2020.)
Time allotted — 35minutes.
Mr Jones — 5minutes.
Other Members — 5 minutes each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 7 x 5 mins]

span.span: of this matter should continue on a future day.

p.span: Orders of the day
1 Roads to Recovery Program: Resumption of debate (from24February2020—Dr Haines, in continuation) on the motion of Mr R. J. Wilson—That this House:
(1) notes:
(a) that from 2013-14 to 2023-24, the Government will provide a record $6.2 billion under the Roads to Recovery Program, with an ongoing commitment of $500 million each year following; and
(b) the significant benefits to the 128 Local Government Areas which will receive an additional $138.9 million in Roads to Recovery drought support funding; and
(2) recognises the real and meaningful difference Roads to Recovery is making to communities right across the country.
Time allotted — 30minutes.
All Members — 5 minutes each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins]

span.span: of this matter should continue on a future day.

p.span: 2 Precision medicine: Resumption of debate (from25November2019) on the motion of Mr Simmonds—That this House:

(1) recognises that precision medicine, enabled by advances in genomics, data analysis and artificial intelligence represents an exciting leap in healthcare that will improve the outcomes of preventative and targeted medicine for countless Australians and their families;
(2) acknowledges that:
(a) our world class healthcare system ensures Australia is well placed to lead the world in precision medicine innovations;
(b) Australian researchers, including those at the University of Queensland, are world leaders in their field and their work is at the forefront of precision medicine; and
(c) research in precision medicine stimulates the economy, leads to growth in highly skilled jobs and supports Australia's $185 billion healthcare industry;

(3) welcomes the Government's significant investment in precision medicine research including as part of the recently announced $440 million in National Health and Medical Research Council grants; and

(4) encourages the Government and private enterprise to continue to invest in the genomics, data analysis and artificial intelligence research required to grow the precision medicine sector in Australia in order to create jobs, keep Australia at the forefront of medical advances and improve the healthcare outcomes for everyday Australians.
All Members — 5 minutes each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 4 x 5 mins]

span.span: of this matter should continue on a future day.

p.span: Items for Federation Chamber (4.45 pm to 7.30 pm)
PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS
Notices – continued
4 Mr Gorman: To move—That this House:
(1) recognises that Australia's tourism sector is vital to a strong, growing economy;
(2) notes:
(a) that 2020 has seen an incredibly tough start to the year for tourism operators with devastating bushfires, an inevitable Coronavirus pandemic and a sluggish domestic economy;
(b) Australia is a tourism dependent economy with the Australian Bureau of Statistics noting a $60 billion contribution to gross domestic product; and
(c) 666,000 people worked in tourism in Australia in 2018-19;
(3) encourages Australians to support our local tourism operators and where possible holiday here, at home, in the best country in the world;
(4) commits Members of this House to work with members of the tourism industry and local operators and encourage the development of new tourism businesses and assets; and
(5) agrees that Australia is the best country in the world and a must visit country for any international tourist.
(Notice given 3 March 2020.)
Time allotted — 40minutes.
Mr Gorman — 5minutes.
Other Members — 5 minutes each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 8 x 5 mins]

span.span: of this matter should continue on a future day.

p.span: 5 Mr Pearce: To move—That this House:
(1) recognises the importance of working with our Pacific neighbours to deliver a region that is secure and sovereign; and
(2) notes:
(a) the Government's Pacific Maritime Security Program is providing the region with a modern and coordinated security capability; and
(b) the Government is delivering important infrastructure projects that will enhance their security capability—this includes:
(i) Fiji's Blackrock Peacekeeping and Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Relief Camp;
(ii) gifting of Guardian Class Patrol Boats; and
(iii) the joint initiative with Papua New Guinea and the Lombrum Naval Base.
(Notice given 3 March 2020.)
Time allotted — 40minutes.
Mr Pearce — 5minutes.
Other Members — 5 minutes each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 8 x 5 mins]

span.span: of this matter should continue on a future day.

p.span: 6 Ms Collins: To move—That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) the COVID-19 pandemic has disproportionately impacted women's economic security, and that:
(i) in April over half a million Australians lost their jobs, of which 55 per cent were women;
(ii) women's underemployment ratio now sits at an unprecedented 16 per cent, compared to 14 per cent for men; and
(iii) modelling has estimated that more than 200,000 women casual workers in the accommodation, food services, and retail trade sectors alone will miss out on the JobKeeper wage subsidy;
(b) women typically retire with half the superannuation balance as men and if they choose to withdraw funds, women will suffer a significantly greater impact on their retirement income than men;
(c) Australian women have been on the frontline of the COVID-19 crisis in Australia in underpaid and undervalued roles—women account for:
(i) 87 per cent of registered nurses and midwives;
(ii) 87 per cent of aged care workers; and
(iii) 96 percent of early childhood educators; and
(d) as a result of COVID-19, mothers are spending an extra hour each day on unpaid housework and four extra hours on childcare; and
(2) calls on the Government to recognise that women have been disproportionately impacted by the COVID-19 crisis and deliver a plan to reduce gender inequality.
(Notice given 10 June 2020.)
Time allotted — 45minutes.
Ms Collins — 5minutes.
Other Members — 5 minutes each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 9 x 5 mins]

span.span: of this matter should continue on a future day.

p.span: 7 Mrs McIntosh: To move—That this House:
(1) recognises the importance of environmental management and conservation in our local communities;
(2) acknowledges the importance of local environmental volunteer groups who devote their time to look after our natural environment;
(3) congratulates our local volunteers on their dedication to supporting our local communities and our environment; and

(4) acknowledges the Government's continued support of environmental groups through the Communities Environment Program, which provides each of the 151 electorates across Australia with up to $150,000 to fund small, community-led environment projects, totalling $22.65 million.
(Notice given 2 March 2020.)
Mrs McIntosh — 5minutes.
Other Members — 5 minutes each.
[Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 8 x 5 mins]

span.span: of this matter should continue on a future day.

p.span: THE HON A. D. H. SMITH MP
Speaker of the House of Representatives
24 August 2020
BUSINESS
Rearrangement

Mr PORTER (Pearce—Attorney-General, Minister for Industrial Relations and Leader of the House) (10:19): I rise to move a motion to suspend standing orders—it's a suspension motion with respect to private members' business in this sitting—and to advise the House that, pursuant to standing order 47(c)(ii), the Manager of Opposition Business and I have agreed that an absolute majority is not required. I move:

That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the order of consideration of matters and the times allotted for debate on each item and for each Member speaking, for committee and delegation business and private Members' business for today, be in accordance with the determinations of the Selection Committee.
Question agreed to.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:20): I present the 14th report of the Petitions Committee of the 46th Parliament, comprising 79 petitions and 93 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.
PETITIONS
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:20): I present the following petitions:
Murray-Darling Basin
An Independent Investigation into Murray-Darling Basin Plan

My issue relates to the millions of fish deaths occurring in the Murray-Darling river. I'm deeply concerned about the immediate impact this is having on communities, wildlife and natural habitats throughout the Murray-Darling regions. Equally concerning to me are the long-term ramifications of this environmental crisis. The consequences it will have on our nation, including fresh water availability, food production and irreversible damage to the landscape. I'm requesting that the House of Representatives call for an independent federal Royal commission into mis-management of the Murray-Darling Basin Plan and water theft by large corporate irrigators.
We therefore ask the House to call for an independent federal Royal commission into mis-management of the Murray-Darling Basin Plan and water theft by large corporate irrigators.
From 5428 citizens (EN1038)
Murray-Darling Basin
An Independent Investigation Into Murray-Darling Basin Plan

Last summer millions of fish died in the Murray-Darling River. These mass fish deaths have been attributed to alleged maladministration and mismanagement. I am deeply concerned about the immediate impact this is having on communities, wildlife and natural habitats throughout the Murray-Darling regions. Equally concerning to me are the long-term ramifications of this environmental crisis. The consequences it will have on our nation, including freshwater availability, food production and irreversible damage to the environment. I am requesting that the House of Representatives call for an independent Federal Royal Commission into the mismanagement of the Murray-Darling Basin Plan and water theft by large corporate irrigators. This is the second of two petitions with these terms.

We therefore ask the House to call for an independent Federal Royal Commission into alleged maladministration and mismanagement of the Murray-Darling Basin Plan and water theft by large corporate irrigators.
From 1754 citizens (EN1124)
Animal Welfare
Immediately Enact Vegan Law
The billions of animal lives lost yearly to slaughter is morally unacceptable.

The link between intensive animal agriculture and unprecedented global disasters including extreme weather events, catastrophic bushfires, and zoonotic pandemics such as COVID-19 is increasingly clear.

The current global crisis offers a perfect opportunity to rethink our relationship with animals and pivot our agriculture and food industries towards a kinder, sustainable, healthier, economically-smart, secure, and future-proofed model that values human health, safety and well-being, respects all life and allows people to thrive in balance with the planet.

Growing public awareness of the health benefits of plant-based diets and the devastating impact on the environment from meat, dairy and egg industries, together with concern over the abhorrent suffering inflicted on animals is already fuelling a massive growth in vegan and plant-based products, services and businesses.
Vegan law will take us quickly from crisis to peace.
We therefore ask the House to:

1. Phase out all businesses causing suffering to animals (meat, fish, egg, and milk industries); prohibit all animal testing (lab, cosmetics, etc.); make all animal products (leather, fur, etc.) illegal.
2. Support livestock farmers, workers and related industries to transition to plant-based businesses and jobs.
3. Incentivise organic vegan farming and regenerative agricultural practices.
4. Promote plant-based lifestyles within communities.
From 678 citizens (EN1534)
COVID-19: Economy
Recovery to include pay cuts for politicians and bureaucrats
To the Honourable Speaker and Member of the House of Representatives.
We the undersigned petitioners call on the Federal Government to immediately commence work on a post-COVID-19 Economic Recovery Review.
The PM has achieved an excellent health COVID-19 outcome, but the economic impact is severe.

'Economic recovery' must include a full review of politicians, bureaucrats and other public servant's salaries (with the exclusion of front-line workers and military personnel), government grants, taxpayer funded Executive's salaries, corporate bail-outs and non- essential government departments such as the Human Rights Commission, Great Barrier Reef Foundation and the Workplace Gender Equality Agency. In addition, the 'Defined Benefits Scheme' for non-military bureaucrats should include the same 'means testing' applied to the rest of Australia.

The Prime Minister has often stated ' we are all in this together' – but this is NOT the case. Half of Australia is severely impacted, and many people have lost their jobs despite the government's generous support packages. The 'other half' continue to be paid their full taxpayer-funded salaries, grants and bailouts.
We therefore ask the House to immediately pass legislation applying a 20% salary reduction for ALL politicians and bureaucrats, with the exclusion of military and front-line workers.

We also call on the House to conduct a fully transparent 'Economic Recovery Review', including savings thru the removal of all non-essential Government Departments, grants, corporate bailouts, and which caps the salaries of taxpayer-funded Executives at $250K.
From 66 citizens (EN1535)
COVID-19
Investigate and disclose Federal Government mismanagement of COVID19 pandemic.

Throughout the COVID19 response the Federal Government violated many rights of Australian Citizens by way of adopting and enforcing clearly inappropriate health protocols and lockdown measures derived from dubious relations with the World Health Organisation(WHO) and associated entities and other corporate and international interests. The data utilised was clearly manipulated and corporate and international conflicts of interest are clearly visible.
Reasonable due diligence was not preformed regarding the selection of data sources, organistaions and corporate entities used to create and enforce COVID 19 mitigation measures.
Australian Citizens have been subject, but not limited to,
Restrictions upon:
Ability to have freedom of movement and travel
Reduced ability to earn income for oneself and family
Ability to conduct business
Ability to access recreation
Ability to gather
Ability to choose ones own health decisions
Restriction and isolation to ones dwelling
Heavy enforcement of deemed restrictions

We therefore ask the House to investigate, publicly disclose and justify any perceived or actual conflicts of interest from all entities that the Federal Government utilised to implement its mitigation management of COVID19. Specifically organisations, subsidisaries and or entities owned by or where Bill Gates is a majority financial contributor. Investigate and justify the continued implementation of highly inaccurate virus modelling and manipulated data utilised from the WHO and other promoted sources. Investigate the misleading and extreme fear based content delivered by goverment owned media throughout COVID19. Disclose publicly any global arrangements, agreements and or targeted outcomes agreed to by the Federal Government relating to COVID19.
From 19 citizens (EN1537)
Trade with China
TARRIFFS ON ALL CHINESE IMPOTS
AUSTRALIA TO PUT TARIFFS ON ALL CHINESE IMPORTS UNTIL IT STARTS PLAYING BY THE SAME WORLD RULES.
STOP SELLING THEM OUR COAL & MANY OF OUR MATERIALS.
BRING BACK ALL MANUFACTURING BACK TO AUSTRALIA FROM CHINE & IF BUSINESSES DO NOT THESE BUSINESSES TO BE CHARGED HIGHER IMPRORT TARRIFFS.
We therefore ask the House to EQUALITY OF TRADE. NO MORE MONEY GOING TO:
WORLD HEALTH ORGANISATION, UNITED NATIONS, WORLD BANKS OR ANY FOREIGN AID
STOP ALL FOREIGN WORKING VISAS & AUSTRALIANS TO HAVE PRIORITY TO ALL WORK
CHINE NEEDS TO BE STOPPED NOW.
Stop all preferential university placements to foreigners
From 22 citizens (EN1538)
COVID-19: International Students
Remove International Student work hour restriction due to COVID-19

Requesting that the house raise or remove the working restriction of 40 hours per fortnight for international students until the end of the year to allow for time lost and lack of government support during COVID-19. Students have received no funding from either Australia or their own countries during this time and although we have savings we will need to re-build this money spent to support ourselves with day to day life expenses and also high tuition fees due each term to keep studying in Australia.

We therefore ask the House to consider increasing the working hours limit or remove it completely for international students. By doing this students will be helping to restart the Australian economy by having funds to spend, and be able to re-build some of their savings and continue to study here. International students are required as per their visa to be able to support themselves for the first year however many students are long past this time frame and are paying just as much Tax as residents. By removing this restriction even for a short term will help and restore some damage to all from this COVID-19 disaster.
From 25 citizens (EN1540)
Telecommunications
5g network
Dangers of 5g communication system
We therefore ask the House to to examin the communication 5g network for dangers of high levels of radiation and any other health concerns if you stand near it will radiation effect you
From 6 citizens (EN1541)
Telecommunications
5g communication
This must be a matter for house to act as australians health are at risk
We therefore ask the House to examine the impact of communication 5g system as radiation and any other issues could hurt australian citizen
From 5 citizens (EN1542)
Australia Post
Failures of Australia Post

Many businesses in this time of economic uncertainty are dependant on a reliable Postal service to deliver envelopes & parcels to both within Australia & abroad. Currently Australia Post is limiting & most cases diminishing profits to business both small & large due to their huge delays. Goods are sitting for weeks & months in Australia Post distribution centres & Australian exit points before being onforwarded making suppliers liable to charge back & refunds due to Australia Post uncertainty. The cost to Australian businesses is huge & Australia Post is major limiting factor to manufacturing & supply from Australia.

We therefore ask the House to urgently investigate Australia Post & force changes to improve the service & not inhibit vulnerable Australian manufactures & suppliers. Our livelihood's are dependant on your actions
From 6 citizens (EN1543)
Teachers
Remove Lantite
Hello,
I hope you are keeping well.

I am quite frustrated to read that education students will have our professional experience hours slashed, this is where all the real learning happens! Instead of slashing the Lantite test they are slashing crucial on the job learning experiences! How ridiculous!

I'm appalled, I really hope you can see where I am coming from. Get rid of Lantite then you will have more teachers readily available and no shortage. I understand wanting the cream of the crop but only a short percentage are failing anyway. Most pass the test, so it's a waste of money and time. Please slash the test just like England did. They proved the test did not filter out the cream of the crop. Experience is crucial and the quicker we get into the classroom, the quicker we learn. A majority of our degree teaches us pre service teachers that learning happens through experience and tests do not show ones potential.

It is also a noteworthy mention that before I began my degree I was specifically told "No exams in this degree". So why was it brought in for people like me half way through? If you pass your units especially when you are doing very well, I receive high distinctions, so I don't understand why this is deemed not good enough anymore.
Please consider removing these tests
Warmest regards
Christina Kingston
We therefore ask the House to remove Lantite tests.
From 3 citizens (EN1544)
Teachers
LANTITE

Requesting for LANTITE to be removed for Australian preserviced teachers as it does not apply for exisiting teachers. It causes stress, depression because preserviced teachers work extremely hard at university and if the don't pass LANTITE, their hard work means "nothing'.
We therefore ask the House to remove LANTITE for Australian teachers.
From 1 citizen (EN1545)
Teachers
Remove LANTITE as a Graduation requirement

LANTITE is causing much distress and a shortage of Teachers. LANTITE has been unfairly applied across the board. This includes students that specifically selected their respective course and career path to ensure that it did not have a math component. They pass their university degree only to be met by the LANTITE requirements. Being able to pass a Math test does not govern that you will be a capable educator. Capable educators now sit with huge Hex debts and cannot progress into their chosen career because LANTITE decides that they are not clever enough. Senior tradesmen that want to teach future trades at TAFE's, art teachers, Music teachers, mature students that have not done Math for 30 years, the list goes on, all fall into this category. It is discriminatory and we will loose valuable experience that should be passed on from the old to the young. The LANTITE concept of "our teachers need to be in the top 30% of intelligence" is great, but not practical. This requires further thought by someone brave enough to stand up and admit fault, as it is wrong.

We therefore ask the House to remove LANTITE as it currently stands and re-structure as a degree entry level requirement. Enabling hundreds stuck with huge debt and no direction to move on with their careers, paying debts and taxes toward rebuilding our economy. It will afford future candidates the chance to understand these requirements prior to studying for 4 years and accumulating a Hex debt.
From 34 citizens (EN1546)
Teachers
Remove lantite

Lantite was never mentioned when I first started my degree, it has cost me money that I don't sparingly have to take this test ! The fact that the exam has been implemented differently in each state: territory. The fact it has no relevance to the methodologies and pedagogy of teaching. Acer have no ministerial oversight and routinely ignore requests for reasonable adjustment despite medical evidence and that schools need back up right now and we need as many casuals as possible. this test doesn't define a teachers worth !! I've completed my units and placements and to be stopped by this test !!
We therefore ask the House to REMOVE LANTITE. Listen to our point of view
From 1 citizen (EN1547)
Teachers
Removal of LANTITE

Many students began a university degree in teaching and towards the end of their degree LANTITE was implemented. LANTITE was not on agreement when students had signed up for their degree. Some students have received their degree but can not gain their teaching registration due to their state implementing they have to pass LANTITE.
Also, many students are having their degrees kept by their universities until they pass the LANTITE.
LANTITE should be an entrance exam, not half way through a degree!

We therefore ask the House to remove LANTITE and grant teaching registration to those who can not teach because of LANTITE and grant those students their degrees. We are amazing, caring and smart students / teachers who deserve to have our teaching degrees and also be able to register!
From 2 citizens (EN1548)
Teachers
THE REMOVAL OF LANTITE
The LANTITE is an unfair test that does not indicate one's capability to be an outstanding and influential teacher.

During this time, teachers are dedicating themselves to their teaching practise, only for their jobs to be threatened by a test causing high amounts of stress and anxiety. We are creating rich and meaningful learning tasks for our students which makes us valuable.
- The UK has removed such tests.
- There are so many flaws with this test.

- Hard working teachers should not be out of a job because of this test, they have already proven themselves to be capable. If we do not remove this test we face losing impeccable teachers who care for their students and their jobs.

Australia does not need to have more people out of work, especially if it is proven that these people are hard working Australians, who deserve to work in the career they have dedicated themselves to.
We therefore ask the House to review the LANTITE, understand that it is not a valid test and has caused many high amounts of stress and anxiety.
Modify the test, so that there is a pass rate.
Make the test an entrance exam, so people are not two years into their teaching jobs, which are now being threatened by this test.
Make it an entrance exam so people are not stuck with a degree that they can no longer use and left with HECS debts.
Please I ask you to please review this test.
From 1 citizen (EN1549)
Teachers
removing LANTITE
removing LANTITE to many reasons to type
We therefore ask the House to removing LANTITE
From 1 citizen (EN1550)
Teachers
Remove LANTITE for pre-service teachers

I have finished all the units and placements for the course all I have now is the literacy test. It wasn't a requirement for my course when I have started in 2015. I can read, write and speak 3 different languages competently. I studied the graduate Diploma in Education for secondary as a post graduate to become a FRENCH language teacher. I passed LANTITE Numeracy test from the first attempt but was unsuccessful in passing the literacy test. My question: Why is the literacy lantite test a requirement for a Language other than English teacher (LOTE) especially since it wasn't a requirement when I have enrolled into the course? I can't graduate or register in Vicrorian Institute of Teaching to become a Language other than English teacher. I have HECS debt to pay and the Uni did not disclose this in the policies an procedures. On another note, why should I be in the top 30% to actually pass the test, this is not defining a good teacher. I am finding the whole process is totally unfair. Those tests brought aditional expenses, anxiety and fear and not getting what we spent from time, effort and money. We have spend thousand of dollars to fulfill our dreams with no return. Thank you so much again for being our voice.
We therefore ask the House to remove LANTITE test especially from the pre-service teachers students who was enrolled in the teachings course before july 2016.
From 7 citizens (EN1553)
Teachers
Abolish LANTITE exam for teachers

The LANTITE exam is unjust and should be a prerequisite for entering an Educational degree. I started my degree in 2014 and passed my degree with a distinction average. I passed the Literacy LANTITE but failed the Numeracy 3 times and have currently spent thousands on tutoring, psychology sessions as I have been diagnosed with maths phobia and anxiety and have been placed on medication due to the stress the LANTITE has caused me.

I am a 41 year old mother of 4. I have been a nurse for the past 20 years. I found my true calling in Primary education but am being prevented from graduating because of the LANTITE. I also face a HECS debt of $36,000 for a degree that I cannot use. I feel the LANTITE does not prove that a person is able to facilitate and control a classroom of children and does not cater for the mental health needs and learning abilities of all Australians.

We therefore ask the House to allow students who started their degree before 2016 to graduate and gain teacher registration and make the LANTITE a prerequisite of an education degree, or enlist universities to assist students by adding a LANTITE unit in the degree to take the pressure of a rigid exam that impeads on individual learning and registration.
From 1 citizen (EN1554)
Teachers
Remove LANTITE

LANTITE is preventing many education students from graduating who could be currently in the workforce. LANTITE is currently booked out and inaccessible to many due to Covid19 causing delayed graduation. Some universities are imposing LANTITE as a graduation requirement for students who began in 2016 before it was a graduation requirement which disadvantages students expecially those who have completed a dual degree in early childhood education birth - 6 as LANTITE is not a registration requirement for early childhood teachers and therefore they could be working and assisting with the shortage of kinder teachers in rural Victoria.

We therefore ask the House to remove Lantite as a graduation requirement and find an alternative quality standard such as on the job assessment to assess the quality of teaching. Also remove LANTITE as a priority for students that commenced before 2017 so they can get into the workforce and remove Lantite for dual degree students (early childhood) so they can gain registration as early childhood teachers and commence work.
From 2 citizens (EN1558)
Teachers
Removal of LANTITE for pre service teachers

I am petitioning the house to reconsider the requirements of LANTITE for pre-service teachers. It was brought in in 2017 without universities engaging its students and now holding degrees to ransom, not allowing students to finish and graduate with their degree if they do not pass the LANTITE leaving students with a HECS debt and no degree to show for it putting these students in financial hardship, and years lost for nothing. In Queensland, LANTITE is not a requirement to register with the Teachers Collage but Swinburne has made it a requirement to graduate but will not allow me to do my last placement if I do not pass, how is this fair or right on the part of the university to take my money but will not let me complete my degree. LANTITE should be a requirement to get into university before starting an education degree.
We therefore ask the House to make LANTITE a requirement to begin an education degree and not a requirement to graduate
From 1 citizen (EN1559)
Teachers
Abolish Lantite Testing

Lantite Testing for graduating teachers is causing depression, anxiety and loss of work, income and teaching positions for thousands of students. I started my teaching degree in 2012 and completed all uni subjects and 4 Prac placements, passing it all. I unfortunately have failed the Numeracy Test twice by 1 and 2 points. This has deemed me unacceptable to teach, shattered my career and leaving me with no degree and $50k debt! This is a disgrace and would destroying... an very un-Australian.

We therefore ask the House to abolish Lantite Testing, or allow unlimited attempts to pass the tests. At present it is 3 attempts and your OUT! Very unfair. Law degrees allow unlimited attempts so should teaching. The test is one size fits all... this is not how people learn... this is what we are taught.
From 1 citizen (EN1560)
Teachers
Remove LANTITE
I am unable to graduate due to Lantite.
We therefore ask the House to remove the Lantite.
From 1 citizen (EN1561)
Teachers
Remove Lantite
I studied 5 years at uni struggling to pass this tests, so i have been removed for running out of attempt. This left me and many other students with:
-unemployment (stay on welfare benenit) and my friend told me I am burden
-30k of hecs
-low carreer oppoturnities
-i personally lose my scholarship, which i consider to be a brainchild
Abolish the test now OR open unlimited attempts like UK. No one is perfect. So we are deserved more chances. We want to contribute to THIS country and serve young generation.
If this problem continue, we wont be able to pay 30,000 HECS debt.
We therefore ask the House to remove the test so we:
-can pay back hecs debt
-have more career opportunities
-have job
-work for our passion
-stop burdening welfare
-stop us from having low self esteem
Please help.
From 1 citizen (EN1562)
Vaccination
Stop Mandatory Flu Vaccinations
To the House of Representatives,

I have elderly parents in a central Victorian nursing home and have been instructed to have a mandatory Flu vaccination to have the right to be able to visit my parents, this also effects all staff, any maintenance/delivery workers or any other people entering the facility. The only way out of having the vaccination is to have a signed Dr's certificate with a valid reason for not being able to have one. I presently have health issues and I believe that having the flu vaccination will only reduce my level of health. I honestly believe that being forced to have a vaccination is totally against my personal rights. My Dr has not agreed to supplying me with a signed certificate removing my need for the flu vaccination.

We therefore ask the House to remove the mandatory vaccination regulation to allow family and all other people visiting nursing homes throughout Australia to have the choice to decline the flu vaccination due to personal, health or religious reasons. I strongly urge that you see that mandatory vaccinations are against a persons free right to decide on their own medical treatment. I also have reason to believe that the Governor General has not signed off on this regulation, which makes it illegal. I also believe that there isn't enough clear evidence to prove that mandatory vaccinating reduces the risk to the elderly in homes; it may actually be to the contrary as vaccinated people shed viral cells afterwards.
From 40 citizens (EN1563)
National Rental Affordability Scheme
Continue the NRAS program beyond 2026

Hi I like the parliament to look into extending the National Rental Affordable Scheme beyond 2026 as low income families and pensioners will be the one who will have a rental increase of over 20% which they can't afford and will see people without a place to rent as they won't be able to afford the rent.. especially with the Covid 19 problem that's effecting all areas of the Australian economy...we don't want anymore homeless on the streets...

We therefore ask the House to commit to extended the NRAS program beyond 2026 so vulnerable families and pensioners don't suffer and end up without a place to rent as rents will be too expensive for them..
From 2 citizens (EN1565)
Teachers
Against LANTITE

This test is unfair. When I was accepted into my course in 2015 I was not aware of the LANTITE nor did my university push me to sit it straight away. I have excelled in my subjects and pracs and to me that proves I am a quality teacher. Myself and thousands of other students want to enter the workforce and contribute to the economy. Its just like a hairdresser passing their four years and then they get given one test and if they don't pass they cant become a hairdresser.

We therefore ask the House to get rid of Lantite. Online is fully booked for the foreseeable future and is run by an overseas company who has been hit harder than us. Although, if there could possibly be another sort of assessment that could be completed within University that would be appreciated as well.
From 1 citizen (EN1566)
Teachers
Removal and Restructure of LANTITE for Pre-service Teachers

Understandably it is important to ensure that quality teachers are working in our schools. However, as a measure of assessing teacher quality, the LANTITE is neither an effective nor ethical form of assessment on teacher quality and is in fact preventing highly experienced and qualified pre-service teachers from entering the profession.

Due to many inconsistencies and a lack of transparency on behalf of ACER, Universities and individual state government legislation, many pre-service teacher's at the final stages of their degrees were dumped with the requirement of passing the LANTITE at their own cost. Failing to do so, regardless of circumstances such as learning disabilities, mental health issues, and basic negligence on behalf of ACER in providing adequate and up to date resources for students to prepare for the test, students are left with no other option but to abandon their degrees. This has become an even greater issue due to the COVID-19 pandemic, as restrictions now prevent even more students from completing the test.

We therefore ask the House to immediately review the LANTITE, it's implementation, and the laws changed that enforced LANTITE as an exit requirement. It should never have been made compulsory for students at the end of their degree. The goal posts have been moved on thousands of high quality teachers who can most certainly meet the literacy and numeracy requirements necessary for teaching, outside of the complexities and pressures imposed upon pre-service teachers to meet this "political bandaid" approach to ensuring quality teaching in our schools.
From 1 citizen (EN1568)
Teachers
Remove LANTITE testing.

I began my bachelor's degree in early childhood education in 2013, long before the mandatory LANTITE test was introduced. As it was not a requirement of graduation at the time of my enrolment, I feel it is a case of moving the goalpost. Due to domestic violence and health issues, and now the pandemic, I have been unable to complete the test and therefore cannot enrol in my final placement and graduate. This also means that instead of making a difference in the lives of today's children, and contributing to society, I cannot work in the field I am almost fully qualified for and more importantly, passionate about.
We therefore ask the House to abolish the LANTITE testing for preservice teachers.
From 6 citizens (EN1569)
Teachers
Exempt from Lantite
To the Hon. Speaker of the House of Representatives and Members of the House of Representatives,

I am writing to request that Lantite exam be removed or for students who are required to complete their degree this year to be exempt from this distressful consequence of losing 5 years of ceaseless hard work and accomplishing our dreams.

I've completed my Bachelor of Primary Education at the University of Sydney in 2019 without ever failing an assignment, unit or placememt. However, due to being unable to satisfy this external exam (which was introduced during my second semester of second year of university), I am currently unable to complete my internship and graduate.

I am currently working as a casual teacher at a school where I was offered a full-time position (on more than one occasion as well as from a few other locations) for the rest of the year. However, due to my current situation, I am unable to accept any offers or properly commence my dream career as a Primary Teacher.
Most sincerely,
Young Ye (Gloria) Ryu

We therefore ask the House to reconsider if Lantite exam is a rightful exam to determine if a person is destined to be a teacher. I undoubtedly believe I am called to be a teacher at such a time as this.
From 1 citizen (EN1570)
Teachers
Abolish LANTITE

LANTITE is a government requirement for education students to graduate, due to COVID-19 students are unable to sit the test as testing centres are close as they are run by an overseas company. As you are aware overseas has been hit by COVID-19 and will be in restriction for longer than us in Australia. Please remove LANTITE as student have worked extremely hard to achieve their degrees.
We therefore ask the House to abolish LANTITE or replace it with a unit of study to produce quality teaches.
From 23 citizens (EN1571)
Teachers
Suspend lantite due to covid 19
Covid 19 has impacted student teachers as many cannot graduate due to the lantite.

The lantite is administered by proctor u - an American company. America has been severely effected by covid 19. It is unfair that student teachers are placed in perpetual limbo until the corona situation normalises in the states. This needs to be fixed immediately. Suspend lantite for the duration of the pandemic.

We therefore ask the House to suspend the lantite examination for the duration of the covid 19 pandemic to allow student teachers to graduate. Instead tie lantite to accreditation/ registration requirements to be completed once covid has subsided.
From 1 citizen (EN1572)
Services Australia
Royal Commission into Centrelink /Services Australia
We request the House to change Centrelink/Services Australia laws to reflect fairness in Deeming, Applications and Reviews. The current laws are unfair.

We therefore ask the House to establish a Royal Commission in dealing with the quagmire and unfair antiquated laws of Centrelink/Services Australia. as it deals with General Applications, Seniors, Deeming, & Appeals./Reviews. As the law stands it is unrealistic to be told the deeming is 3% by Centrelink when in reality it is on a sliding scale which in itself is unrealistic. At the top end of 2.5% the Banks are not paying interest even close to the 2.5%. , more like 0.5%. People of Australia of goodwill should standby a system which brings true fairness and equality in dealing with Centrelink/Services Australia.
From 3 citizens (EN1573)
Teachers
Removal of the LANTITE

As a Diploma qualified Early Childhood Educator I entered University to follow my dream to become a Kindergarten Teacher. However, the Federal Government has decided a 'one size fits all' test determines whether my dream becomes a reality.
I have completed all my University requirements and should be graduating this year.
The LANTITE is stopping me!
I began my degree in 2015, no mention of LANTITE testing!
I feel discriminated against, the LANTITE is NOT a registration requirement as an Early Year's Teacher, but must be completed successfully as a Bachelor of Education student.
The Bachelor of Teaching degree has been phased out, leaving no other pathway forward.
Mr Tehan can you please explain to the thousands of potential Early Childhood Teachers how is this fair or equitable.
Kind regards, Diane Robinson
We therefore ask the House to re-consider the validity of imposing LANTITE testing for graduating students who desire to work in the Early Years Sector as Early Childhood Teachers.
From 2 citizens (EN1574)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Amendment Bill 2020

p.span: Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Amendment Bill 2020
Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Amendment Bill 2020

With Federal Parliament flat out dealing with the social and economic fallout of the COVID-19 pandemic, now is hardly the right time for a government to introduce legislation giving ASIO the power to question 14-year-old children, interfere with the rights of legal advisers, and enable the tracking of individuals without the need for a warrant. But Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton has no such qualms. On Wednesday he introduced the benignly titled Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Amendment Bill 2020. This is an attack on our Australian values.

We therefore ask the House to reject Peter Dutton's proposed law that would allow ASIO to seek a warrant so they can question young people between 14 and 18 if that young person is a target of an ASIO investigation into politically-motivated violence: broad criteria to say the least. Then there is a serious attack on the fundamental right of a person, whether they be 14 or 40, to choose their own lawyer when they are subject to investigation by ASIO. The bill allows for a prescribed authority, which is a judge/Administrative Appeals member selected by the government, to stop a person ASIO is seeking to question from contacting their lawyer if satisfied, based on circumstances relating to the lawyer, that, if the subject is permitted to contact the lawyer, a person involved in activity prejudicial to security may be alerted that the activity is being investigated.
From 24 citizens (EN1575)
Teachers
Remove LANTITE (Literacy and Numeracy test)

Requesting the LANTITE needs to be removed as there are high demands in need of teachers. Due to the LANTITE test, graduated teachers aren't able to teach due to the requirement. Therefore leaving graduated teachers jobless.

Testing places are closed because of COVID-19. Online is fully booked for the foreseeable future and is run by an overseas company who has been hit harder than us. This test is unfair. When I was accepted into my course in 2014 I was not aware of the LANTITE nor did my university push me to sit it straight away as we were notified about it in 2017 ( the year of graduation). I have excelled in my subjects and pracs and to me that proves I am a quality teacher. Myself and thousands of other students want to enter the workforce and contribute to the economy. Its just like a hairdresser passing their four years , receiving a certificate and then they get given one test and if they don't pass they cant become a hairdresser.

We therefore ask the House to house to remove the LANTITE as the test should have been implemented on an entry requirement of the course. Teachers need to be teaching students to provide the best learning for all students. Children are our priority.
From 2 citizens (EN1579)
Teachers
Remove Lantite

I am a student from Australia Catholic University Melbourne. I have completed all my units of work and placements to become a teacher. I started my Bachelor of Education/ Primary in 2014 and half way through my degree was when the lantite was introduced.
Reasons for removal:
- This exam has been implemented differently in each state.
- There is no relevance to the mythologies and pedagogy of teaching.
- Acer have no ministerial oversight and routinely ignore request for reasonable adjustments despite medical evidence
-Schools need to be supported due to shortages.
- Other universities in Melbourne (Victoria University, Latrobe, RMIT, Monash, Swinburne and Deakin) have all allowed some students to graduate knowing they have no lantite completed.

In my circumstance I have been out of university for almost 2 years now and have not been able to use my degree. I spent 6months seeing psychologist to help support my stress and anxiety and another 6 months studying. Now COVID 19 has impacted up lantite aswell.
We therefore ask the House to discuss the removal of the lantite or create alternatives that DO NOT rely on standardised testing for students like myself.
From 1 citizen (EN1580)
Visas
Allow temporary visa holders to travel to Australia.

Temporary Visa Holders(Subclass 457,482,485 and other visa holders) who are stuck overseas due to Australian Border Closure. All of us trying to apply exemptions to Australian Border Force Commissioner but every time he is rejecting our applications with replying we are not meeting the criteria for exemptions he is only granting the exemptions tp people he want to and who are highlighted in news as they were also rejected by the commissioner many times before and they also had the same reasons travel to Australia like us and it's not fair with us isn't it ? From 2203 citizens (EN1596)
Employment
Inquiry into S382 to 384 of Fair Work Act 2009.
The petitioner expresses concerns that Sections 382 to 384 (the unfair dismissal sections) of the Fair Work Act 2009, that affect Australia's 2.6 million casual employees:

Contain criteria - continuous service, regularity and systematic engagement AND a reasonable expectation of continuing employment – that are imposed exclusively upon casual employees, and that exclude casual employees from the operation of the unfair dismissal remedial relief provisions of Part 3-2, Division 4 of the Fair Work Act on the ground that an employee's termination was unfair, harsh, unjust or unreasonable;
Offend the assumption of the fundamental common law doctrine of legal equality which confines the scope of the Commonwealth's legislative power identified in the Constitution; and

Contravene the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights: Article 14(1) (equality before the courts and tribunals), read together with Article 2(1) (equal access to courts and tribunals), and Article 26 (equality before the law and entitlement to the equal protection of the law).

We therefore ask the House to summon an inquiry into the ongoing operation of Sections 382 to 384 of the Fair Work Act 2009, into how those sections restrict (given the reasons set out above) the ability of casual employees to seek proper redress (including a hearing of the merits of their applications for protection from unfair dismissal, and for compensation) for the termination of their employment.
From 10 citizens (EN1597)
Climate Change
Endorse The Marine Arctic Peace Sanctuary Treaty Protecting All Life

To The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, like every nation on Earth, Australia depends on the Arctic Ocean as a global life support that keeps us cool and healthy. But today it is under threat. There is 75% less Arctic sea ice today than 50 years ago, making the Arctic Ocean vulnerable to exploitation which exacerbates the problem. A melted Arctic Ocean causes global weather patterns to destabilize, leading to floods, droughts and fires, storms, sea level rise, crop failures, ocean acidification, coral bleaching, food and water shortages, refugees, diseases, and deaths. Leading biologists urge us to protect 50% of the entire planet immediately to prevent mass extinction. As the world's largest marine protected area at 8 million square km, MAPS protects 2.2% of the world's oceans, which fits naturally with the United Nations' proposed commitment to protect 30% of our oceans by 2030. MAPS also supports nations in meeting their objectives under the Paris Agreement, and helps achieve almost every UN Sustainable Development Goal. The MAPS Treaty accords protection for the Arctic Ocean similar to that which has existed for decades in Antarctica. It declares all ocean waters north of the Arctic Circle off limits to exploitation, and enters into force with the signatures of 99 UN member states.

We therefore ask the House to recommend Australia's formal endorsement of the Marine Arctic Peace Sanctuary Treaty on an urgent basis, to protect the citizens and ecosystems of Australia, and all life on Earth.

We can have security without being a Security State.

From 51 citizens (EN1603)
Family Law
Urgent changes to Family Law legislation

Current family law and child support legislation financially incentivises resident parents to make false allegations and encourage conflict to gain sole responsibility and care of children and separate children from non-resident parents.
This contributes significantly to adverse mental health outcomes for children, non-resident parents and extended family.

Social costs of these adverse outcomes include suicide, overwhelmed courts and social services, perpetuating the cycle of broken families and ineffective protection for true victims of domestic violence.
We therefore ask the House to
1. Link payments of child support strictly to terms set in parenting plans and court orders so that non-compliance by resident parents is not financially incentivised.

2. Prohibit relocation of parents with children without a finalised parenting plan or court orders, to encourage parents to enter into mediation, counselling and other conflict resolution instead of litigation, and where litigation is necessary, to incentivise both parties to settle litigation as soon as possible.

3. Introduce video conference arbitration, where parties self-represent, prior to court litigation and empower arbitrators to issue orders that have effect as court orders to alleviate the burden on courts. Arbitration panels are proposed to comprise a family law specialist lawyer, a family report writer and a clinical psychiatrist. Parents will equally share costs for arbitration, and Legal Aid funding be made available for parties suffering financial hardship.
4. Restrict court intervention and supervised visitation of children to matters that involve a criminal or child safety investigation or conviction, or non-compliance with arbitration orders

From 784 citizens (EN1618)
Indigenous Australians
Calling for an Inquiry into First Nation Women In Custody
We call upon the House of Representatives to establish an inquiry into First Nation Women In custody

It has been almost 30 years since the Royal commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody released its 339 recommendations. Since that time more than 400 First Nation people have died in custody and the number of First Nation people in custody and under remand has risen.

First Nation women are at risk with an alarming number of women remanded in custody for minor offences. The legal system as it relates to women is over burdened and under resourced. The various bail laws place an increased burden on the system resulting in a high proportion of First Nation women remaining in custody for minor offences.
The current laws and processes around bail and remand are inadequate to deal with the complex and traumatic histories of vulnerable First Nation Women
More resourcing for community services, including legal services that help women are needed.

We therefore ask the House to initiate a committee inquiry into and report on the intergenerational trauma for First Nation Women and the underlying causes relating to their interactions with the justice systems. In particular, the inquiry needs to investigate the current laws and processes around bail and remand, the provision of medical care to First Nation Women whilst in custody and the inadequacy of levels of resourcing and support for community services in order to prevent First Nation Women from being incarcerated.
