From 29 citizens (EN1620)
Hearing Health
Education - Mandatory study of AUSLAN & Deaf Culture Awareness

Currently 1 in 6 Australians are affected by hearing loss and there are estimated to be 30,000 Deaf AUSLAN users with total hearing loss. With the dramatic start to 2020 (fires, floods, Covid-19) Politicians are holding press conferences nearly every day and it is heartening to see, in the main, AUSLAN Interpreters present ensuring the Deaf Community are being kept up to date with changes as they occur. Many people assume tv captions meet the information needs of the Deaf Community but these captions are in English - AUSLAN is NOT signed English and is not an appropriate means of communication.

NDIS recognises hearing impairment as a disability. A principle of NDIS is that people with disability have the same rights as other members of Australian society to realise their potential for physical, social, emotional and intellectual development. NDIS outcomes include inclusive and accessible communities; personal and community support. Increasing the percentage of Australians able to communicate via AUSLAN & who have an appreciation of Deaf Culture will assist the achievement of these outcomes.

We therefore ask the House to require AUSLAN, and the Study of Deaf Culture, to be a mandatory subject for all year levels in all Primary Schools. To increase the number of Accredited AUSLAN Interpreters (which are sadly lacking to meet the support needs of people with a hearing disability) AUSLAN/Deaf Culture studies must continue to be offered as an Elective Subject at all Secondary Schools.
All schools - Public, Religious & Independent
From 40 citizens (EN1621)
Charitable Organisations
Large Charity Appeals Reporting Requirements

Australia has a history of natural disasters (floods, bushfires & drought) following which Charities run Appeals to raise donations to assist those adversely affected, however there does not seem to be any statutory requirement for those Charities to declare how the funds raised from each Appeal have been utilised. A recent example of this is the Australian Red Cross' Bushfire Appeal to raise funds for those people & communities impacted by the 2019/2020 Summer Bushfires. The information on their website provides a rough overview as to how the funds are expected to be expended. On review of the 2018/2019 Audited Financials, under Note 4, Donations are reported by Appeal but nowhere in the Financials is there corresponding information as to how those funds have been utilised against each Appeal. This doesn't provide transparency that Donated funds have been utilised for the purpose for which they were donated.

We therefore ask the House to legislate that all Large Charities are required to include a Profit & Loss Statement for each Appeal where $1.0m or more has been donated, and that the individual Appeal Profit & Loss Statement must clearly show how the funds donated have been used to ensure that they have been used for the purpose for which they were donated (eg if 5 Appeals were held, and for 3 Donations received were over $1.0m, the Charity would be required to have a Note to the Financial Statement and include a Separate Profit & Loss Statement for those 3 Appeals).

These students have successfully completed the units in their degrees, as well as professional practise in the form of placements. Throughout degrees and placements, the importance of literacy and numeracy is highlighted, and students are graded on their abilities to successfully implement these areas in their teaching.

We implore you to support this notion of removing LANTITE. In doing so, you will be contributing and assisting Australia's economic return through this pandemic and recession as well as ensuring that our children continue to have access to quality teachers
We therefore ask the House to remove LANTITE
From 3 citizens (EN1628)
Teachers
Stop LANTITE for this pandemic situation

We therefore ask the House toAs a result of these unprecedented times, testing centres are closed and the students only option is to sit the LANTITE test online, for the foreseeable future. As the online version of LANTITE is run by an overseas company (U.S), spaces are limited and the majority of education students are being left without access or alternatives, forced out of their degree and are having their degree's withheld from them. This is stopping thousands of pre-service teachers from entering the profession, progressing in their education degrees, graduating, and registering. This will not only stop people from graduating and entering the field this year but also delay students in graduating for years to come.

These students have successfully completed the units in their degrees, as well as professional practise in the form of placements. Throughout degrees and placements, the importance of literacy and numeracy is highlighted, and students are graded on their abilities to successfully implement these areas in their teaching.

We implore you to support this notion of removing LANTITE. In doing so, you will be contributing and assisting Australia's economic return through this pandemic and recession as well as ensuring that our children continue to have access to quality teachers.
From 2 citizens (EN1629)
Teachers
REMOVE LANTITE

If we as teachers took the same rigid and complex approach to assessing our student's abilities in Literacy and Numeracy, only to abandon them when they fail, leaving them in a fixed position with no other options to move forward, in the same way the government has chosen to use the LANTITE to assess its future teachers; Australia's education system would be a laughing stock and an utter failure.

The issue lies fundamentally with ACER, it's implementation of the LANTITE, and it's refusal to work openly and transparently with Universities and students regarding the LANTITE test content, student test results, and ACER'S overall negligence in providing constructive feedback and relevant, up-to-date resources to students and universities that accurately reflects the content of the test and what students are required to do in order to pass. ACER have on more than one occasion, set high-achieving, quality Pre-service teachers up to fail, at the cost of their careers, and their degrees.
We therefore ask the House to remove lantite as a requirement for education courses.
From 2 citizens (EN1630)
Teachers
Abolish LANTITE for all.

Lantite does not measure teacher quality. It does not measure an individual's compassion, care, patience and true teaching ability. How does lantite test teacher quality when a person can only pass when they are in the top 30%.

The lantite literacy and numeracy test is not basic literacy and numeracy. These tests are pitched beyond a year 9 level and include statistics and graphs that are difficult to read. These two tests are causing anxiety, depression and high levels of stress on our future teachers.

In the Masters of Teaching program at QUT there is a criteria on every assignment that a student must pass spelling, grammar and sentence structure to pass the assignment. Therefore, this proves that literacy and numeracy is embedded throughout our degree.
The government wants quality teachers and in my opinion for this to happen we need to improve on teacher development and stop using standardised tests to measure teachers.
In this email I have attached some important photos to prove there is a teacher shortage and how lantite has affected this.
We therefore ask the House to abolish LANTITE for all education students.
From 9 citizens (EN1631)
Teachers
Lantite Test

I would like you to address the problem of the Lantite Test. As a teacher of 30 years I am dismayed to discover that many outstanding young student teachers have been unable to complete their degree due to failing the test three times. My daughter is one of them. She is a Graphic Designer and decided to go back in 2018 and obtain a Masters in Primary Teaching as she wishes to be an Art/Primary teacher. She is a visual learner and the test does not cater for this. No hard copies are handed out so she can highlight key words. She completed a teaching round at Balnarring Primary School, and they were so impressed at her 'visual teaching' they asked her back for a second round. The state has lost out on a dedicated and talented teacher. The debt accrued from tutors, the Lantite test and now a HECS debt from a Masters she can not complete; is outrageous. The test has also accelerated mental health issues in our youth. This is very concerning. When I attended uni in 1983 we had to complete a English, Maths and Music test through the uni. It was free and we could sit it every week for three years until we passed. I had trouble with the music but after 10 attempts I was able to pass. Definitely food for thought! PLEASE PLEASE re-consider the Lantite test. Kind Regards, Jenny Tomkins
We therefore ask the House to reconsider the Lantite test.
From 9 citizens (EN1632)
Aboriginal Deaths in Custody
Full implementation of recommendations
The Deloitte Access Economics review of recommendations from the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody found :

"Our review found that across all the recommendations, 64% have been implemented in full, 14% have been mostly implemented, 16% have been partially implemented and 6% have not been implemented. The most action has been taken to respond to recommendations that relate to the justice system, prison safety, and reconciliation, land needs and international obligations.
The least action has been taken to respond to recommendations that relate to non-custodial approaches and self-determination."
By implementing the remaining recommendations (in full) we can ensure all action that could be taken (recommended) has been taken to support the indigenous members of our community.

We therefore ask the House to work towards a full and complete implementation of the recommendations with specific reference to Non-Custodial approaches (recommendations 79-91) and Self Determination (recommendations 188-204).

Building these approaches into processes that are regularly, independently reviewed and the results of these publicly available via freedom of information at both a federal and state government level.
From 13 citizens (EN1633)
Teachers
Remove LANTITE

Due to the unforeseeable conditions of the world we live in today, University students are being forced to complete their LANTITE online. These online tests have limited spaces and therefore hundreds of students are being forced to push their degrees back and are unable to graduate. Universities are currently placing so much pressure on completing the test however due to these current conditions not only are people unable to afford the cost of the test they are unable to physically sit it.
We therefore ask the House to remove the LANTITE in its entirety, or allow students to make arrangements to accommodate their timely graduation.
From 14 citizens (EN1635)
Teachers
LANTITE

As a result of these unprecedented times, testing centres are closed and the students only option is to sit the LANTITE test online, for the foreseeable future. As the online version of LANTITE is run by an overseas company (U.S), spaces are limited and the majority of education students are being left without access or alternatives, forced out of their degree and are having their degree's withheld from them. This is stopping thousands of pre-service teachers from entering the profession, progressing in their education degrees, graduating, and registering. This will not only stop people from graduating and entering the field this year but also delay students in graduating for years to come.

These students have successfully completed the units in their degrees, as well as professional practise in the form of placements. Throughout degrees and placements, the importance of literacy and numeracy is highlighted, and students are graded on their abilities to successfully implement these areas in their teaching.

We therefore ask the House to support this notion of removing LANTITE. In doing so, you will be contributing and assisting Australia's economic return through this pandemic and recession as well as ensuring that our children continue to have access to quality teachers.
From 10 citizens (EN1636)
Australian Constitution
Acknowledge Indigenous Australians as first peoples in a Constitutional reform

There is clear evidence to show Indigenous peoples have occupied this land before European settlers. The lack of acknowledgement has led to violence, racism, murder and a system that is slowly erasing an oppressed group of people. Sovereignty was never ceded and Indigenous peoples are suffering because of our European ancestors. Today it is unfathomable to consider a Government would allow this to happen, but the effects are still prevalent. We are standing on stolen land. It is in-humane to ignore the clear violation of unspoken Civil Rights in 2020. If a referendum is successful, it will ensure there will be no discrimination in the Constitution, and will be the first step in a path of abolishing racism. Australia is a young Nation and we must be accountable for our actions now, before more lives are lost.
We therefore ask the House to consider a change the Constitution to acknowledge Indigenous Australian's and Torre Straight Islanders as the Nation's first peoples.
From 374 citizens (EN1637)
Taxation
Junk food tax to subsidise affordable fresh healthy food

I ask that the government charge a 10 -20% tax on all junk food like biscuits, chips, lollies, chocolate, ice cream, sugary drinks ect and use the money to subsidise the cost of Australian grown fresh fruit, vegetables, dairy and meat to make it more affordable for low income earners to have access to healthier food choices and by also making junk food a less cost affective way of eating.
We therefore ask the House to put in place a junk food tax to subsidise Australian grown fresh fruit, vegetables, dairy and meat to make healthy options affordable for all peoples.
From 47 citizens (EN1638)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:20): Ministerial responses to petitions previously presented to the House have been received as follows:
Minister for Men
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter dated 11 February 2020 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, regarding petition number EN1185 concerning the appointment of a Minister for men and boys. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf.

Under section 64 of the Constitution, the Governor-General, on the advice of the Prime Minister, appoints Ministers, establishes Departments of State and formally allocates executive responsibility among Ministers through the Administrative Arrangements Order.

The position of Minister for Women reflects the Government's priorities of strengthening women's economic security including women's workforce participation, supporting more women into leadership positions, and ensuring that women and their children are safe from violence. These priorities reflect lower rates of workforce participation by women, lower representation of women in leadership positions, and higher rates of domestic and family violence against women.
The Prime Minister considers that the current ministry appropriately reflects the Government's priorities and does not propose amending existing arrangements.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Prime Minister's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton (Petition No. EN1185)
Gambling
Dear Chairman
Thank you for your email dated 15 April 2020 concerning Petition EN1217 which relates to gambling advertising.

I note the petition requests that the House of Representatives enact a ban on showing sports-betting and gambling (including scratch-cards and lotteries) advertising in Australia on television, radio and online platforms.

The Morrison Government recognises the importance of gambling promotions being presented in a responsible manner. Advertising regulation in Australia is intended to strike a balance between legitimate commercial interests and appropriate community safeguards.

Most content broadcast in Australia is regulated by co-regulatory codes of practice developed by broadcasting industry sectors in accordance with the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. This co-regulatory system recognises the importance of ensuring that television and radio content reflects community standards. Codes of practice are available on ACMA's website at acma.gov.au/industry-codes-practice.

The Commercial Television industry Code of Practice (the Commercial TV Code) applies to commercial free-to-air television broadcasters. The Commercial TV Code is also available from the website of commercial television industry peak body, Free TV Australia, at www.freetv.com.au/what-we-do/industry-standards.

The Subscription Broadcast Television Codes of Practice (Subscription TV Code) applies to subscription television broadcasters. The Subscription TV Code is also available from the website of subscription media industry peak body, the Australian Subscription Television and Radio Association (ASTRA) at astra.org.au/advocacy/codes-of-practice.

The Commercial Radio Code of-Practice (Commercial Radio Code) applies to commercial radio broadcasters. The Commercial Radio Code is also available from the website of the commercial radio industry peak body, Commercial Radio Australia, at www.commercialradio.com.au/legal/regulation-codes.

span.span: s viewing hours on broadcast platforms

p.span: The Commercial TV Code prohibits gambling advertisements:
during General (G), Preschool (P) or Children's (C) rated programs broadcast between:
6.00 am and 8.30 am: and
4.00 pm and 7.00 pm; and
during any program that is broadcast between 5.00 am and 8.30 pm and which is principally directed at children.

These prohibitions do not apply to advertisements broadcast in a news. current affairs or sports programs during those time periods. They also do not apply to advertisements relating to such things as government sanctioned lotteries, keno or competitions, or, generally, to advertisements for entertainment or dining facilities where gambling may take place.

The Subscription TV Code requires relevant licensees to take into account the intellectual and emotional maturity of the intended audience of the relevant channel when scheduling advertising relating to betting or gambling.

span.span: Gambling advertisements during live sports broadcasts

p.span: In 2018 further restrictions were applied to the showing of gambling promotions during live sporting events broadcast on commercial television. commercial radio, subscription television and the Special Broadcasting Service. More information about these restrictions is available on ACMA's website at acma.gov.au/gambling-ads-during-live-sports-broadcasts.

Broadcasting industry codes of practice are periodically reviewed. Members of the public may contact the relevant peak industry body to raise their concerns, and to enquire about how they can contribute to future review processes.
For commercial television broadcasters, Free TV Australia's contact details are:
Free TV Australia
First Floor, 44 Avenue Road
Mosman NSW 2088
Web: www.freetv.com.au
For subscription television broadcasters, ASTRA 's contact details are:
Australian Subscription Television and Radio Association
Level 2, 4 Broadcast Way
Artarmon NSW 2064
Email: admin@astra.org.au
Web: www.astra.org.au
For commercial radio broadcasters, Commercial Radio Australia's contact details are:
Commercial Radio Australia Ltd
Level 5, 88 Foveaux Street
Surry Hills NSW 2010
Web: www.commercialradio.com.au

span.span: Gambling advertisements during sports streamed over the internet

p.span: In September 2018 new rules came into effect which restrict the showing of gambling promotions during on line streams of live sporting events. The Broadcasting Services (Online Content Service Provider Rules) 2018 (Online Rules) contain gambling promotions restrictions that are, to the extent possible, similar to those which broadcasting industry codes impose on the broadcast of live sporting events.
More information about the Online Rules is available on the ACMA's website at acma.gov.au/gambling-ads-during-sport-streamed-over-internet.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Ministerfor Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts,Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN1217)
Film Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter dated 9 April 2020, in relation to Petition EN1298, concerning Australia's role in ensuring diversity in the exhibition of films.

The Morrison Government recognises and promotes diversity in the screen industry and has a range of programs to ensure that Australian stories are accessible domestically and internationally across all platforms. Screen Australia is the Government's principal funding agency for providing support to Australian screen practitioners to develop compelling Australian stories. Screen Australia has a strong focus on diversity both on screen and behind the camera.

Through the Government's continued support of SBS and the ABC, the Australian public has access to a broad range of international content. Australians of all backgrounds and interests are able to participate in the international cultural landscape and experience the true variety of the world's film and television offerings. Diverse cultural capital is essential to the continued growth of Australia, and the Australian Government will continue its commitment to diversity when supporting the film and television industries.

While film distributors in Australia are private companies and decisions relating to the marketing of productions are commercial decisions for those organisations, technological developments have contributed to the provision of a range of pathways for distributors to reach different markets, and this can include the release of content in different languages to reach broader audiences.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1298 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Ministerfor Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts,Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN1298)
Australian Bushfires
Dear Mr O'Dowd

span.span: Petition EN1305 - Bushfire donation administration fees

p.span: Thank you for your letter of 15 April 2020 concerning petition EN1305 requesting an investigation into the administrative fees levied by entities who accept donations, with particular reference to the recent bushfires.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that all donations from the public are used appropriately, including where donated for that purpose, to support bushfire relief and recovery activities.

The Government regulates all charities through the Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission (ACNC). Registered charities are required to comply with a set of governance standards that ensure assets and income, including donations, are used only for their charitable purpose. The ACNC also requires charities to submit financial reports and an annual infom1ation statement on their activities. The ACNC makes this information on charities publicly available on its charity register at www.acnc.gov.au/charity. The ACNC also provides guidance for the public on how to ensure donations are going to a reputable entity and will be spent for the purpose for which they are given.

Charities must also not mislead the public as to how their donations are used. If charities make false or misleading statements about their fundraising arrangements, they may contravene Australian Consumer Law. This is a breach of the ACNC Governance Standards and the ACNC takes these matters seriously.

The experience of many charities during the Black Saturday bushfires was that long-term community support was needed to rebuild. Similarly, recovery from the recent summer bushfires will require sustained support from the charity sector over the longer-term and into the future. The ACNC is working with these charities to ensure they continue to meet their reporting obligations, and that funds donated are used appropriately.

I note the petition's request for the House to address the issue of a charity's administration costs. Charities involved in bushfire assistance have proactively published information on their websites indicating exactly where the funds will be used and what percentage will be used for administration costs.

This publicly available information greatly assists all donors to understand how their donations are spent. The petition particularly singled out the work of the Red Cross, the Salvation Anny and St Vincent de Paul. The websites of all three charities provides detailed information on how bushfire donations have been and will be utilised, and gives assurance that all funds donated for bushfire relief and recovery efforts will be used for this purpose. All three charities are to be commended for their efforts in transparently providing up-to-date information on their work.

While charities should be striving to maximise funds available for achieving their charitable purpose, it is important to note that this will include expenditure on running the charity in order to deliver services. Administration costs in and of themselves do not indicate how effective a charity is in achieving its purpose and must be considered alongside a range of factors. However, if there is evidence that administration costs or salaries are unreasonably high the ACNC may look into the operations to establish that the charity is operating in accordance with the ACNC Governance Standards.
Further, on 29 January, the ACNC Commissioner publicly indicated that he will be conducting audits of charities specifically related to bushfire activities within the next twelve months.

I would also draw the petitioner's attention to the work of the National Bushfire Recovery Agency (NBRA). The NBRA was established by the Prime Minister in January 2020 to lead and coordinate a national response to rebuilding communities affected by bushfires across large parts of Australia.

The NBRA works to connect people, communities, primary producers and businesses with the services and assistance they may need to rebuild and recover to support the recovery of all Australians. Further, the NBRA coordinates the National Charities Bushfire Recovery Forum to assist not-for-profits to collectively deliver relief and recovery efforts to bushfire affected communities.

I trust this information addresses the concerns of the petitioners, and demonstrates the degree of regulatory and government oversight that currently already exists, not only for charities involved in bushfire recovery efforts, but for all charities.
from theAssistant Minister for Finance, Charities and Electoral Matters, Senator Seselja (Petition No. EN1305)
Australian Flag
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 9 April 2020 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, enclosing petition EN1320, which requests that the Government change the design of the Australian National Flag. The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf as I am the Minister responsible for national symbols policy.
The Australian National Flag is Australia's foremost national symbol. It was first flown in 1901 and has become an expression of Australian identity and pride.
The Flags Act 1953 requires a poll of all Australians before the design of the Australian National Flag can be changed. The Government is not considering changing the flag's design.

The Government remains focused on delivering the Closing the Gap refresh, in partnership with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and the states and territories. On 26 May 2019, the Prime Minister announced the appointment of Australia's first Aboriginal Cabinet Minister in the Minister for Indigenous Australians, the Hon Ken Wyatt AM MP.

Minister Wyatt has said that his key focus will be to ensure better health, education and safety outcomes for all First Australians, with access to real jobs and greater opportunities. He is also dedicated to achieving Constitutional Recognition for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Morton (Petition No. EN1320)
Qualifications of Members
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your letter referring petition number EN1119 for response. My apologies for the delay in reply. The petition requested that legislation be changed to allow any voter anywhere in Australia to challenge the eligibility of a candidate in any electorate.

Sections 353 and 355 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 provide that a petition disputing the outcome of an election be addressed to the High Court sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns. Petitions disputing the outcome of an election for the House of Representatives must be signed by a candidate running in that election, or by a person qualified to vote in that election. Petitions can also be submitted by the Electoral Commission.

In conducting elections, writs are issued for each 'division' (electorate) in which candidates are running for election to the House of Representatives. In the case of a general election, such as the 2019 Federal election, writs were issued and returned for all 151 federal electoral divisions. When considering petitions made to the Court of Disputed Returns, each division's election result is provided for in a separate writ, and must be considered, and contested, separately. Consequently, individuals who are not eligible to vote in a particular electorate are not considered participants in that division's election.

Allowing any voter within Australia to challenge any candidate's eligibility would undermine the democratic process, by allowing someone who did not participate in a division's election to potentially impact that election's result.
The Government has no plans to change the law to allow voters to challenge the eligibility of candidates outside their electorate.
I have also copied this latter to the Assistant Minister for Finance, Charities and Electoral Matters.
Kind regards,
from theMinister for Finance,Senator Cormann(Petition No. EN1119)
Economy
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for correspondence originally directed by Mr Llew O'Brien to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1179. The correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The Petition proposes that half of the compulsory superannuation guarantee (SG) be redirected into employees' take home wages. Compulsory SG is a central and longstanding feature of Australia's retirement income system and is intended to allow Australians to improve their standard of living in retirement. Reducing the SG contribution rate would not be consistent with this objective and the Morrison Government therefore has no plans to introduce legislation to this effect.

More broadly, allowing individuals to redirect their superannuation savings to alternative uses would negate the benefits of regular superannuation contributions and compounding interest and would result in lower retirement incomes for Australians than would otherwise be the case.

To stimulate the economy, the Morrison Government has acted decisively to support households and businesses and address the significant economic consequences of the Coronavirus. A total of $259 billion is being injected into the economy in order to keep Australians in work and businesses in business. The package is designed to support businesses to retain jobs and manage short-term cash flow challenges, provide support to individuals, severely affected communities and regions, and to ensure the continued flow of credit in the Australian economy.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and Financial Technology, Senator Hume (Petition No. EN1179)
Energy
Dear Mr O'Brien
I refer to your correspondence of 11 February 2020 regarding Petition Number EN1201.
Australia must play its part in the global response to climate change and we are doing our bit. While it is not widely reported, Australia's emissions are coming down. In fact:
Australia's emissions are lower now than when the Coalition came to Government in 2013.

Australia's emissions are more than 13 per cent lower than 2005 levels (the year from which our 2030 Paris target is measured). This compares to flatlining emissions in Canada and less than a one per cent decrease for New Zealand.

Looking forward, Australia's 2030 target is for a 26-28 per cent reduction on 2005 levels. On a per person basis, our target is more ambitious than the European Union, Germany, Canada, New Zealand or Japan have committed to over the same period.

The $3.5 billion Climate Solutions Package maps out how we will meet our 2030 target down to the last tonne. The latest official projections show that we are on track to meet and beat our 2030 target by 16 million tonnes. Under United Nations rules, countries including Australia are able to use emissions budgets to account for their Paris Agreement targets. For example, an emission budget approach is central to how the European Union acquits its targets.

The Government is committed to reducing emissions without imposing new costs on households, businesses or the economy. At its core, our approach is about technology not taxes. It means reducing emissions, not reducing jobs or the economy. It is an approach based on rigour, optimism and Australian ingenuity, not ideology.
The Government has a clear focus - back new and emerging technologies that will:
Continue supplying the affordable and reliable energy households and industry need to support jobs and the economy;
Increase the productivity of export sectors like agriculture, energy, metals and minerals processing;
Allow Australia to capitalise on opportunities to develop new industries and jobs; and
Position Australia to suppo1t our trading partners' plans to reduce emissions through the export of low emissions technologies, energy and other products.

We see enormous potential in technologies like hydrogen, carbon capture and storage, soil carbon sequestration and biofuels to reduce emissions in Australia and globally - all while strengthening our economy.

The Government has already invested $10.4 billion into more than 670 clean energy projects with a total value of $35 billion. These projects include the largest pumped hydro scheme in the southern hemisphere, Snowy 2.0, hydrogen demonstration projects and biofuels. Our investments are supporting new jobs, reducing power prices and improving the reliability of our electricity grid while lowering emissions.

Australia is a world leader in renewable energy. Around a quarter of our electricity is sourced from renewables and this is projected to increase to more than 40 per cent in the National Electricity Market by 2025. According to Bloomberg, Australia invested $7.7 billion or $308 per person in new renewable energy projects in 2019. This places us ahead of countries like the United States, Japan and the United Kingdom on a per person basis and more than ten times the global average.

Almost one in four Australian households now have solar panels on their roof- the highest rate of uptake of household solar in the world. The Government is working to progress measures to support vulnerable consumers by improving access to energy efficiency upgrades and distributed energy resources.
Further, in May 2020, the Government released a Technology Investment Roadmap discussion paper here: https://consult.industry.gov.au/climate-change/technology-investment-roadmap/.

Consultation on the Roadmap will inform the development of the first annual Low Emissions Technology Statement, which will identify technology priorities and ensure the Government's investment portfolio can be refined and updated over time.
All of this is focused on meeting and beating our commitments while maintaining a strong economy.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, Mr Taylor (Petition No. EN1201)
Telecommunications
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 8 April 2020 concerning Petition number EN1210, which relates to granting Sky News permission to broadcast on the free-to-air terrestrial television network.
The Morrison Government recognises that Australians have a wide range of views about the programs and channels they like to watch on television.

The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (the Act) provides the regulatory framework for Australia's broadcasting industry. Among other things, the Act aims to encourage diversity in the control of the more influential forms of media, and to promote the availability of a diverse range of television and radio services throughout Australia. Under the Act, the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) is responsible for planning and regulating the number and characteristics of television and radio services that can be made available in licence areas. Section 37A of the Act stipulates that the number of commercial free-to-air television licences in any licence area must not exceed three.
In conducting its planning activities, ACMA is required to promote the objects of the Act, including the economic and efficient use of the radiofrequency spectrum.
In this context, there is generally limited broadcasting spectrum available for the provision of terrestrial broadcasting services, including television services.

While the Act only allows for three commercial television licences in each licence area, it does not prevent licence holders broadcasting numerous digital multichannels, provided they do so within their allotted spectrum. I understand that Sky News has a commercial agreement with regional broadcaster WIN Television to provide the 'Sky News on WIN' channel on WIN's regional free-to-air network.
The broadcast of Sky News by a metropolitan free-to-air broadcaster is a commercial decision for the broadcasters concerned and the Government does not seek to intervene in such matters.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN1210)
Taxation
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 8 April 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1214 - tax exemptions for firefighters. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

The Australian Government is, and will remain, extremely grateful to our volunteer firefighters for the bravery and dedication they demonstrated over the summer. However, there are simpler and more direct ways of assisting volunteer firefighters, than through the introduction of a temporary income tax exemption.

While the petitioner is correct to state that the Government provides a foreign services tax exemption, the suggestion that an analogous arrangement could be put in place for volunteer fire services is not practical or effective. Importantly, a tax exemption would only assist those volunteers that have a tax liability. That is, volunteer fire fighters that do not have sufficient income to incur a tax liability will not benefit from a tax exemption.

There are better, more direct ways to ensure we offer support to volunteer firefighters. This includes the Government's direct payment to volunteers of up to $6,000. Further information is available at: www .bushfirerecovery.gov.au
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar (Petition No. EN1214)

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications

p.span: Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 8 April 2020, in relation to Petition EN1215, concerning the inclusion of Arts in the title of the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications. I apologise for the delay in this response.

As part of the Government's reform agenda to put Australians at the centre of Government, the Prime Minister consolidated the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Cities and Regional Development, and the Department of Communications and the Arts, to create the new Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications.

The structure aim to drive greater collaboration on important policy challenges to deliver better services for the Australian people. These changes increase opportunities for synergies, and for the thinking of people in the arts area of the Department to influence the thinking of people working on regional development and infrastructure, and vice versa.

Some members of our community are concerned about what the name of the new Department means for the arts. There is no change to the Government's strong commitment to the arts. The dedicated and committed officials working on arts policy have moved across to the new Department to form the Office for the Arts.
They continue to have the same responsibilities and the same resources.
I remain the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, with no change to my Ministerial title or responsibilities representing the arts in Cabinet.

The Australian Government invested approximately $776 million in the arts and cultural sector in 2019-20, including significant funding of $212 million for the Australia Council to support Australian artists and arts organisations.

On 25 June 2020, the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP and I announced a $250 million COVID-19 Creative Economy Support Package to address urgent needs within the arts and screen sectors. This includes a range of measures, including: $75 million to support new productions, festivals and events through the Restart Investment to Sustain and Expand Fund; $90 million for concessional loans to assist arts and entertainment businesses to fund new productions and events; and $3 5 million to support significant arts and culture organisations facing sustainability disruption due to COVID-19.
The Government's commitment to the arts is evidenced through our record support to the cultural and creative sector.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1215 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN1215)
Arts
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 8 April 2020, in relation to Petition EN1218, concerning the inclusion of Arts in the title of the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications. I apologise for the delay in this response.

As part of the Government's reform agenda to put Australians at the centre of Government, the Prime Minister consolidated the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Cities and Regional Development, and the Department of Communications and the Arts, to create the new Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications.

The structure aims to drive greater collaboration on important policy challenges to deliver better services for the Australian people. These changes increase opportunities for synergies, and for the thinking of people in the arts area of the Department to influence the thinking of people working on regional development and infrastructure, and vice versa.

Some members of our community are concerned about what the name of the new Department means for the arts. There is no change to the Government's strong commitment to the arts. The dedicated and committed officials working on arts policy have moved across to the new Department to form the Office for the Arts.
They continue to have the same responsibilities and the same resources.
I remain the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, with no change to my Ministerial title or responsibilities representing the arts in Cabinet.

The Australian Government invested approximately $776 million in the arts and cultural sector in 2019-20, including significant funding of $212 million for the Australia Council to support Australian artists and arts organisations.

On 25 June 2020, the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP and I announced a $250 million COVID-19 Creative Economy Support Package to address urgent needs within the arts and screen sectors. This includes a range of measures, including: $75 million to support new productions, festivals and events through the Restart Investment to Sustain and Expand Fund; $90 million for concessional loans to assist arts and entertainment businesses to fund new productions and events; and $35 million to support significant arts and culture organisations facing sustainability disruption due to COVID-19.
The Government's commitment to the arts is evidenced through our record support to the cultural and creative sector.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN1218 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN1218)
Defence Facilities
Dear Chair
I write in response to petition EN1223 referred to Senator the Hon Linda Reynolds CSC on 8 April 2020 regarding the planned sale of Defence's Leeuwin Barracks, Western Australia.

Leeuwin Barracks has been assessed as surplus to Commonwealth requirements in accordance with the Commonwealth Property Management Framework, which requires that property should only be held by the Commonwealth where it demonstrates retention contributes to government service delivery outcomes, and continued ownership represents value for money.

Defence divests surplus property in accordance with the Commonwealth Property Disposal Policy (CPDP), which is administered by the Department of Finance. The CPDP requires surplus property is sold on the open market at full market value. A core principle underpinning the CPDP is to ensure all non-government entities are provided equitable opportunity to acquire surplus Commonwealth property. The CPDP provides for off-market sales direct to state or local government where it can be demonstrated that this will achieve broader Australian Government policy outcomes.

Defence is committed to identifying and protecting the heritage values of Leeuwin Barracks and has been working with the Town of East Fremantle (Town) and the Western Australian Heritage Council to ensure the heritage values will be protected after the site leaves Commonwealth ownership. Defence has also committed to providing added protection for the Junior Recruit Memorial and will ensure the future purchaser is required to retain the memorial as part of the development of the site.

Defence and the Town in consultation with the West Australian Government will undertake a Metropolitan Region Scheme amendment to ensure the site is appropriately rezoned prior to sale. Defence and the Town will consult with the local community and key stakeholders to inform the planning amendment process, to build on the great work that was achieved with the community as part of the Leeuwin Vision Plan. This process will provide opportunity for all interested parties to contribute to the future planning outcomes of the site. If you wish to receive updates about this process you can register your interest at property.disposals@defence.gov.au or visit Defence's property disposals website at https://www.defence.gov.au/id/propertydisposals/Leeuwin.asp.

Defence values and is committed to supporting its veterans and recognises the importance of veterans' organisations and the support they provide to former and current serving members and their families. The Department of Veterans' Affairs administers the Government's policy initiatives to provide support and assistance to veterans and veterans organisations. In March 2020, the Australian Government granted $5 million to the RSL Western Australia to construct a Veterans Wellbeing Centre which is anticipated to be open in Perth near the end this year. Additionally a Veterans' Hub accommodating approximately 50 veterans and family members is partly operational within the Perth metropolitan area.
Thank you for your interest in this matter and I trust this information addresses your issues raised.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence Industry, Ms Price (Petition No. EN1223)
Water
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 8 April 2020 concerning the petition on the supply of water from the Wonthaggi Desalination Plant in Victoria (EN1225).

The Wonthaggi Desalination Plant is privately operated by AquaSure, and is contracted by the Victorian Government to provide up to 150 gigalitres (GL) GL per year. The Victorian Government places orders with AquaSure for desalinated water as required. Water produced supplements Melbourne's water supply system, as well as underpinning water security for Geelong, Ballarat and other regional areas such as South Gippsland. The water is used for both urban and agricultural purposes.
The Commonwealth government has no role in the plant's operation.

In 2019 the Victorian Government ordered 125 GL of water for FY 2019-20, this represents over 83% of the desalination plant's full operating capacity (150 GL). In March 2020, the Victorian Government ordered another 125 GL of water for FY 2020-21.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Resources, Water and Northern Australia, Mr Pitt (Petition No. EN1225)
Online Gambling
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 9 April 2020, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning Petition EN1242 - Remove the Interactive Gambling Amendment Act 2017.

The Interactive Gambling Act 2001 (IGA) was introduced in response to concerns that new digital technologies can greatly exacerbate the negative social impact of excessive gambling. Australians are losing almost $24 billion per year to all forms of gambling, both land-based and online. Problem gambling is already a significant social issue in the community which affects individuals, their families and communities. It also affects the Commonwealth in terms of welfare and other support functions.

The IGA prohibits the provision or advertising of certain interactive gambling services played for money or anything else of value, which includes overseas-based online gambling services such as online casinos. This is due to the high-risk nature of these gambling services, which can lead to problem gambling. The IGA also prohibits the advertising of these illegal services and this applies to all platforms including broadcasting, print and online.
In 2017, the Government introduced the Interactive Gambling Amendment Act 2017 to strengthen the enforcement of the IGA, measures including:

1. Clarifying the law to make it clear that it is illegal for overseas gambling companies to offer gambling products to Australians unless the person or company holds a licence under the law of an Australian State or Territory; Empowering the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) with new civil penalties, complementing the existing criminal penalties powers held by the Australian Federal Police, and allow the ACMA to be responsible for the entire complaint handling process from receipt to enforcement; and

3. Introducing other disruption measures to curb illegal offshore gambling activity, such as placing company directors or principals of offending gambling companies on the Movement Alert List so any travel to Australia can be disrupted.
These measures resulted in a large number of illegal gambling operators ceasing to provide gambling services to persons in Australia.
Despite ACMA's success in reducing offshore gambling, there remain practical and legal challenges with enforcing laws with entities with no Australian presence.

On 11 November 2019, the Government announced that ACMA will use its powers to direct Australian Internet Service Providers (ISPs) to block illegal offshore gambling websites. ACMA will investigate suspect websites and where other enforcement actions prove unfeasible, refer those in breach of the IGA to ISPs to be blocked under Section 313 (3) of the Telecommunications Act 1997 which enables Commonwealth enforcement entities to block websites containing illicit or contravening material.
These website-blocking measures will apply to sites found to be in breach of the IGA, but which continue to offer services to Australian consumers in spite of enforcement actions by ACMA.

As at 22 June 2020, 54 websites have been blocked under this scheme with further sites the subject of ACMA investigation. A list of the blocked websites can be found on ACMA's website at www.acma.gov.au/blocked-gambling-websites

To complement these enforcement actions, ACMA commenced an awareness campaign starting on 20 May 2020 to alert Australians on the risks of betting with illegal offshore gambling websites. This campaign is being conducted across social media and digital platforms
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Position No. EN1242)
Water
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 9 April 2020 on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions regarding Petition Number EN1243. The petition submitted to the House of Representatives on 8 April 2020 requested "the House of Representatives adhere to the Australian Constitution and act to achieve Freedom of water." I apologise for the delay in responding.

As you are aware, Australia has a federalist system whereby the Australian Constitution establishes and restricts Commonwealth legislative powers. The Commonwealth Parliament does not have an express power to legislate in respect of water management and use in Australia. The only reference to water in the Constitution is Section 100 and this restricts the ability for the Commonwealth to make legislation in regard to water management.

The Commonwealth has been able to legislate in respect of water resources by relying on a number of Constitutional powers, including the external affairs, corporations and the interstate trade and commerce powers. However, as the Commonwealth does not have an express power in the Australian Constitution for water management, the legislative power for management of water in Australia primarily rests with the States.

While the Australian Government is not directly responsible for the day-to-day management and supply of water, it provides national leadership, coordination and support to make sure Australian water resources are sustainably and efficiently managed. State and Territory governments are able to put in place statutory mechanisms and processes that manage the amount of water that can be captured and used based on water sharing or water allocation plans.

The management of the Murray-Darling Basin's water resources is an example of cooperative arrangements between the Commonwealth and States. The Water Act 2007 enables the Commonwealth, in conjunction with the Basin states and territory to manage water resources within the Basin in the national interest. The Basin states and territory remain responsible for managing and regulating water in the Basin through their own policies and legislation, in a manner consistent with the Water Act 2007, Murray-Darling Basin Agreement and the Murray-Darling Basin Plan. The Basin states and territory continue to exercise responsibility for decisions around water harvesting and water allocations.

The Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council is the joint government policy decision-making body for water management in the Basin. The Ministerial Council comprises water ministers from the Basin States and I am the chair in my capacity as the Commonwealth water minister.

Within this context, the Basin Plan provides an integrated and strategic framework for water reform consistent with the requirements of the Water Act 2007. The Basin Plan sets a limit on the amount of water that can be taken from the Basin's water resources as a whole, and from particular water resource plan areas, each year, while leaving enough for the environment.
In addition, the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement is provided at Schedule 1 of the Water Act 2007. The purpose of the Agreement is to promote and co-ordinate effective planning and
management for the equitable, efficient and sustainable use of the water and other natural resources of the Basin.
Thank you for writing on this matter. Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Resources, Water and Northern Australia, Mr Pitt (Petition No. EN1243)
Cybersafety
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 9 April 2020, on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions concerning Petition EN1249. The petitioner requested that the House of Representatives work with experts on consumer rights and digital security to formulate regulations, standards and practices relating to the Internet of Things (IoT).

The IoT refers to an ecosystem in which applications and services are driven by data collected from devices that sense and interface with the physical world. In the IoT, devices and objects have communication connectivity, either a direct connection to the internet or mediated through local or wide area networks. These devices are enhancing the way Australians work and live, as well as supporting innovation and economic growth through solutions for healthcare, agriculture, environment and resource management, transportation, and energy industries.

As with other internet-connected devices, the Morrison Government understands the potential risks posed by IoT devices and the importance of protecting Australian consumers. The Government continues to work in partnership with industry to safeguard consumer rights and improve the security of IoT devices through a number of initiatives. These include development of a voluntary Code of Practice, consumer advice, standards development, existing consumer law protections, and industry-led guidelines. The opportunities, risks and consequences presented by the IoT are also being considered in further research, which will inform the Australian Government of ways to continue to foster their development and responsible deployment.

The Australian Government expects that internet-connected devices, including the IoT, are secure by design to keep Australians safe from cyber threats. The Government is developing a 2020 Cyber Security Strategy, building on the 2016 Cyber Security Strategy to address emergent risks to cybersecurity and strengthen overall cybersecurity measures.

Existing legislative obligations relating to cybersecurity apply in the telecommunications industry; however, these do not extend to other industries. Consequently, the Strategy will seek the introduction of an overarching duty for industry to take reasonable steps to safeguard the cybersecurity of infrastructure, systems and products. The Strategy, when finalised, will be the product of extensive consultation across Government, industry and academia. An Industry Advisory Panel chaired by Mr Andy Penn, CEO of Telstra, has been appointed by the Minister for Home Affairs to guide development of the Strategy. The Panel is meeting regularly to consider the outcomes of the public consultation.

span.span: Code of Practice: Securing the Internet of Things for Consumers

p.span: To complement the Strategy, the Government has committed to develop a voluntary Code of Practice: Securing the Internet of Things for Consumers (the Code of Practice) to improve the security of the IoT for Australian consumers. The draft voluntary Code of Practice was released for public consultation in November 2019. Feedback received throughout the consultation process is currently being considered by the Government. Consisting of 13 voluntary principles, the Code of Practice is targeted to an industry audience and seeks to inform them about the cybersecurity features expected of IoT devices available in Australia. The Code of Practice is a first step in encouraging manufacturers to better protect Australian consumers, and signals to the market that the Australian Government expects that IoT devices should be 'secure by design'.

The Code of Practice sets out principles for industry to improve cybersecurity, including strong password protection and mechanisms to identify and resolve security vulnerabilities. Additionally, the Code of Practice recommends clear communication to consumers about secure software updates for their devices, including provision of 'end of life' policies that specify the minimum timeframe products will receive such updates. The draft Code of Practice is available at www.homeaffairs.gov.au/reports-and-pubs/files/code-of-practice.pdf.

The Government also publishes information to educate consumers about the importance of securing their own IoT devices. For example, the Government's Stay Smart Online website contains information to reduce cybersecurity risks, such as advising consumers to change default passwords on devices, update software and firmware, and exercise caution around third parties or resellers. More information is available at www.staysmartonline.gov.au. The Australian eSafety Commissioner has published a gift guide to advise Australian consumers about choosing technology gifts that are safe for children and young people, including smart toys, wearables and other IoT devices. The gift guide can be found at www.esafety.gov.au/parents/gift-guide.

span.span: Privacy and the Internet of Things

p.span: Australian users of IoT devices have recourse to a number of privacy protections. In particular, the Privacy Act 1988 (the Privacy Act) and the associated Australian Privacy Principles impose obligations on certain entities that collect personal information. Entities are required to manage personal information in an open and transparent way, and take reasonable steps, such as implementing robust security practices, to protect personal information from misuse, interference, loss and unauthorised access. The Privacy Act codifies the Notifiable Data Breaches scheme, requiring entities to notify affected individuals of eligible data breaches.

The draft Code of Practice builds on these existing privacy protections. It encourages manufacturers and service providers to offer consumers clear information about the collection and use of their personal information, and to provide simple ways for consumers to delete this data. Privacy is also supported by other principles related to installing and securely configuring devices.

Australian participation in the development of technology standards is important in making sure that the technologies Australians are adopting are secure. This includes seeking to embed security by design as a key principle of technological development. Australia promotes sufficient diversity, competition and transparency in global critical and emerging technology markets, characteristics which support enhanced security, while participating in the development of these standards.

Engagement in the development of standards is led by Standards Australia, an independent, not-for-profit national standards development body. Standards Australia leads Australia's participation in the development of international standards, including those related to the IoT, as the Australian member of the International Organization for Standardization and the International Electrotechnical Commission. Standards Australia also coordinates the development of Australian standards based on those formulated at the international level, bringing together key parties and stakeholders to form technical committees that develop or update new or existing standards.

Consumers are also granted a number of rights and protections under the Australian Consumer Law (ACL). While the drafting of the ACL pre-dates the rise of IoT, even without legislative amendment some of these rights may extend to IoT consumer products. To confirm the ACL remains fit for purpose and technology neutral, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) continues to examine whether emerging technology, such as Artificial Intelligence, machine learning or other algorithm technology, may be captured by existing legal definitions under the ACL.

In 2019, raising awareness and building capacity to address consumer product safety hazards with interconnected devices, including IoT devices, was an ACCC Product Safety Priority. As an outcome of the priority project, the ACCC published information for consumers about interconnected devices.

This included 'buying tips' encouraging consumers to consider securing their home network and to be cautious of unauthorised third party software. Further information is at www.productsafety.gov.au/products/electronics-technology/interconnected-devices.

The Internet of Things Alliance Australia (IoTAA), the Australian peak IoT industry body, also encourages businesses to treat consumer data securely and provide clear information to consumers about the ways IoT devices collect and use their personal information. IoTAA has published guidance for industry, including a Good Data Practice guide and an Internet of Things Security Guideline, to assist industry's understanding of their privacy and security obligations and to promote security and privacy principles. IoTAA's guidance is available at www.iot.org.au/resources.

span.span: Further research on the Internet of Things

p.span: The Government continues to assess the implications of increased use of IoT devices in Australia. The Australian Council of Learned Academies (ACOLA), with funding from the Government, is developing a report in its Horizon Scanning series that examines the impact that the IoT is likely to have over the coming decade, and identifies and assesses opportunities presented by the deployment of the Io T in Australia. The report is expected to be released in 2020 and is intended to provide evidence-based findings on the IoT technology, its benefits and risks, and practical measures that the Australian Government, the IoT industry, business and consumers can take to maximise the opportunities the IoT offers.
Thank you for bringing the concerns in Petition EN1249 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Position No. EN1242)
Water
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 8 April 2020 concerning the petition into a Royal Commission into the licensing and trading of water and the operation of the Murray-Darling Basin Authority (EN1257).

The Australian Government does not support calls to establish a federal Royal Commission as this would divert valuable resources from the important task of implementing the Murray-Darling Basin Plan. In addition, various reviews into different aspects of the Murray-Darling Basin (Basin) legislation and governance have been undertaken in recent years and several are still underway. This includes several Parliamentary inquiries into the
· Basin as well as Commonwealth and state reviews and independent assessments.

The reviews currently in progress or recently completed include: the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's inquiry into water markets in the Basin; the Senate inquiry into multi-jurisdictional management and execution of the Basin Plan; the Murray-Darling Basin Interim Inspector General's inquiry into the management of Basin water resources, the review of the water for the environment special account; and the independent review of socio­economic impacts of the Basin Plan.

The Government will consider the recommendations of these reports and work with Basin state governments to continue to improve the management of the water resources of the Basin in the interests of all Australians.
Thank you for writing on this matter. Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Resources, Water and Northern Australia, Mr Pitt (Petition No. EN1257)
Epilepsy
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence to the Minister for Employment, Skills, Small and Family Business, Senator the Hon Michaelia Cash, concerning petition EN1261 about support for people living with epilepsy and the need to raise awareness of epilepsy. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health. I regret the delay in responding.
The Australian Government is committed to addressing the impact that chronic conditions, such as epilepsy, have on the Australian community.

In the 2019-20 Budget, the Government announced funding of $20 million over four years to support the Epilepsy Smart Australia Program Pilot (Program). This new national Program, being developed and delivered by the Epilepsy Foundation, will provide an information and referral service for people living with epilepsy, and their families and carers. The Program will offer individualised support services, and will facilitate peer support engagement. In addition, it will deliver education and training to a variety of sectors, including the employment and education sectors. This will enhance the understanding of epilepsy and also will improve knowledge about how to most appropriately respond to the needs of people living with epilepsy.

The Government also provides funding of $1.46 million to support the implementation and delivery of the Epilepsy Action Response Service, a dedicated national telehealth service for people affected by epilepsy. Epilepsy Action Australia operates this service seven days a week and provides expert epilepsy information, support and guidance concerning the diagnosis and management of epilepsy. The service provides support for Australians living with epilepsy, their families and carers, and assists national efforts to improve detection, treatment, control and management of the condition.

Treatment and management support for Australians with chronic conditions, including epilepsy, is provided through ongoing universal health programs. This includes rebated services through the Medicare Benefits Schedule and subsidised medicines through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). There are 21 medications available on the PBS for the treatment of epilepsy, including clonazepam, gabapentin, lamotrigine, nitrazepam and perampanel. In 2018-19, the Government spent more than $77 million on PBS medicines for the treatment of epilepsy.

Clinical research is also crucial for identifying better ways of treating and managing the condition. Since 2000, the Government has provided more than $161.7 million in funding through National Health and Medical Research Council grants for research into epilepsy.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1261)
Education
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 9 April 2020 regarding Petition EN1266 requesting the addition of native flora, fauna and caring for injured wildlife to the curriculum.

The nationally agreed Foundation to Year 10 Australian Curriculum sets the expectations for what all Australian students should be taught, regardless of where they live or their background. The curriculum includes eight learning areas, seven general capabilities and three cross curriculum priorities.

There are multiple examples in the Australian Curriculum that discuss native flora, fauna and caring for injured wildlife. For example, Year 5 students studying Humanities and Social Science may get an opportunity to forecast probable futures relating to how native fauna populations might change if an introduced species such as the cane toad, carp, feral cats or rabbits continue to increase in population. Year 1 students may be given the opportunity to identify ways that Science is used in the care of the local environment such as animal habitats, and suggesting changes to parks and gardens to better meet the needs of native animals.

In addition, within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander histories and cultures cross-curriculum priority, students learn about the inseparable connection between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages and land/sea, Country/Place, the environment, fauna and flora. Students also have the opportunity to gain a greater knowledge through the sustainability cross-curriculum priority, including exploring the interdependent and dynamic nature of systems that support all life and Earth and our collective wellbeing. The outdoor learning curriculum connection covers topics such as human-nature relationships and conservation and sustainability including care of wildlife. You can read more about the inclusion of topics in the Australian Curriculum online at www.australiancurriculum.edu.au.

Responsibility for delivery of school education, including decisions around delivery of the Australian Curriculum, rests with the individual education authorities in each state and territory. Given this, the petitioner may wish to contact their state or territory education minister to discuss further. To assist, I have enclosed the contact details for each state and territory education minister.
Thank you for bringing these concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely,
