Banking and Financial Services
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the Treasurer, relating to Petition EN1273 concerning lending requirements. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

Lending conditions on individual products are commercial decisions for individual financial institutions. The Government is aware of recent anecdotal reports that, given the current level of public scrutiny of their past lending practices, banks have become overly cautious in how they are interpreting the application of existing legal and prudential obligations on their lending. In response, the Treasurer has stated publicly that while banks must adhere to their obligations, consideration should also be given to the need to provide access to finance for families and businesses, thus facilitating a critical part of the economy.

Recent reforms have been intended to boost competition and access to finance in the Australian banking system. For example, under the Morrison Government's Open Banking system, the holders of banking data (i.e. banks) will be obliged to securely share a customer's banking data, at the customer's direction and with parties nominated by the customer, in a form that facilitates its use. These parties might include providers of banking and financial services striving to compete for new customers.
Consumers can, of course, try a different lender. Further information, including options for shopping around, is at www.moneysmart.gov.au/borrowing-and-credit.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and Financial Technology, Senator Hume (Petition No. EN1273)
Telecommunications
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter dated 9 April 2020, concerning Petition EN1274 regarding the charging regime implemented by telecommunications service providers for pre-paid mobile phone services, specifically the ability for service providers to cancel any unused credit at the end of a customer's pre-paid plan period.

The Morrison Government's role in the telecommunications regime is to establish the legislative and regulatory framework within which service providers operate, including providers of pre-paid mobile phone services.

Pre-paid mobile phone plans are subject to the Pre-paid Calling Card Guideline which is an industry guideline that provides guidance to service providers in relation to the provision of pre-paid calling cards, including appropriate requirements for customer assistance and return-and-refund policies. Service providers are expected to follow the Guideline in their product offerings.

All terms and conditions of any goods or service contract between a service provider and consumer must also comply with the provisions of the Australian Consumer Law (ACL). The ACL is the legislation governing consumer protection and fair trading in Australia which is contained in a schedule to the Competition and Consumer Act 2010.

The ACL includes specific requirements in relation to service provision which are enforced and administered by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) and also the consumer protection agencies in each state and territory. Information about how the provisions of the ACL apply in practice to both consumers and service providers is available on the ACCC's website at www.accc.gov.au.

Telecommunications-specific consumer protections are contained in legislation, industry standards and service provider determinations. They are also contained in industry codes, including the Telecommunications Consumer Protections Code (TCP Code). The TCP Code is designed to protect consumer rights and to make clear the obligations of telephone and internet service providers. The TCP Code provides benchmarks for consumer safeguards in sales and service, contracts, billing, credit and debt management, changing suppliers and complaint handling.

Under the TCP Code, all service providers must make available to consumers a standard format 'Critical Information Summary' (CIS) that briefly and plainly outlines the key information consumers need to make informed purchasing decisions and compare different products and plans. Each CIS must provide succinct information about the service plan, including the terms, conditions, exclusions, restrictions or limitations and an explanation of all associated charges.

Consumers are strongly encouraged to review the CIS for any mobile service plan they may be considering prior to purchase, as it provides information such as call, SMS and data inclusions, termination fees and the length of any contract. Further information about pre-paid and post-paid phone cards for use with mobile and fixed line phones is available on the website of the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) at www.acma.gov.au/telecommunications-consumer-protection-code.
The existing framework does not prevent a service provider from cancelling any unused credit at the end of a customer's pre-paid plan period.

The Government has been undertaking a comprehensive review of the existing telecommunications consumer protections to prepare the safeguards framework for a post 2020 environment - one in which the large scale roll-out of the National Broadband Network (NBN) is complete.

Part C of the Consumer Safeguards Review focusses on whether consumers are able to make informed choices and are treated fairly by their provider in areas such as customer service, contracts, billing, credit/debt management and switching providers. The Government expects to conclude the Review by the end of 2020. Further information is available at www.communications.gov.au/consumer-safeguards-review.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concern to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN1274)
Roads
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 16 April 2020 regarding petition EN1282 requesting the installation of Wildlife Detectors on National Highways and roads where there are frequent animal/vehicle incidents around Australia.

Every level of government, and each member of the Australian public, plays a role in ensuring safety on our roads. The Australian Government is committed to reducing the number of deaths and serious injuries caused by road crashes, and we are demonstrating this through providing national leadership and increased investment.

The Government is investing an additional $2.2 billion in road safety funding across Australia from 2019-20 through the Local and State Government Road Safety Package. This includes $550 million for the Black Spot Program, targeting road locations with a history of at least three casualty crashes in five years. The Program aims to reduce the risk of crashes through funding safety measures including safety barriers and lighting at these locations.

The Government has also established the Office of Road Safety to improve national leadership and coordination efforts and work to reduce deaths and serious injuries on Australian roads. The Office has published guidelines for round one of the $12 million Road Safety Innovation Fund, available on www.grants.gov.au. Funding will support road safety research and the development of new technologies and products, including in regional and remote areas where wildlife may be more prevalent.

The Australian Government is working closely with state and territory governments to deliver $100 billion over ten years in infrastructure to get Australians home sooner and safer. State and local governments are responsible for the operational aspects of road networks, including tailored measures for roads in their jurisdictions. All levels of government welcome sensible initiatives to make our roads safer and help protect Australia's iconic wildlife.
Thank you for bringing this issue to my attention and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr McCormack (Petition No. EN1282)
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email correspondence of 8 April 2020 advising a petition has been presented to the House of Representatives and requesting a response.

The petition has asked the House to greatly reduce delays for disabled people to access their funds to purchase Specialised or Complex Assistive Technology (AT) that will improve their lives, and to make the National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) Technical Advisory Team more transparent. Specifically, they have commented that the Technical Advisory Team "needs to be more transparent especially in regard to why they take so very long to do their job effectively and why Disabled people cannot get a fair Estimated Time from this mysterious and invisible Team".

We acknowledge some participants have experienced delays in the assessment and delivery of AT. To address this, the NDIA is delivering an extensive program of works to reduce delays and improve participants' experience of the assessment and delivery of AT. Specific initiatives in place or being implemented include:
new assessment templates to assist participants and AT assessors in providing evidence to enable timely planning decisions
streamlined decisions on repair or replacement of AT
no requirement for quotes for low cost AT under the value of $1,500, and AT assessment/advice only required for higher risk items
requiring only one quote for most AT under the value of $15,000 and no more than two quotes for AT over the value of $15,000
introduction of processes and practices to improve access to mid-range AT supports valued between $1,500 and $5000
implementing transition arrangements with state equipment providers to ensure our AT processes are nationally consistent and easy to follow.

The NDIA internal Technical Advisory Branch (TAB) provides a Technical and Clinical Advisory internal support service to assist NDIA delegates, planners and partners on complex issues requiring Subject Matter Expertise (SME) in Specialist areas such as:
complex assistive technology
complex home modifications
behavioural modification programs
complex health conditions
psychosocial disability
physical therapies
neurological rehabilitation
prosthetics and orthotics
justice/health and other mainstream interfaces.
The NDIA is unable to provide further detail about individual participants without consent or information from the petition signees as to where there may be issues in accessing AT supports.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Mr Robert (Petition No. EN1284)
Autism
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for the Committee's correspondence of 9 April 2020 regarding petition EN1285. The petition requests that the government recommend to the Australian Human Rights Commission or to the relevant Parliamentary Committee that they launch an inquiry into the community treatment and understanding of those on the Autistic Spectrum. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government believes all people are entitled to respect, dignity and the opportunity to participate in society regardless of their personal attributes, and recognises that to enjoy civil and political rights on an equal basis with others, people need to be able to do so free from discrimination.

I note your concerns about the misunderstanding and negative treatment that those on the Autistic spectrum can experience in community settings. The Commonwealth anti‑discrimination laws, including the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, make discrimination and harassment on a number of protected grounds, including disability, unlawful in ·a wide range of areas of public life.

On 27 November 2019, the Senate resolved to establish a Select Committee on Autism to inquire into and report on the services, support and life outcomes for autistic people in Australia and the associated need for a National Autism Strategy. The inquiry is intended to go beyond diagnostic services and the National Disability Insurance Scheme to also ensure access to a range of inclusive services such as health, education, housing, justice, rights and employment.

The terms of reference of the inquiry includes particular attention to international best practice with regards to diagnosing, support services and education, effectiveness, cost and required intensity. There is also reference to the social inclusion and participation of autistic people within the economy and community.

The Select Committee on Autism are calling for individuals with autism to participate in the inquiry. Submissions to are currently open and due to close on 17 July 2020. The committee is to present its final report on or before the first sitting day of October 2021.
More information regarding the inquiry and the submission process can be found at the following link:
https://www.aph.gov .au/Parliamentary Business/Committees/Senate/Autism/autism
Thank you again for bringing this petition and the concerns raised to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter (Petition No. EN1285)
Work-Life Balance
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 9 April 2020 regarding Petition EN1290 - Reduce the working week to 3 or 4 days to address unemployment and income inequality. I have considered this matter in conjunction with the Australian Government's ongoing response to the Coronavirus pandemic (COVID-19). Given that the Government's response to COVID-19 is evolving, regrettably it took longer than anticipated to receive advice from my department.

Under the Fair Work Act 2009 (FW Act), maximum weekly hours form part of the National Employment Standards (NES). The NES state that an employer must not request or require a full-time employee to work more than 38 hours of work in a week, unless the additional hours are reasonable. While a 3 8 hour workweek is the maximum allowable under the NES, employers and employees can agree to a shorter working week under an enterprise agreement.

Additionally, Australian businesses and workers may use a range of alternatives to full-time employment which are necessary, legitimate and important forms of work. This may include part-time and casual employees and contracting arrangements.

The Australian Government supports those in the Australian community in need of income assistance through various income support payments, including payments to support those who are looking for work, or are temporarily unable to work. The JobSeeker Payment provides financial help for those aged 22 years to Age Pension age who have the capacity to work now or in the future, while the Youth Allowance payment for job seekers provides financial help for those aged 21 or younger.

The Australian Government is taking unprecedented action to meet the challenges posed by COVID-19, and cushion the blow on those most vulnerable to the impacts of this crisis. This includes those negatively impacted by loss of income and unemployment.

The Government's JobKeeper wage subsidy scheme is helping to keep more Australians in jobs and maintain vital connections between employers and employees during this unprecedented crisis. It also seeks to support business recovery, ensuring that such operations can return to normal as quickly as possible on the other side.

In addition, the Government is temporarily expanding eligibility for income support payments, making them easier to claim. This can include casuals who have not been with their employer for at least the previous 12 months and are therefore not entitled to the JobKeeper Payment. Expanded eligibility will also assist people caring for someone infected or in isolation as a result of contact with COVID-19.

The Government is also establishing a new, temporary Coronavirus Supplement to be paid at a rate of $550 per fortnight. This is part of unprecedented action to strengthen the safety net available to Australians, including full-time, part-time and casual workers. The Coronavirus Supplement is being paid to both existing and new recipients of income support, including those receiving the JobSeeker Payment and Youth Allowance, and will apply for six months.
Thank you for raising this matter with me. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from theMinister for Industrial Relations, Mr Porter (Petition No. EN1290)
COVID-19
Dear Chairman
Thank you for your email dated 10 April 2020 concerning Petition EN1293, which relates to the publication of material concerning the COVID-19 pandemic in the Daily Telegraph and the Herald Sun.

The priority for the Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments is the health and wellbeing of Australians, their livelihoods, their jobs and ensuring that Australia is positioned to emerge strong and resilient.

The Morrison Government recognises the importance of Australians having accurate information about the COVID-19 pandemic. Reliable information on how Australians can protect themselves and their families from corona virus is available at www.australia.gov.au.

The Government also believes that a balanced, robust and independent media sector plays an important role in a healthy democracy and is committed to having policy settings in place which encourage an Australian media sector that offers competitive and diverse services.

Print and online news publications in Australia, such as newspapers, predominately operate under self-regulatory arrangements that recognise the importance of a print media sector in which media standards reflect community expectations.

The Australian Press Council (APC) is the self-regulatory body with responsibility for promoting standards relating to media practice, and is the principal body with responsibility for handling complaints about most major Australian newspapers, magazines and associated digital outlets, as well as some independent online-only news services.
All publications subject to the APC's remit, including News Corp Australia publications, are required to comply with the APC's Standards of Practice including the Statement of General Principles.

The Statement of General Principles requires publications to, among other things, avoid causing or contributing materially to substantial offence, distress or prejudice, or a substantial risk to health or safety, unless doing so is sufficiently in the public interest. The full Statement of General Principles is available at www.presscouncil.org.au/statements-of-principles.

Members of the public may lodge a complaint with the APC about material published by organisations subject to the APC's remit. Further information about the regulation of print media and the APC complaints process is available from the APC website at www.presscouncil.org.au.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN1293)
Services Australia
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I write in response to your letter dated 9 April 2020, concerning petition EN1302 presented to the House of Representatives, regarding the closure of Sickness Allowance to new claimants from 20 March 2020, and its cessation on 20 September 2020.

The petitioners raise a concern that Australians who are sick, injured or disabled will not receive adequate income support on JobSeeker Payment to assist their time in recovery. The petitioners ask that the House of Representatives Allowance, and it be reinstated as part of the income support system.

As you are aware, the Social Services Legislation Amendment (Welfare Reform) Act 2018was passed in March 2018, as part of the modernisation of the social security system. The legislation was granted Royal Assent in April 2018 with the relevant provisions commencing on 20 March 2020. Australians in work or study who have a temporary incapacity now receive support through JobSeeker Payment.

Job Seeker Payment is the main income support payment for unemployed people of workforce age who have capacity to work now or in the future. Its introduction has simplified the income support system and provided or maintained incentives for people to find employment and support themselves to the greatest extent possible.

Creating a single payment for working-age people, with a single set of rules and a single set of payment rates has made it simpler and easier for people to access payments that support their needs and circumstances. As part of the reform, eligibility for JobSeeker Payment was broadened to include access for people who have temporarily stopped working or studying to recover from an illness or injury, or who are bereaved.

Payment rates and conditions that existed under Sickness Allowance have been maintained under JobSeeker Payment to ensure there is no loss for these people who would have been eligible for Sickness Allowance. This provision has enabled Australia to better handle the current COVID-19 crisis as people who need to self-isolate are still able to claim and receive for Sickness Allowance.

JobSeeker Payment better accommodates individual circumstances, meaning current recipients will not need to claim a new payment if they enter a period of illness or injury, and those who finish a period of illness or injury and still require assistance do not need to claim another payment, as was the case with Sickness Allowance. This allows for an easier and simpler transition between the two payments and removes significant red tape and frustration for recipients.

Social security law provides for a temporary incapacity exemption from mutual obligation requirements for JobSeeker Payment recipients who are assessed as being unable to work for 8 hours or more per week due to a medical condition, if supported by medical evidence. The assessment also considers whether a person is able to undertake another appropriate activity, other than their usual work for 8 hours or more a week. Exemptions are generally granted for the length of a person's medical certificate, up to a period of 13 weeks at a time. If the person is still incapacitated after an initial period of 13 weeks they must lodge another medical certificate. This is the same as what existed under Sickness Allowance.

Where a person is unable to meet mutual obligation requirements for extended periods due to a serious illness, such as cancer, they may be granted an exemption for an initial period of up to 12 months. Where the same serious illness persists, an additional period of exemption of up to six months can be considered based on further medical evidence.

People who were receiving Sickness Allowance before 20 March 2020 will continue to receive the payment for the length of their medical certificate, as long as they remain eligible. The cessation of Sickness Allowance will occur on 20 September 2020, by which time existing medical certificates, which were due to expire beyond 20 March 2020, would have expired and recipients either transferred to JobSeeker Payment, another appropriate payment or the recipient may exit the income support system altogether.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston (Petition No. EN1302)
Indigenous Health
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I refer to your letter to the Hon Ken Wyatt AM MP, Minister for Indigenous Australians, concerning a Petition (EN1307) to the House of Representatives on the high rate of Indigenous suicide within the Pilbara region of Australia, and the provision of mental health services in the region. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health. I regret the delay in responding.

I support the intent of the petition to support better mental health and suicide prevention services for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the Pilbara region. The Australian Government is committed to reducing the impact of suicide on First Nations individuals, families and communities.

However, a federal inquiry into this issue would be premature. There are a number of significant policy and community developments currently underway in the Pilbara region, as well as in the mental health and suicide prevention sector more broadly.

On·25 January 2019, the Government announced funding for Beyond Blue to fast-track the rollout of Be You. This program promotes mental health and wellbeing for children and teens by offering free education and training to early learning, primary, secondary and pre-service educators across Australia. Be You is piloting a culturally appropriate, place-based approach to implementing the program in the Pilbara and Kimberley regions. The Be You initiative is led by Beyond Blue who are partnering with Puntukurnu Aboriginal Medical Services and Kimberley Aboriginal Medical Services to deliver the Be You Kimberley/ Pilbara pilot.

On 29 March 2019, the Hon Ken Wyatt AM MP, as the then Minister for Indigenous Health, approved funding for a range of initiatives in Western Australia. With this support, Karratha Central Healthcare is delivering complimentary social, emotional and mental health support through a collaborative partnership with existing agencies in the West Pilbara region; Mentally Healthy WA is implementing projects in the Pilbara and Roebourne regions that aim to support resilience and build the capacity of Indigenous communities to prevent and respond to mental health issues.

In April 2018, headspace launched an innovative trial in the Pilbara. The trial delivers a new, flexible model of headspace service delivery for Pilbara young people. Instead of young people visiting a headspace centre, the Pilbara trial brings headspace services to young people through outreach and community engagement. On 30 January 2020, the Government announced a four-year extension of the trial to continue providing services suited to the unique geographic and social nature of the Pilbara region.

In addition, the Government is supporting the implementation and evaluation of twelve suicide prevention trial sites in identified priority areas. These trials are being implemented by Primary Health Networks (PHN) in partnership with communities, and are bringing together the best evidence-based strategies and models to better target people at risk of suicide. The National Suicide Prevention Trial will improve our understanding of what strategies are most effective in preventing suicide at a local level and for at-risk populations including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. Findings from the trial will be made available to all PHNs to guide future suicide prevention activities, and will inform Government policy development.

The Government is also investing in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander leadership. Established in late March 2020, Gayaa Dhuwi (Proud Spirit) Australia will be a national inclusive representative voice, leader and advocate for system-wide changes to approaches to Indigenous suicide prevention, social and emotional wellbeing and mental health. The Government has provided $4.5 million to support the establishment of Gayaa Dhuwi (Proud Spirit) Australia. The organisation will lead the co-design and implementation of a strengths-based Indigenous suicide prevention strategy and implementation plan. This will provide a framework to significantly and sustainably reduce Indigenous suicide rates and improve mental health outcomes.

The petitioners can be assured that the Government is committed to reducing the impact of suicide and suicidal behaviours in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. This commitment is demonstrated through directed and sustained mental health and suicide prevention activities in the Pilbara region. And it is demonstrated through policy development, which is occurring in partnership with Indigenous communities, experts and peak bodies.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1307)
Climate Change
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 9 April 2020 regarding Petition EN1315. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.
Australia has a responsibility to play our part in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, while also making sure we have affordable electricity and a strong economy.

At the 2019 election the Government took a clear plan to the Australian people to responsibly reduce Australia's carbon emissions consistent with our international commitments. We remain committed to this plan.

We beat our first Kyoto target by 128 million tonnes and we're projected to beat our 2020 target by 411 million tonnes. Under our 2030 Paris target, we're reducing emissions by 26 to 28 per cent on 2005 levels by 2030. Over this period we will have halved the amount of emissions per Australian.
On a per capita basis, our emission reductions will be greater than many comparable countries, including the European Union, Canada, Japan and Korea.

We have set ourselves an ambitious, but responsible, emissions reduction target for 2030. We will meet it and we intend to beat it, and the latest emissions projections already show we are on track to do so.

But Australia cannot cut global emissions in isolation. The development and deployment of new technologies will be essential to reducing emissions, both here and around the world, while creating jobs.

Our focus is on improving existing and adopting new technologies, not taxes. We do not support the introduction of a carbon tax, we do not support driving up electricity prices and we do not support plans that will abandon the jobs many regional Australians rely on and make emissions reduction unsustainable.

That's why we have released a Technology Investment Roadmap, which is available here: https://consult. industry.gov.au/climate-change/technology-investment-roadmap/. It will guide us as we seek to deploy new technology as rapidly as possible to reduce emissions, both at home and overseas.

The Roadmap will position Australia to contribute to, and take advantage of, global decarbonisation efforts. It will set a framework for our investment in emission reducing technologies over the short (to 2022), medium (to 2030) and long-term (to 2050).
This builds on what we're already doing to drive down emissions, including:
The $10 billion Clean Energy Finance Corporation, which brings down the cost of renewable energy;
Our $1 billion Grid Reliability Fund to promote investment in battery and pumped hydro renewable energy storage;
Our $500 million hydrogen strategy to position us as a key player in the emerging green hydrogen economy and;
Our soon-to-be-released electric vehicle strategy to accelerate the modernisation of our transport fleet.

Although seemingly representing climate action, the Bill proposed by the Member for Warringah would only result in more bureaucracy, duplicate our existing processes and sign the country up to major commitments without appropriately considering the costs and impacts.

Our national emissions reduction target is achievable, responsible and sustainable. We are playing our part in coordinated global action to deliver a healthy environment for future generations while keeping our economy strong.

More details on how the Government is tackling climate change can be found on the Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources website: https://www.energy.gov.au/A-fair-deal-on-energy/a-fair-deal-3
Thank you again for bringing your concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Energy and Emissions Reduction, Mr Taylor (Petition No. EN1315)
Reserve Bank of Australia
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning EN1326 to replace the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Board. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

Lower interest rates are a global phenomenon and the decline in interest rates has been seen in all major economies. Indeed in many developed economies interest rates are significantly lower than in Australia. The Australian Government and Reserve Bank of Australia do not have the capacity to control global interest rates, which have a significant influence on interest rates in Australia, especially longer term interest rates. But the Government and the Reserve Bank must respond to these developments which reflect powerful economic forces in the global economy.

The RBA is an independent institution with a mandate for controlling inflation and supporting growth and full employment. The Bank sets the cash rate in order to influence other interest rates in the economy. However, as discussed above, the Bank has only a limited capacity to influence domestic borrowing and lending rates as a range of other domestic and international factors also influence interest rates. In deciding on the appropriate level for the cash rate the Bank must balance a range of considerations, including the circumstances of borrowers and savers. It must also respond to international developments, including the decline in international interest rates.

Low interest rates are intended to stimulate economic activity. One of the ways which this is intended to occur is through a lowering of currency exchange rates. A lower exchange rate makes foreign goods and services more expensive compared to those produced in Australia, and should lead to an increase in exports and domestic activity, all else equal. A relatively lower Australian Dollar then, is a desired outcome for monetary easing.

Another way lower interest rates are intended to support economic activity is by reducing the cost of borrowing relative to the return on new business projects, and thereby encouraging new investment. It is difficult to know the counterfactual, but without the easing of monetary policy since 2011 business investment would likely have been lower.

While interest rate settings may be helping the economy as a whole, I understand that people with cash in bank deposits will receive less interest income as a result. The RBA must balance these competing effects when making decisions on interest rate settings and does not do so lightly.

While the RBA has independence in its conduct of monetary policy, the Government supports the framework within which the RBA makes its decisions as articulated in the Statement on the Conduct of Monetary Policy.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and Financial Technology, Senator Hume (Petition No. EN1326)
Indigenous Australians
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter of 9 April 2020 to the Attorney-General, the Hon Christian Porter MP, regarding the presentation of petition EN1329 on the definition of lndigenous. The petition has been referred to me for a response as this matter falls within my portfolio responsibility.
The petition asks the House to examine the meaning of Indigenous and whether a person who has only one Aboriginal parent can be classed as Indigenous.

In the international context, 'indigenous' is used to refer to the first peoples of a particular nation or territory. However, the United Nations acknowledges that there is no universally-agreed definition of the term 'indigenous peoples'. In Australia, 'Indigenous' is a term inclusive of both Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples as both are acknowledged as being the first inhabitants of this nation.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander identity is a personal matter and can be extremely complex. The working definition used by the Australian Government is that an Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander person is someone:
of Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander descent,
who identifies as an Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander, and
who is accepted as such by the community in which they live, or have previously lived.

It does not matter whether an individual has one or two Indigenous parents or if that individual is born overseas - a person is either an Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander or he/she is not, as per the three-part definition above.

Sometimes proof of Indigeneity is required to determine eligibility for Indigenous-specific Government services. Proof can be confirmed by an Indigenous community or organisation if it is satisfied that an applicant identifies with their family history and heritage and is accepted by their local community as Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander.
The Government does not propose to interfere with that process or to introduce any additional or new tests.
Thank you for referring this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Mr Wyatt (Petition No. EN1329)
Nuclear Waste
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 April 2020 concerning petition EN1330 requesting the House to rescind the decision to site the National Radioactive Waste Management Facility (Facility) near Kimba, South Australia.
The Australian Government did not hold a pre-determined view that the Facility would be located in South Australia. This is a facility of national significance, the siting of which came after:
analysis of forty-two discrete potential Commonwealth-owned sites which did not reveal any suitable sites after examining technical, economic, social and environmental criteria;
a nation-wide voluntary nomination process, including preliminary community ballots in 2017 indicating majority support for further discussion on the facility; and
a consultation phase involving significant community participation in consultative committees, economic working groups, site characterisation activities and community events.

I introduced the National Radioactive Waste Management Amendment (Site Specification, Community Fund and Other Measures) Bill 2020 (NRWM Bill) into the Parliament on 13 February 2020 and it passed the House of Representative on 11 June 2020. The NRWM Bill provides an opportunity for the Australian Parliament to have a say on the siting of this important piece of national infrastructure. The Bill has four key aims:
establishment of a $20 million Community Fund to deliver benefits for the community and support long-term infrastructure and development priorities;
updates the site nomination and selection framework and inserts provisions which specify the site on which the facility will be located;
enables additional land acquisition, beyond the 160ha site size specified in the Act, should it be necessary to support emergency road access or other regulatory requirements; and
provides the Parliament with an important opportunity to consider the delivery of the Facility at the identified site near Kimba.

The amendments shift the decision from that of a single minster to a matter for the Australian Parliament. The Bill has been referred to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee for scrutiny, and the Committee is expected to deliver its report by 31 July 2020.
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to the matters raised in this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Resources, Water and Northern Australia, Mr Pitt (Petition No. EN1330)
Air Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 9 April 2020 regarding petition EN1337 seeking to ban reclining seats on aircraft during domestic flights on economy/premium-economy seats.
The Civil Aviation Safety Authority has been consulted in the preparation of the below information.

Under the Australian Civil Aviation Safety Regulations 1998, there is a requirement that cabin interiors must be aligned with international standards. The seat pitch, being the existing distance between one seat and the same point on another seat directly in front or behind, is determined by the standards for cabin seating layout and based on occupant safety and emergency evacuation requirements.

Passenger safety is the primary consideration when setting and applying the design standards. These are defined in the applicable airworthiness design standards such as the US Federal Aviation Administration Code of Federal Regulations 14, Federal Aviation Regulations 25, or the European Aviation Safety Agency Certification Specifications 25.

Airlines are primarily responsible for ensuring the seats installed are compliant and meet the approved safety requirements. As long as the design, and placement of seats on aircraft are not in contradiction to aviation safety standards, it is the airlines' prerogative whether seating is able to recline during the cruise phase of flight.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to my attention and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr McCormack (Petition No. EN1337)
Superannuation
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN1338 to make it compulsory to obtain written authorisation from superannuation members prior to investing in fossil fuel industries.

Superannuation must be invested with the sole purpose of providing income in retirement, and superannuation fund trustees have a fiduciary duty to make investments in the best interests of their members. Indeed, APRA Chairman Wayne Byres has said publicly that 'any evidence of trustees potentially giving priority to anything other than members' interests and the provision of retirement incomes would be of concern."
The Government has no intention to act on the ideas outlined in the petition. I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and Financial Technology, Senator Hume (Petition No. EN1338)
Promotional Toys
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 9 April 2020 concerning petition number EN1344, regarding promotion of plastic toys with food purchases.

In Australia countless materials, including plastics, are disposed of in ways that do not benefit our environment, economy and people. To deal with the impacts of waste plastics, the Australian Government has overseen a phase out of microbeads and has worked with states and territories to issue the National Waste Policy Action Plan 2019, which sets the direction for priority actions on waste management and recycling in Australia until 2030.

On 8 November 2019, Australia's environment ministers agreed this new plan of national action on waste and recycling would include ambitious national targets that make Australia a world leader in resource management and recovery, including that by 2025 or sooner, Australia will phase-out the problematic and unnecessary single-use plastics through design, innovation or the introduction of sustainable alternatives, and develop a national plastics plan to increase recycling and reduce plastic pollution. This Plan complements and supports the implementation of better waste management plans by state and territory governments, local government, business and industry. More information on the Government's plastics strategies can be found at: environment.gov.au/protection/waste-resource-recovery/plastics-and-packaging.

Another important aspect of the Government's response, product stewardship, concerns how we manage the impacts of different products and materials on the environment and on human health and safety. It recognises that the people and businesses involved in producing, selling, using and disposing of products have a shared responsibility to ensure they manage these products or materials throughout their lifecycle. The Government manages the Product Stewardship Act 2011, which sets out a framework to effectively manage the environmental, health and safety impacts of products, in particular the impact of disposing of particular products.

Some hard plastics, including plastic toys, can be recycled through most kerbside recycling bins and processed to manufacture new products including textiles, furniture and bottles. There is some great ongoing collaboration between governments, industry organisations and the community more broadly to proactively tackle this challenge. I understand that Coles is providing in-store collection points where unwanted plastic promotional toys can be returned and repurposed into shoe soles, in partnership with the product stewardship initiative Save Our Soles.

Together with environmental groups and businesses in the packaging supply chain, Australia's major supermarkets have committed to collective action to meet the National Packaging Targets. Coles and Woolworths, for example, are active members of the Australian Packaging Covenant Organisation (APCO) and have both banned single-use plastic shopping bags in all their stores.

Thank you again for bringing your concerns to the Government's attention. I trust this background serves to demonstrate that plastic waste is a major priority for the Morrison Government and that the Commonwealth is undertaking a comprehensive and ambitious program to address this significant national challenge in close collaboration with industry and state and territory governments.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Waste Reduction and Environmental Management, Mr Evans (Petition No. EN1344)
COVID-19
Dear Chairman
Thank you for your email dated 9 April 2020 concerning Petition EN1346 which relates to another petition, Petition EN1293, as well as media reporting on the potential origin of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Morrison Government believes that a balanced, robust and independent media sector plays an important role in a healthy democracy and is committed to having policy settings in place which encourage an Australian media sector that offers competitive and diverse services.

Print and online news publications in Australia, such as newspapers, predominately operate under self-regulatory arrangements that recognise the importance of a print media sector in which media standards reflect community expectations.

The Australian Press Council is the self-regulatory body with responsibility for promoting standards relating to media practice, and is the principal body with responsibility for handling complaints about most major Australian newspapers, magazines and associated digital outlets, including News Corp Australia publications, as well as some independent online-only news services.

More information about these self-regulatory arrangements is available on the Australian Press Council website at presscouncil.org.au and the Independent Media Council website at independentmediacouncil.com.au.

from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN1346)
Broadband
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 9 April 2020, on behalf of the Standing Committee of Petitions concerning the request for fibre rollout of the National Broadband Network (NBN) to the Greater Mylor region.

NBN Co Limited (NBN Co) is accountable to the Government and to the Australian community for its performance and is building and operating the network on a commercial basis in line with the Government's Statement of Expectations. Technology selection and network design are operational matters for the company.

There can be difficulties in deploying fixed line broadband infrastructure to a locality like Mylor and its surrounds. Because broadband signals supplied over copper lines decrease over long distances, it is necessary to install new fibre infrastructure to a node within close range of a home or business to provide faster broadband, even if there is an existing copper connection to that premises. The more premises are spread out, more civil works are required. This means there is a much higher cost involved in deploying fixed line infrastructure to premises in peri-urban, and regional areas with low population densities, regardless of distance from the nearest metropolitan area.

The Morrison Government considers that broadband services should be upgraded in the most cost-effective way using the best matched technology for each area. Due to low population densities and distances from other NBN infrastructure, it would simply be cost-prohibitive to attempt to connect some areas of Mylor via fixed line technology.

NBN Co has informed me that Inner Mylor, including local businesses, community premises and the primary school receive their NBN connection through fibre to the node technology. NBN Co has also delivered fixed wireless technology to parts of Mylor where it has been possible. Until January 2020 NBN Co looked to provide fixed wireless technology to the 450 premises in the Greater Mylor Region. Unfortunately the potential fixed wireless sites became unavailable.

I understand NBN Co has been searching extensively to find a site to host a fixed wireless tower to provide broadband connectivity to the area. In March 2020, NBN Co agreed to conduct a detailed investigation into whether a newly identified site in the Mylor region would be feasible. This site was previously not considered based on former engineering standards. However, very recent developments in antenna technology mean it warranted further investigation.

NBN Co has advised that despite initial interest, all land owners whose land could have been used to provide services from this location have now withdrawn support for the installation of NBN Co infrastructure on their property. NBN Co has expanded the search area around Mylor to try to identify an alternative site location but for the moment satellite services remain the option for NBN services in these areas.
Thank you for bringing the Mylor constituents' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN1351)
Domestic and Family Violence
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter dated 13 May 2020 about petition EN1360, concerning domestic violence housing.

Since 2013, the Australian Government has committed more than $1 billion to address family, domestic and sexual violence. This includes the record $340 million Fourth Action Plan of the National Plan to Reduce Violence against Women and their Children 2010-2022 (the National Plan), with initiatives to improve housing and other support services for women experiencing family, domestic and sexual violence.

The Fourth Action Plan will provide $60 million for the Safe Places grant round, which is estimated to build 450 emergency accommodation dwellings across Australia that will help up to 6,500 women and children a year.

The Australian Government is also investing $18 million to continue the Keeping Women Safe in their Homes (KWSITH) initiative. The KWSITH initiative supports women and their children who have experienced violence to remain in their homes, or a home of their choice, where it is safe and appropriate to do so. As at June 2020, KWSITH has assisted over 8,500 women and children nationally since 2015.
To discover more about the Fourth Action Plan and its initiatives, I encourage you to view the website plan4womenssafety.dss.gov.au.

In March 2020, the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, announced an additional $150 million as part of the Domestic Violence Support Package in response to the coronavirus pandemic. Under a new National Partnership Agreement, this package will provide $130 million to states and territories to fund safer housing and emergency accommodation, counselling and outreach, crisis support and helplines.

The package also includes $20 million to boost key programs under the National Plan, as well as contributing towards the new national awareness campaign, Help is Here, which launched on Sunday 3 May 2020. This campaign will ensure all Australians affected by domestic violence know where to seek help when they need it.

Help is Here directs audiences to the two national helplines - 1800RESPECT and MensLine Australia - as well as state and territory services. The campaign includes advertising across television, digital, social media, radio, magazines and newspapers as well as in shopping centres, hospitals and doctors' surgeries.

Finally, on 4 June 2020, the House Standing Committee on Social Policy and Legal Affairs adopted an inquiry into family, domestic and sexual violence. The inquiry has broad Terms of Reference, including investigating the way that housing affects the ability of women to escape domestic violence. The inquiry is currently accepting written submissions addressing one or more of the terms of reference.
The deadline for submissions is Friday 24 July 2020. More information on the inquiry
is available online at
www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary Business/Committees/House/Social Policy and Legal Affairs/Familyviolence.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston (Petition No. 1360)
E-Cigarettes
Dear Mr O'Dowd
I refer to your email of 13 May 2020 concerning the petition on e-cigarettes (EN1362).

The Australian Government is taking a precautionary approach to e-cigarettes and continues to monitor emerging evidence about the direct harms they pose to human health, their impact on smoking initiation and cessation, uptake among youth, and dual use with conventional tobacco products. This position is based on the need to consider overall the impacts that e-cigarettes pose to population health, including on non-smokers and smokers.

Recent reports have highlighted alarming trends in youth e-cigarette use in some countries, such as the United States of America and Canada where e-cigarettes containing nicotine are widely marketed and accessible. Increasing evidence linking their marketing and use to nicotine addiction, lung disease and smoking uptake among youth are particularly troubling and reflect the Government's stance on e-cigarettes.

On 28 November 2019, the Ministerial Drug and Alcohol Forum, which includes Commonwealth and State and Territory Ministers, agreed to a set of updated national guiding principles for e-cigarettes. The principles reaffirm the precautionary approach to e-cigarettes being taken by all Australian governments. The principles also note that any change to regulation of e-cigarettes in Australia will have protecting the health of children and young people as its primary focus and goal. The principles are available on my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au click on resources and search 'regulatory approach to e-cigarettes in Australia'.

The Government's approach to e-cigarettes also recognises the current state of evidence regarding their utility as an aid to smoking cessation. At a population level, there continues to be insufficient evidence promote the use of these products for smoking cessation. Unlike any e-cigarette product, all smoking cessation products lawfully available for sale in Australia have been evaluated by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) for safety and efficacy, and have been registered with the TGA. There are no restrictions on who might apply to the TGA to market a smoking cessation product in Australia. However, no e-cigarettes have been approved by the TGA for smoking cessation.

Currently, nicotine for use in e-cigarettes cannot be lawfully sold in Australia. The sale of nicotine for use in e-cigarettes would require an amendment to the Standard for the Uniform Scheduling of Medicines and Poisons (the Poisons Standard). The Poisons Standard is a record of decisions regarding the classification of medicines and chemicals into Schedules for inclusion in relevant legislation of the states and territories. There is a clearly defined process for amendments to the Poisons Standard to be considered and it is important to note this process is independent from Government. Under this process, anyone may make an application to schedule or reschedule a substance.

Although nicotine for use in e-cigarettes is not currently available for sale in Australia, it may be lawful for health practitioners to access this substance on behalf of their patients for smoking cessation in specific circumstances. Further information about accessing products that have not been approved by the TGA for sale in Australia is available at: www.tga.gov.au/accessing-unapproved-products.

On 25 May 2017, the Standing Committee on Health, Aged Care and Sport commenced an inquiry into the use and marketing of e-cigarettes and personal vaporisers in Australia. The Inquiry's final report was published on 28 March 2018 and is available at www.aph.gov.au by using the search term 'Inquiry e-cigarettes'. The Government will carefully consider the Inquiry's recommendations before providing a response.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN 1362)
Women in Sport
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2020 concerning petition number: EN1368 requesting that the House support the Transforming Brimbank Girls and Women in Sport 2020 Agenda. Through the national sport plan, Sport 2030, the Australian Government is continuing to support more women and girls to participate in sport and physical activity.
