The ASF provides assistance to not-for-profit, incorporated and other eligible organisations, such as sporting clubs, councils, schools and community groups to raise funds for sport­related projects that aim to increase opportunities for Australians to participate in sport. Further information can be found on the ASF website at: www.asf.org.au or by telephone on (02) 5112 0990.

I acknowledge Brim bank City Council's interest in establishing a permanent training base at Sydenham Park for the National Women's Football team, the Matildas. The Government has made a $15 million commitment to support women's football and establish a national Home for the Matildas. Football Victoria is leadi.ng the project, working closely with the Victorian Government.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Youth and Sport, Senator Colbeck (Petition No. EN1368)
Age Pension
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 13 May 2020, on behalf of the Australian Pensioners' and Superannuants' League (QLD) Inc, concerning petition EN1370—Age Pension single and couple relativity.

The Australian Government appreciates the important economic and social contribution senior Australians make to our community and is keen to ensure that pensioners' living standards are safeguarded by the Age Pension. Pensions, such as the Age Pension, are funded by taxpayers and targeted through the means test to those who need it most.

On 20 March 2020, the maximum total pension rate for single pensioners increased to $944.30 a fortnight or $24,551.80 a year. The maximum rate for pensioner couples combined increased to $1,423.60 a fortnight or $37,013.60 a year.

The social security system recognises that single pensioners need more income to have a similar standard of living to couples. The single rate is set at 66.33 per cent of the couple combined pension, while each eligible member of a couple receives 50 per cent of the combined couple rate.

Prior to the 2009 Secure and Sustainable Pension Reform package, which was based on findings of the Pension Review undertaken by Dr Jeff Harmer, the relativity was around 60 per cent. The Pension Review found that the relativity was too low for single pensioners who live alone and should be in the range of 64 to 67 per cent. This recommendation was supported by research on actual expenditures of single pensioners and pensioner couples, as well as evidence about hardship and financial stress.

Couples gain economies and advantages from living together and can pool resources to meet their needs. Single people cannot usually share costs such as electricity, telephone, transport, heating and house maintenance, which is why single pensioners receive a higher pension rate than each member of a couple.

Members of a couple also face some individual costs for which the opportunity to economise by sharing is limited. Food, clothing, medical expenses and travel costs are examples of expenses where there are limited economies. As a result, a couple needs more than a single person, but less than double, to achieve the same standard of living.
Services Australia (Centrelink) has payments, support and other services to help those who are widowed. Further information, is available at
https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/subjects/death-and-bereavement#support.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston (Petition No. EN1370)
Road Safety
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 13 May 2020 concerning the House of Representatives petition EN1374, which seeks amendments to Australian Design Rule (ADR) 6/00, Direction Indicators.

The Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communications administers the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 (the Act), which requires that all new road vehicles to comply with the ADRs before they can be offered to the market for use in Australia. The ADRs are mostly performance-based standards that deliver levels of vehicle safety, emission control and anti-theft protection that are generally expected by the Australian community.

Where possible, the ADRs are harmonised with international vehicle regulations adopted by the United Nations (UN). This is important because the overwhelming majority of motor vehicles supplied to the Australian market are imported, while vehicle sales in Australia represent less than one per cent of the total world production of motor vehicles. Regulation based on internationally agreed standards provides consumers with access to the safest vehicles from the global market at the lowest cost.

ADR 6/00 is harmonised with UN Regulation 6 which specifies a range of requirements direction indicators must comply with, including requirements related to the intensity of the light emitted and the colour of the light emitted. Prescriptive design requirements such as those suggested are not included as they can limit innovation in the vehicle industry.

Recently, the UN has conducted a review of its lighting regulations and is currently transitioning from individual lamp regulations like regulation 6 to three regulations covering road illumination devices (Regulation 149), light signalling devices (Regulation 148) and retroreflective devices (Regulation 150). My Department has commenced a project to review and amend the lighting ADRs to allow continued harmonisation with UN regulations.

For the reasons mentioned in this letter, the Department is not considering establishing unique requirements for direction indicator lamps. However, if as a result of its review it identifies deficiencies in the performance of direction indicators, it may raise those issues at the UN World forum for the Harmonization of Vehicle Regulations (WP.29), the peak international forum for the development and harmonisation of vehicle standards, or its subsidiary body the Working Group on Lighting and Light Signalling (ORE) for consideration of amending the regulations.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to my attention and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr McCormack (Petition No. EN1374)
COVID-19: Schools
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your emails of 13 May 2020 to the Hon Greg Hunt MP, Minister for Health, regarding the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) and Petitions EN1375, EN1388, EN1395 and EN1399. As the matters raised fall with my portfolio responsibilities as Minister for Education, your emails have been referred to me for response.

The Australian Government is actively monitoring the outbreak of COVID-19. The National Cabinet, made up of the Prime Minister, Premiers and Chief Ministers, is co-ordinating the national response to COVID-19 across all Australian governments.

As you know, the Australian Government's priority is to keep communities safe. We will continue to follow the medical advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC), which is developed by chief medical officers from the Commonwealth and each state and territory. The aim of all governments is to safeguard the health of Australians.

The National Cabinet has agreed to a set of seven National Principles for School Education (National Principles) to support the ongoing delivery of high quality education for all school students during COVID-19. These principles are available at www.dese.gov.au/covid-19/schools/national-principles-for-school-education.

The National Principles note that the consistent health advice of the AHPPC is that attendance at a school campus for education represents a very low health risk to students. The advice also notes that appropriate practices must be employed at schools, like at other workplaces, to provide a safe working environment for school staff, including teachers, and that the specific AHPPC advice regarding school campuses should be followed.

The AHPPC has issued practical guidance and advice to support school leaders to reduce even further the risk of COVID-19 transmission in schools. The guidelines and the latest health information relating to COVID-19 are available at www.health.gov.au/committees-and-groups/australian-health-protection-principal-committee-ahppc.

It is vital that all students continue to engage with a high quality education and progress through their year level throughout this COVIDl9 period. While the AHPPC advice is clear that there is a low risk of transmission of the virus in schools, ultimately, operational decisions about the reopening of schools are matters for state and territory governments and non-government sector authorities. During the pandemic across Australia a mix of delivery models were in place, including remote and online learning, face-to-face teaching, and staggered returns to classroom teaching. All states and territories have now reopened their schools.

In addition, the Australian Government advice has been consistent that universities and higher education providers are essential and should continue operating at this time. This advice was supported by the AHPPC in a statement issued on 17 March 2020 that universities and higher education providers should continue operations but with appropriate risk mitigation measures implemented including social distancing. The AHPPC advice supported education providers moving to online platforms, where appropriate, for continuity of student education.
For programs requiring face-to-face interactions or that use physical environments, such as laboratories, it was advised that classes could continue but need to consider:
social distancing requirements including reduction in the size of the classes, and
enhanced hygiene measures including ensure regular hand hygiene for all staff and students and ensure cleaning addresses areas of high touch points for students and staff.

Universities and higher education providers are autonomous entities and able to make their own decisions around how they respond to the COVID-19 pandemic. I expect the announcement of the national three-step road map to a COVID-safe Australia will gradually see a return to on-campus learning.

The Australian Government Department of Education, Skills and Employment provides advice for schools and early childhood education and care services, parents, students and higher education providers about COVID-19. The Department of Health also provides regular updates on the COVID-19 situation in Australia. The most recent advice from Australian Government agencies is available at www.australia.gov.au.
I trust this information assists the deliberations of the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Tehan (Petition Nos EN1375, EN1388, EN1395 and EN1399)
Environment
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2020 concerning petition number EN1377, regarding the plastic pollution problem.

The Morrison Government recognises the importance of Australia's environmental sustainability, and both the challenges and opportunities in front of us when it comes to plastics and waste more broadly. That is why our Government is strongly committed to reducing waste, increasing recycling and making sure that we can manage our waste and recycling here in Australia.

On 8 November 2019, Australia's Environment Ministers agreed to a new National Waste Policy Action Plan that will drive the implementation of our National Waste Policy. One of the targets in the National Waste Policy Action Plan is to phase out problematic and unnecessary plastics by 2025, with an agreed action to develop a National Plastic Plan by the end of 2020 to increase recycling rates and reduce plastic pollution.

Environment ministers also agreed to ambitious 2025 National Packaging Targets to create a new sustainable pathway for the way we manage plastic packaging in Australia. In addition to the target to phase out problematic and unnecessary single-use plastics packaging by 2025 or sooner, environment ministers agreed to achieve the following by 2025:
100 per cent of packaging is reusable, recyclable or compostible;
70 per cent of plastic packaging is recycled or composted;
50 per cent average recycled content included in packaging.

The Australian Packaging Covenant Organisation (APCO) and its members (over 1000 brand-owners and retailers) are delivering an extensive program of work to deliver on the 2025 National Packaging Targets.

The Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment administers the Product Stewardship Act 2011, which provides a framework to effectively manage the environmental, health and safety impacts of products. To enable greater levels of recycling across Australia, the Government has committed $20 million for a Product Stewardship Investment Fund to accelerate work on new industry-led schemes and increase recycling rates of existing and new schemes.

Plastic waste is a shared problem and, in the long-term, it will require a shared solution. The Government strongly supports and encourages jurisdictions to grow our recycling capabilities and to reduce litter and other wastes, including cans, plastic containers, plastic bags and other packaging material, to reduce their impact on the environment. State and territory governments retain responsibility for waste management and associated legislation. States have several different ways in which they encourage recycling and reduce the impact of waste on the environment, such as regulating to reduce the amount of waste going to landfill and providing funding for infrastructure and industry development.

We can also be encouraged by state and territory governments' efforts to minimise and ban plastics. For example, I am encouraged to see that South Australia is working on a potential ban of certain products such as plastic straws, cutlery and stirrers, and Queensland is developing a Plastic Pollution Reduction Plan for government, business and the community to work together to reduce the impacts of plastic pollution. In Queensland, the lightweight single-use plastic shopping bag ban will also significantly reduce the amount of plastic litter in the environment. To complement the ban, Queensland is working with retailers to adopt a voluntary phase-out of thicker single-use µboutique' style plastic shopping bags.

Coles and Woolworths are taking steps to improve the recyclability of their home-brand product packaging, reduce plastic packaging where appropriate and ensure that their customers can recycle plastic bags and other soft-plastic packaging that can't be recycled through household kerbside recycling services through Recycle collection bins at shopfronts. Aldi has also taken steps to improve their packaging and labelling. The Australian Government will keep working with state and territory governments and businesses to support these initiatives.

I hope this background serves to demonstrate that plastic wastes are a major priority for the Morrison Government and that the Commonwealth is undertaking a comprehensive and ambitious program to address this significant national challenge in close collaboration with industry and state and territory governments.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Waste Reduction and Environmental Management, Mr Evans (Petition No. EN1377)
Taxation
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2020 concerning Petition EN1380 - Tax Reform. Receiving suggestions from members of the public plays an important role in the Government's efforts to monitor and respond to the economic impact of the Coronavirus. Please accept my sincere apologies for being slow to respond. I have received a large number of emails and requests for information and have not been able to respond as quickly as I would like.
The Australian Government has acted decisively to support households and businesses and address the significant economic consequences of the Coronavirus.
The Government's Economic Support Package provides timely support to workers, households and

businesses through a difficult time and has positioned the Australian economy to recover strongly. A total of $259 billion is being injected into the economy in order to keep Australians in work and businesses in business.

The package is designed to support businesses to retain jobs and manage short-term cash flow challenges, provide support to individuals, severely affected communities and regions, and to ensure the continued flow of credit in the Australian economy.

The Government understands that the economic and financial impacts of Corona virus will extend well beyond those receiving direct assistance under its Economic Response to Coronavirus package. This event will affect all Australians, to varying degrees. The announced measures are expected to benefit all Australians, now and over the long-term, by supporting overall confidence, employment and business continuity.
We appreciate the concerns raised in this petition and will ensure they are part of the feedback that we pass on to the relevant offices.
More information about this package is available at: www.treasury.gov.au/coronavirus
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar (Petition No. EN1380)
COVID-19: Economy
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter dated 13 May 2020, concerning Petition EN1387 - Call for financial relief support and assistance to events industry.
I acknowledge that the impact of COVID-19 on the arts and entertainment sector is very significant.

In recognition of the economic, social and national importance of the cultural and creative sector, the Morrison Government has provided $277 million of additional, targeted support to the sector in response to the pandemic. This includes a comprehensive COVID-19 Creative Economy package totalling $250 million to support the sector get back in business following the disruptions caused by COVID-19, announced by the Government on 25 June. This support includes:

Seed Investment -
$75 million in grant funding to support new productions, festivals and events through the Restart Investment to Sustain and Expand (RISE) Fund

Kick-starting Local Screen Production
- $50 million for Screen Australia to support local film and television producers to secure finance in the face of temporary insurance market failures

Concessional Loans
- $90 million for concessional loans to assist arts and entertainment businesses to fund new productions and events, to be delivered through banks supported by terms and conditions tailored to the arts and entertainment sector; and

Supporting Sustainability of Sector-Significant Organisations
- $35 million to support significant arts and culture organisations facing sustainability disruption due to COVID-19.

In addition, the Government is establishing a Creative Economy Taskforce to support implementation of the package, alongside the Office for the Arts and the Australia Council. Following the successful development of guidelines to safely reopen our National Collecting Institutions and support the reopening of the screen sector, the Government is also working through the National Cabinet to develop a broader roadmap to reopen for the arts and entertainment sector to protect the public and workers.

The RISE Fund will provide seed investment for new events and productions to enable the arts and entertainment sector to restart. Private promoters putting on musicals, concerts or arts festivals need capital to book venues, hire staff, market their events and develop new ways of presenting commercially viable shows. Arts businesses - whether subsidised companies or private promoters and commercial production companies - will be able to apply for competitive funding.

Complementing the RISE Fund, a loan facility will be able to be drawn upon should subsidised or commercial arts companies need additional funds. The Government is providing $90 million for a concessional loan scheme to enable arts organisations and businesses access to vital funding to rebuild and invest in income generating activities. The funds will be earmarked from the Coronavirus SME Guarantee Scheme, with arts sector specific loan settings and eligibility. Loans will be available for companies for activities that generate jobs and are subject to lenders' credit assessment and approval processes.

These measures are on top of the $27 million announced on 9 April which is providing dedicated financial support to Indigenous visual art centres, regional arts and the live music and performance industry.

This funding supplements the approximately $750 million the Government was already investing in the arts and cultural sector in 2019-20 - the highest amount ever - for a diverse range of programs and organisations across the visual arts, performing arts, literature, national collecting institutions, Indigenous arts and languages, screen and music.

Many businesses and organisations in the cultural and creative sector are able to draw on the Government's substantial economy-wide stimulus measures. A total of $259 billion, equivalent to 13.3 per cent of annual GDP, in economic measures have enhanced the nation's safety net for individuals and businesses affected by COVID-19.
There is a range of other whole-of-government assistance that may also be accessible to organisations in the cultural and creative sector:
Cash flow assistance for small and medium businesses and not-for-profits (including charities), up to a maximum of $100,000 with a minimum payment of $20,000
Increase to the instant asset write-off threshold from $30,000 to $150,000
Government may guarantee 50 per cent of new unsecured loans to small and medium businesses
Temporary relief for directors from any personal liability for trading while insolvent because of COVID-19
Temporary increase to the threshold at which creditors can issue a statutory demand on a company and the time companies have to respond; and

Not-for-profit arts organisations may also be eligible for Deductible Gift Recipient status, and those that are registered as charities may be eligible for Income Tax exemptions, Goods and Services Tax concessions, and Fringe Benefits Tax rebates and exemptions.

Finally, both the Australia Council and the Office for the Arts are being as flexible as possible in providing reporting and other grant condition relief to organisations with existing Government funding arrangements.
The Government has acted decisively to provide significant support to assist the cultural and creative sector to reactivate and contribute to the recovery of Australia's economy and communities.
Please also check the Office for the Arts website for further information at www.arts.gov.au.
Thank you again for writing and I trust this information is helpful.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN1387)

from the Minister for Communications, Cyber Safety and the Arts, Mr Fletcher (Petition No. EN1391)
COVID-19: Sports
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I refer to your letter of 13 May 2020 concerning petition number EN1393, which seeks to postpone the recommencement of the 2020 Australian Football League (AFL) season in light of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Australian Government is taking a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest and best medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and the Communicable Diseases Network Australia.

Australia is very well prepared to respond to COVID-19 and the course of the virus. Australian Government agencies and state and territory governments are working together to coordinate an evidence-based response and keep Australians fully informed.
Together these actions have placed us in a good position globally.

On 8 May 2020, the National Cabinet finalised a three-step roadmap plan to gradually remove baseline community restrictions and make Australia COVID-safe. Stages relating to the resumption of sport and recreation activities are underpinned by the National Principles for the Resumption of Sport and Recreation Activities (Principles) and the Australian Institute of Sport's Framework for Rebooting Sport in a COVID-19 Environment. These frameworks allow for the resumption of competitions by sporting organisations provided they engage with, and where necessary seek approvals from, the respective state/territory and/or local public health authorities regarding additional measures to reduce the risk of COVID-19 spread.

In relation to the resumption of sporting and activities, jurisdictions have the ultimate responsibility for implementing their own restrictions and making the final decision as to whether the AFL and other professional sports can recommence. These decisions are not made lightly.

The AFL is implementing extensive transmission risk mitigation measures for the recommencement of the season. These include stringent protocols for players, staff and officials before, during and after training, with oversight from the AFL in these controlled environments exceeding that which may be ordinarily expected across the community.

Commonwealth and state and territory governments will maintain an open dialogue with the AFL to monitor the resumption of its professional competition and ensure it fully complies with current health advice and additional measures agreed with relevant jurisdictions.
Thank you for writing.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1393)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for writing to me in relation to Petition EN1402, which attracted 13 signatures, requesting that the House freeze all (household) bills and initiate quarantine in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
The Government appreciates that this has been a difficult time for all Australians and the impact that COVID-19 is having on lives.

First, in relation to freezing of household bills, while the Government appreciates the good intentions of the petitioners, it would not be a practical measure at this time, especially given the comprehensive measures that the Government has already taken to keep Australians in jobs and businesses in business.
To support these efforts, we have already announced $260 billion in measures to protect the economy- that is around 13 per cent of the size of the economy.

Our measures support households including casuals and sole traders, retirees and those on income support. They include doubling the JobSeeker Payment, through the introduction of a temporary coronavirus supplement.

We are providing a historic wage subsidy to workers who will receive a flat payment of $1,500 per fortnight through their eligible employer, before tax. The JobKeeper Payment scheme will help businesses significantly impacted by COVID-19 with the costs of their employees' wages so more Australians can retain their jobs and businesses can restart quickly when the crisis is over.

We are also providing regulatory protection and financial support to help businesses stay in business. This includes subsidising up to half the wages of 117,000 apprentices in 70,000 small businesses and $31.9 billion in financial support for small businesses.

Second, in relation to quarantine, we quickly established travel bans and scaled up screening on our borders. We evacuated Australians from virus hotspots and set up quarantine facilities. All travellers arriving in Australia are required to undertake 14 day self-isolation at designated facilities.

Additionally, our world class health system is receiving over $6 billion in additional support to fight against COVID-19, including taking action to set up more than I 00 pop-up clinics, expanding telehealth services, providing additional mental health support to Australians and ensuring the viability of our private and not-for-profit hospitals.

We have also increased funding to public hospitals and aged care, boosted our National Medical Stockpile of essential medicines and masks, and have secured alternative supplies of vital personal protective equipment for our healthcare workers.

Because we are winning this fight against the virus, with tangible success on the health front and economic lifelines in place, from here, the Government has now embarked on the next stage of our plan to reopen the economy and support the recovery.

The Government's JobMaker Plan will restore and create jobs, support incomes and lift economic growth. It will achieve this by enabling business to thrive by skilling Australians; building the infrastructure to support a modem, innovative and competitive economy; minimising red tape; and ensuring we continue to champion free trade and open access to markets.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Prime Minister, Mr Morrison (Petition No. EN1402)
COVID-19: Economy
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2020 concerning Petition EN1405—support for venues impacted by Coronavirus. Please accept my sincere apologies for being slow to respond. I have received a large number of emails and requests for information and have not been able to respond as quickly as I would like.

National Cabinet agreed to a moratorium on evictions over the next six months for residential tenancies in financial distress who are unable to meet their commitments due to the impact of Coronavirus.

Importantly, the Australian Government's JobKeeper payment is designed to provide timely support to affected businesses and their employees. The JobKeeper payment is a wage subsidy made to eligible businesses and not-for-profits affected by the coronavirus to support them in retaining employees. Eligible employees and those who are self-employed will receive a minimum of $1,500 per fortnight before tax, which will assist with the economic and financial impacts of the coronavirus.
Any further measures beyond the moratorium on eviction, which may impact your particular circumstances, are a matter for state and territory jurisdictions, who have responsibility for these issues.
Some state and territory links for residential tenancies:
NSW www.fairtrading.nsw.gov.au/resource-library/publications/coronavirus-covid-19/property/moratorium
Vic www.consumer.vic.gov.au/resources-and-tools/advice-in-a-disaster/coronavirus-covid19-and-vour-rights
Qld www.covid19.qld.gov.au/the-hub
WA www.commerce.wa.gov.au/consumer-protection/residential-tenancies-covid-19-response
SA www.cbs.sa.gov.au/rental-advice-due-covid-19#
Tas www.cbos.tas.gov.au/topics/housing/residential-tenancies-covid-19-emergency-provisions
ACT www.covid19.act.gov.au/help-and-advice/residential-tenancies
NT www.consumeraffairs.nt.gov.au/rental-changes-due-to-covid-19/residential-tenants-affected-by-covid-19 (for residential tenants) and
www.consumeraffairs.nt.gov.au/rental-changes-due-to-covid-19/residential-landlords-affected-by-covid-19 (for residential landlords).
Regarding the broader support for the economy, the Government has acted decisively to support households and businesses and address the significant economic consequences of the Coronavirus.
The Government's Economic Support Package provides timely support to workers, households and businesses through a difficult time and has positioned the Australian economy to recover strongly.
A total of $259 billion is being injected into the economy in order to keep Australians in work and businesses in business.

The package is designed to support businesses to retain jobs and manage short-term cash flow challenges, provide support to individuals, severely affected communities and regions, and to ensure the continued flow of credit in the Australian economy.

The Government has introduced a wage subsidy program to support employees and businesses. Under the JobKeeper payment, eligible businesses and not-for-profits will receive $1,500 per fortnight per eligible employee to cover the costs of wages. This will mean more employees can retain their job and continue to earn an income.

The Government is providing up to $100,000 to eligible small and medium sized businesses (SMEs), and not-for-profits (including charities) that employ people, with a minimum payment of $20,000. These payments will help businesses' and not-for-profits' cash flow so they can keep operating, pay their rent, electricity and other bills and retain staff.

The package provides regulatory protection for businesses to stay in business, including by providing temporary regulatory relief for financially distressed businesses. This builds on other business support measures to increase the instant asset write off, back business investment by providing accelerated depreciation deductions, supporting apprentices and trainees and providing targeted support for Coronavirus-affected regions and communities
The Government has also made temporary changes to the bankruptcy system to help lessen the threat of people being forced into bankruptcy during the difficult economic times ahead.
More information about this package is available at: www.treasury.gov.au/coronavirus
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar (Petition No. EN1405)
Beechworth Principles
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2020 regarding Petition EN1412, which requests that the House of Representatives supports the passage of a Bill to establish a Federal Integrity Commission that upholds the Beechworth Principles established by the Member for Indi, Dr Helen Haines MP. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.

The Australian Government condemns corruption in all its forms. The Government is committed to ensuring our federal integrity framework is as robust as possible to maximise public confidence in our national institutions.

That is why the Government has committed to establishing a Commonwealth Integrity Commission (CIC) to enhance national integrity arrangements across the federal public sector. The CIC will comprise a public sector integrity division and a law enforcement integrity division, ensuring targeted attention to corruption across the entirety of the public sector.

I note the petitioners' support for an anti-corruption body that upholds the Beechworth Principles of 'broad jurisdiction, common rules, appropriate powers, fair hearings, and accountability to the people.' The proposed CIC is broadly consistent with these principles. Specifically, the CIC will be an independent statutory agency with an extensive jurisdiction and a broad suite of coercive and investigative powers. Existing integrity agencies will be able to refer matters to the CIC, and vice versa. In appropriate circumstances, the CIC will be able to conduct joint investigations with other agencies, including state and territory anti-corruption commissions.

Through the CIC, the Government is intending to target serious criminal corruption that presents a threat to good public administration. The CIC will not duplicate the roles of existing bodies, but instead it will provide an expert investigative capability to respond to allegations of serious criminal corruption across the public sector.

While the CIC must be equipped with strong powers to effectively address corruption, I am committed to ensuring the model also provides due process of law and natural justice to those who fall within the CIC's jurisdiction. In relation to the Beechworth Principle promoting public hearings, hearings will only be able to be held in public when dealing with law enforcement corruption issues, not when dealing with other corruption issues. This will promote natural justice in investigations and preserve the role of the courts as arbiters of a person's guilt or innocence.

The public sector division will focus on investigating suspected criminal corrupt conduct, while maintaining the role of existing integrity agencies and mechanisms for dealing with less serious forms of misconduct. This will ensure that the jurisdiction of the CIC and other integrity agencies is clear and that the CIC's significant powers are reserved for use in appropriately serious cases.

The Government has been consulting widely to ensure that the model for the new Commission strengthens federal integrity arrangements without comprom1sing fundamental principles of our criminal justice system. The Government is focused on ensuring that the CIC is properly designed, appropriately resourced and informed by thorough consultation. To that end, we will be releasing a draft of the CIC legislation for public consultation. The petitioners may wish to consider the draft and provide further comments once it is made available.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter (Petition No. EN1412)
Business Investment
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition Ministerial Referral (EN1421). Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

As you may be aware, on 29 March 2020 the Treasurer announced temporary changes to the foreign investment review framework designed to protect Australia's national interest as we deals with the COVID-19 pandemic. Under the changes, all proposed foreign investments into Australia subject to the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 require approval. The changes help us safeguard the national interest as the pandemic puts intense pressure on the Australian economy and Australian businesses. Without these changes, it is possible many normally viable Australian businesses would be sold to foreign interests without any government oversight, presenting risks to the national interest.

At the same time, the Australian Government recognises that foreign investment will play an important part in helping many businesses get to the other side—securing jobs and supporting our economic recovery. In a post-COVID-19 world, competition for global foreign direct investment will intensify. We must maintain our reputation and credibility as an open and welcoming place to invest. Foreign investment supports one in ten jobs, boosts our exports by improving business links to global supply chains, and helps our businesses achieve global success by bringing critical skills and technologies to Australia.

In addition to these temporary changes, on 5 June 2020 the Treasurer announced comprehensive reforms to the foreign investment review framework. These reforms update the framework in three broad ways: they address national security risks; strengthen the existing system, particularly as it relates to compliance by foreign investors; and streamline investment in non-sensitive businesses. The intention is for a seamless transition from the temporary measures to the reforms, which are intended to commence on 1 January 2021.
For further information on the temporary changes and the reforms please refer to the Foreign Investment Review Board website at www.firb.gov.au
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar (Petition No. EN1421)
COVID-19
Dear Chair

I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1423, calling on the Australian Government to counter the spread of COVID-19 in Australia by implementing an immediate lockdown and strong social distancing measures. I note Australia's situation concerning the pandemic has changed substantially since the petition was initiated.

The Government took a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest and best medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee. Australia's strategy was based on the twin pillars of containment and capacity building. Our health emergency response measures were proportionate, scalable and tailored to the situation as it evolved. They included closing borders and implementing quarantine periods; testing and contact tracing; physical distancing; and enhanced hygiene practices.

The international experience, as observed by the petitioner and many Australians, informed the community's support for physical distancing and similar measures. These measures successfully contained the spread of COVID-19 in the community and placed Australia in a good position globally.

Australia's COVID-19 response included building capacity across the primary healthcare, aged-care, hospital and medical research systems to ensure they were not overwhelmed as feared by the petitioner. Aligned initiatives included improving the surge capacity and upskilling the medical workforce; increasing intensive care unit capacity and medical equipment (including ventilators); and boosting supplies of personal protective equipment.

In addition, the Government introduced telehealth services, a home medicines program, a $74 million mental health support package; over $850 million to support the aged care sector's response to COVID-19, opened more than 133 GP led respiratory clinics, and contributed over $352 million funding to develop vaccines, treatments and diagnostics.

The Government is fully committed to keeping Australians as safe and well as possible during this pandemic. We have been highly successful in 'flattening the curve'. Australian governments are now taking a measured approach, implementing a three-step plan that gradually remove restrictions to allow work and social activities to resume in a COVID-19 safe environment. A roadmap outlining each step can be found in the media update of 8 May 2020 at: www.pm.gov.au.

The three-step plan provides a pathway for states and territories to move towards COVID-safe communities in a way that best suits their individual circumstances, reflecting the fact that they are at different stages of the pandemic response. The focus is now on containing domestic outbreaks in local communities through rapid responses.

Our continued success in keeping our communities safe as restrictions ease depends on all of us continuing to practice physical distancing. We need to stay home when unwell and make enhanced hygiene part of our daily lives. When Australians leave home they will need to continue to think about how to keep themselves, their family and local community safe.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1423)
Domestic and Family Violence
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 15 June 2020 regarding petition EN1426, which proposes that urgent reforms are required to protect men during police investigations and within the judicial system from false allegations of domestic violence.

The petition raises the issue of false allegations of domestic violence being made by mothers and other parties in state and federal court proceedings. All victims, regardless of whether male or female, need compassionate and highly responsive support when experiencing domestic, family and sexual violence, and all perpetrators must be held accountable for their violence. The National Plan to Reduce Violence against Women and their Children 2010-2022 (the National Plan) recognises that men and boys can be victims of domestic and family violence and sexual assault.

It is a role for the courts to consider the evidence presented, including allegations of family violence, and determine the weight it should be given in proceedings. This is done on a case-by-case basis. Under Australia's federal system of government, the criminal aspects of violence against women and their children are primarily a state and territory government responsibility. Each jurisdiction manages its own criminal justice system, including criminal laws, policing, courts and corrections. As the criminal aspects of the concerns raised fall within the responsibilities of the states and territories, they would be appropriately directed to relevant state or territory Attorneys-General.

To the extent the petition raises concerns about the family law system, the Family Law Act 1975 provides a legal framework for resolving arrangements for children and property following a relationship breakdown, which fall within Commonwealth responsibility.

The 'best interests of the child' is the paramount consideration when resolving parenting matters. This includes the need to protect children from harm and, in the absence of factors such as violence or abuse, for children to enjoy a meaningful relationship with each of their parents. The Family Law Act is gender neutral and focuses on the rights of children and the responsibilities that each parent has towards their children, rather than on parental rights.

With regard to the petition's call for change to federal law, the Government is committed to ensuring the family law system is supporting Australian families to resolve their disputes safely, and as efficiently and cheaply as possible. That is why the Government supported the establishment of a Joint Select Committee to inquire into the family law system. Family and relationship breakdown are often .traumatic and devastating experiences for all involved. For those going through the family law system during this harrowing time, it's important that the systems they have to go through work as best as they can. Family breakdown is a risk factor for suicide; it is a time when family violence can escalate, and it warrants this level of attention.

The terms of reference for the inquiry are broad, and allow for the examination of a range of matters that have a real and practical impact on Australian families. It is an opportunity to further consider how to ensure the family law system keeps children and families safe from violence and abuse. The inquiry will look at how the family law system, state and territory child protection systems and family and domestic violence jurisdictions can communicate better, given the importance of this issue for keeping children and families safe.

The inquiry also provides an opportunity to look at the way family violence orders are considered in family law proceedings, which is an issue frequently raised, noting the importance of ensuring family members, including children, are not placed at risk of further violence. Additionally, the inquiry also provides the opportunity to examine the appropriateness of family court powers to ensure parties in family law proceedings provide truthful and complete evidence.

The Committee is scheduled to report by 7 October 2020. For the terms of reference and further information about the progress of the inquiry, please see the Committee's website at: www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary Business/Committees/Joint/Family Law System.

The Government is also carefully considering the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission's (ALRC) comprehensive review of the family law system, including the Family Law Act: This included consideration of how to ensure the system protects the best interests of the child and keeps families safe from violence and abuse. The final report was tabled by the Attorney-General on 10 April 2019 and is available from the ALRC website: www.alrc.gov.au/inguiries/farnily-law-system. The Government will give thorough consideration to the complex issues set out in the report, and each of its recommendations, before determining how to proceed.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter (Petition No. EN1426)
COVID-19
Dear Chair

I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1429, calling on the Australian Government to counter the spread of COVID-19 in Australia by implementing an immediate lockdown, similar to Italy, for at least 12 weeks.

The Australian Government took a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest and best medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal _Committee. Australia's strategy was based on the twin pillars of containment and capacity building.

Our health emergency response measures were proportionate, scalable and tailored to the situation as it evolved. They included closing borders and implementing quarantine periods; testing and contact tracing; physical distancing; and enhanced hygiene practices. These measures successfully contained the spread of COVID-19 in the community and placed Australia in a good position globally. Unlike countries such as Italy which was mentioned in the petition, we have remained ahead of the curve.

Research shows that because of the virus's exponential growth characteristics, the effectiveness of lockdown measures is affected by the time of the epidemic when the measures are established. Furthermore, it has become apparent from observations of other countries, where restrictions have been lifted too soon, there has been a 'second wave' of infection.

The Australian governments are taking a measured approach, implementing a three-step plan that gradually remove restrictions to allow work and social activities to resume in a COVID-19 safe environment. A roadmap outlining each step can be found in the media update of 8 May 2020 at: www.pm.gov.au. The three-step plan provides a pathway for states and territories to move towards COVID-safe communities in a way that best suits their individual circumstances, reflecting the fact that they are at different stages of the pandemic response. It is anticipated that all three steps will be completed across the country in July 2020.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1429)
COVID-19
Dear Chair
I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning Petition number EN1433. The petition calls on the Australian Government to close hairdressing and beautician salons during the COVID-19 pandemic.

On 24 March 2020, the National Cabinet introduced social distancing measures that closed highly discretional services that required close and prolonged personal contact between the service provider and client, including beauty therapy, nail salons, massage parlours, body piercing services and tattoo parlours. Hairdressing was exempted recognising that hairdressers can take action to minimise continuous face-to-face contact by working from behind clients as much as practically possible.

On 8 May 2020, the National Cabinet announced the national three-step plan to relax restrictions, help prepare Australians to go back to work in a COVID-19 safe environment and get the economy back to a more sustainable level. The three-step plan provides a pathway for jurisdictions to move towards COVID safe communities in a way that best suits their individual circumstances.

Safe Work Australia provides information to support workplaces through this transition period, with specific information available for beauty salons, and hairdressers. This includes information on undertaking a risk assessment for work that requires close contact with a client. Current guidelines can be found by searching 'beauty salons' or 'hairdressing' at: www.safeworkaustralia.gov.au.
I hope the above information provides clarity on the rationale for the approach for hairdressers and beauty services.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1433)
COVID-19
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter of 15 June 2020 forwarding Petition EN1435 that asks the House of Representatives to consider and approve the repatriation by air of Australians who have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Since 13 March 2020, more than 340,000 Australian citizens and permanent residents have returned to Australia. The majority of these have done so by means of regular commercial flights. However, a significant number have returned - and continue to return - because of prompt, practical intervention by the Australian Government.

To date, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has, through its global diplomatic network, helped over 25,000 Australian citizens and permanent residents to return home on over 290 flights, of which 58 were directly facilitated by the Government. Our facilitation efforts included the provision of financial support to Qantas and Virgin, so they could maintain a schedule of flights from key international hubs from April to early June.

I am pleased that the resumption of a growing number of airlines' scheduled commercial flights into Australia is providing many Australians overseas with better options to return. Where Australians overseas have very limited, or no, options to return however, the Government continues to work with airlines and other national governments on possible solutions.
I would be grateful if you could convey this response to your Committee's members.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne (Petition No. EN1435)
COVID-19: Hospitals
Dear Chair

I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1443 which requests limited medical registration be granted to international medical graduates (IMG) to assist with the response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Australia has been highly successful in 'flattening the curve' of COVID-19 infections. This success means the spread of COVID-19 has slowed and improved the capacity in our health system to manage the impact of the virus.

The Medical Board of Australia (MBA) is responsible for all matters relating to the regulation of the medical profession in Australia, including determining the suitability of IMGs for registration. The MBA is a national body established by the states and territories through the Health Practitioner Regulation National Law.

While maintaining standards to keep the public safe, the MBA has introducing new policies that will get more doctors into the health system, increase employer flexibility and cut red tape during this time. These new policies include:

Streamlined processes to enable IMGs within hospitals with limited and provisional registration to be redeployed more easily without a formal application to the MBA. The MBA will accept a written notice from the Director of Medical Services or equivalent of changes to supervisor, position or level of supervision (level one to two).

For 2020, the MBA will not refuse to renew an IMGs registration or refuse to re-register an IMG solely because they have not been able to sit an Australian Medical Council or college examination or assessment.

To further support the health workforce to response to COVID-19, all Australian health ministers endorsed the creation of a pandemic health practitioner sub-register to be established to fast track the return of experienced and qualified health practitioners to the workforce for a period of 12 months.

It is important to note that the pandemic sub-register is intended as a workforce contingency option and will be utilised when current health workforce options are exhausted'. There are some exceptions, where individuals will be recruited on a selective basis to fill positions where specialist skills and experience are required. Health practitioners on the sub-register must also ensure they work within their scope of practice, as it was prior to ceasing clinical practice.

While I understand the petitioners concerns about a potentially untapped pool of IMGs who are finding it difficult to find supervised employment opportunities, the Commonwealth does not have a direct role in the recruitment of health practitioners. The responsibility for employment of medical practitioners in hospitals rests with the relevant state and territory health departments.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1443)
COVID-19

States and territories will ease restrictions in a way that best suits their individual circumstances, reflecting the fact that they are at different stages in their pandemic response.

Yours sincerely
