from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1457)
COVID-19
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning the petition seeking support of landlords (petition number EN1464). Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.
The Australian Government has acted decisively to support households and businesses and address the significant economic consequences of the Coronavirus.

The Government's Economic Support Package provides timely support to workers, households and businesses through a difficult time and has positioned the Australian economy to recover strongly. A total of $259 billion is being injected into the economy in order to keep Australians in work and businesses in business.

The package is designed to support businesses to retain jobs and manage short-term cash flow challenges, provide support to individuals, severely affected communities and regions, and to ensure the continued flow of credit in the Australian economy. This includes the JobKeeper Payment, tax-free cash flow boosts for small and medium businesses that are employers, the small-medium sized entities (SME) guarantee scheme to enhance access to working capital and further support to business through increases to the instant asset write off and accelerated depreciation deductions to back business investment.

National Cabinet also agreed that state and territory jurisdictions would implement a mandatory Code of Conduct (the Code) for SME commercial leasing principles during COVID-19. The Code is ultimately regulated and enforced by state and territory jurisdictions.

The Code will help ensure SME businesses that rent their place of business are able to emerge from this challenging period and bounce back on the other side by allowing an appropriate burden share over the period and providing tenants and landlords with a framework with which to negotiate during this period. Importantly, the mandatory Code allows parties to reach tailored, bespoke and appropriate temporary arrangements for each tenant, and sets out a binding mediation process that parties should follow if they are not able to reach an appropriate agreement.

The more supportive we all are in ensuring as many businesses are in a position to continue activity after the passing of the Coronavirus pandemic, the more successful the recovery will be on the other side.

The Government understands that the economic and financial impacts of Coronavirus will extend well beyond those receiving direct assistance under its Economic Response to Coronavirus package. This event will affect all Australians, to varying degrees.

While there may be businesses that may not be eligible for direct assistance on this occasion, the announced measures are expected to benefit all Australians, now and over the long-term, by supporting overall confidence, employment and business continuity.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar (Petition No. EN1464)
Foreign Investment
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition Ministerial Referral (EN1466) - Protect Australian owned assets and entities. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Foreign investment provides significant benefits to Australia. It contributes to the prosperity of businesses, communities and the overall economy. At the same time, the Australian Government recognises that foreign investments must be in the national interest. Australia's foreign investment framework strikes a balance between ensuring we remain an attractive investment destination and upholding the national interest. If it is determined that a proposal is contrary to the national interest, it will not be approved or conditions will be applied to safeguard the national interest.

On 5 June 2020 the Treasurer announced comprehensive reforms to the foreign investment review framework. These reforms update the framework in three broad ways: they address national security risks; strengthen the existing system, particularly as it relates to compliance by foreign investors; and streamline investment in non-sensitive businesses. The reforms are intended to commence on 1 January 2021.

In the meantime, the temporary changes to the framework that the Treasurer announced on 29 March 2020 will remain in place for the duration of the coronavirus crisis. Under these changes, all proposed foreign investments into Australia subject to the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 require foreign investment approval.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar (Petition No. EN1466)
COVID-19: Employment
Dear Chair

I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1469 asking the Australian Government to implement a range of measures that would support businesses to get back to work safely in a COVID-19 environment.

The Government has taken a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest and best medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee. Through the adoption and observance of restrictions, including physical distancing, Australia has so far been successful in 'flattening the curve'. We are now gradually removing restrictions, following a three-step plan agreed by National Cabinet.

This plan includes a number of the strategies suggested by the petitioner to support hotels, restaurants and bars as they get back to business in a COVID-safe environment and return the economy to a more sustainable level. A roadmap outlining each step and information for specific industries can be found in the media update of 8 May 2020 at: www.pm.gov.au.

Safe Work Australia has developed new guidance and resources to help workplaces stay safe and manage the risks from COVID-19. This includes information for over 30 different industries on key topics such as duties under WHS laws, risk assessments, physical distancing, cleaning and hygiene. Guidelines for the hospitality sector include advice on when it is appropriate to use masks and other protective equipment. Current guidelines and a small business planning tool can be found at: www.safeworkaustralia.gov.au.

Individual states and territories are moving between steps on the pathway at different times, in line with their current public health situation and local conditions. The National Cabinet is reviewing progress regularly to assess the impact of changes, track progress against agreed conditions, and make any further decisions.

I acknowledge this has been a difficult time for businesses and their staff and I appreciate the petitioner's commitment to new processes to ensure the safety of customers and staff. Our shared goal is to have a sustainable COVID-safe Australia in July 2020. As long as we all keep living and working in a COVID-safe way, we can keep case numbers low and continue taking steps to relax restrictions in the coming weeks.

Further information can be found at: www.australia.gov.au which has the latest COVID-19 news, updates and advice from Government agencies across Australia as well as links to state and territory government websites.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1469)
Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1470.

As you're aware, the Australian Government supports immunisation in recognition that it is a safe way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

The Government's policies on immunisation are based on advice from independent expert clinical advisory groups - the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. Vaccines are only made available in Australia after they have been rigorously tested, evaluated and approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) to ensure they meet stringent safety and efficacy guidelines. Vaccines continue to be tested after their introduction via additional clinical trials, surveillance and monitoring of vaccine adverse events.

Vaccines, like any other medicines can have side effects, however all vaccines used within Australia provide benefits which greatly outweigh their risks. A number of organisations including the Australian Academy of Science, an independent scientific body, have found that vaccinating against diseases is safer and more effective than being infected with those diseases. Those who have provided this petition may be interested in 'The Science of Immunisation: Questions and Answers', produced by the Academy of Science available at: www.science.org.au.

The Government has also invested in AusVaxSafety, the national, monitoring and surveillance system which actively monitors vaccine safety throughout Australia. Current results are available on their website at: www.ausvaxsafety.org.au. Parents/carers and immunisation providers can also report adverse events to the TGA via the Adverse Event Management System at: www.tga.gov.au.
While the Government supports immunisation, it is not compulsory, and people maintain the right to choose whether to vaccinate themselves and their family.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1470)
COVID-19: Taxation
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1471—tax deductions for meals purchased whilst working from home. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Australian Government is aware that the public health measures taken in response to COVID-19 have raised considerable challenges for the hospitality industry. However, it is of the view that the revenue streams of these businesses are likely to naturally increase as public health measures are relaxed. Because of this, the Government has been focussed on offering direct assistance to businesses as they seek to manage temporary cash-flow shocks.

For example, the Government is providing tax-free cash flow boosts of between $20,000 and $100,000 to eligible small and medium businesses (SMEs) and non-profits. It is also, under the Coronavirus SME Guarantee Scheme, offering a guarantee of 50 per cent to SME lenders to support new unsecured loans. Both of these policies will help give SMEs - including those in the hospitality industry - access to the liquidity they need to keep operating until their revenue streams recover. To date, approximately 14,000 loans worth $1.4 billion have been accepted by borrowers under the scheme.

In regards to goods and services tax relief, the Australian Taxation Office has announced a number of measures to assist businesses through the Commissioner's general powers of administration. Further information can be found at: www.ato.gov.au/General/COVID-19/Additional-support-during-COVID-19
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar (Petition No. EN1471)
COVID-19
Dear Chair

I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 on a petition before the Standing Committee on Petitions, number EN1474, which requests removal of current English language proficiency requirements for those seeking registration with the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (Board).

I can advise that under the National Registration and Accreditation Scheme (Scheme), the Board regulates the practice of nursing and midwifery in Australia, and is supported in this role by the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency (Ahpra). While the Ministerial Council provides some oversight of the Scheme, the Government cannot intervene in their operation or decision making. One of the Board's key duties is to protect the public. It does this by developing registration standards, professional codes, guidelines and standards for practice which establish the requirements for the professional and safe practice of nurses and midwives.

Under the legislation that underpins the Scheme, all National Boards must set English language standards, and have no legal ability to remove or change these requirements. The Board's English language skills registration standard establishes a nurse or midwife's requirement for English language proficiency.

While I acknowledge the frustration of petition signatories in having to meeting the Board's English requirements, they are in place to address community expectations that nurses are able to communicate effectively to provide safe practice. Further information on the Board's English language requirements can be found at: www.nursingmidwiferyboard.gov.au/Registration-Standards/English-language-skills.aspx.

The Board is aware that some practitioners may have difficulty sitting English language tests during COVID-19 disruptions, and understands that this may cause some stress for registration applicants. Applicants are being encouraged to consult their test providers who are regularly updating their information about test availability as restrictions ease.

Nursing applicants who are having difficulty meeting the Board's registration requirements can also speak with their assigned Ahpra registration officer to clarify how they can meet these requirements. Alternatively, they can contact the Board directly via email at: nmbafeedback@ahpra.gov.au, to outline any concerns about the Board's English standard requirements as they relate to their individual situation.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1474)
Charitable Organisations
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 15 June 2020 concerning Petition EN1475—Charities' disbursement of donations, specifically relating to charity relief and recovery efforts as a result of the 2019-20 bushfire season.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that all donations from the public are used appropriately, including where donated for that purpose, to support bushfire relief and recovery activities.

The Government regulates all charities through the Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission (ACNC). Registered charities are required to comply with a set of governance standards that ensure assets and income, including donations, are used only for their charitable purpose. The ACNC also requires charities to submit financial reports and an annual information statement on their activities. The ACNC makes this information on charities publicly available on its charity register at www.acnc.gov.au/charity. The ACNC also provides guidance for the public on how to ensure donations are going to a reputable entity and will be spent for the purpose for which they are given.

Charities must also not mislead the public as to how their donations are used. If charities make false or misleading statements about their fundraising arrangements, they may contravene Australian Consumer Law. This is a breach of the ACNC Governance Standards and the ACNC takes these matters seriously.

Charities engaged in bushfire relief and recovery activities are continuing to work hard to ensure donations flow through to those in need, while also now being engaged in efforts to support those members of the Australian community that have been impacted by the corona virus pandemic.

The experience of many charities during the Black Saturday bushfires was that long-term community support was needed to rebuild. Similarly, recovery from the recent summer bushfires will require sustained support from the charity sector over the longer-term and into the future. The ACNC is working with these charities to ensure they continue to meet their reporting obligations, and that funds donated are used appropriately.

I note the petition's request for the House to investigate charities involved in relief and recovery efforts, particularly to ensure that 100 per cent of donations go towards victims. Charities involved in bushfire assistance have proactively published information on their websites indicating exactly where the funds will be used. This publicly available information greatly assists all donors to understand how their donations are spent.

While charities should be striving to maximise funds available for achieving their charitable purpose, it is important to note that this will include expenditure on running the charity in order to deliver services. Administration costs in and of themselves do not indicate how effective a charity is in achieving its purpose and must be considered alongside a range of factors. However, if there is evidence that administration costs or salaries are unreasonably high it is the role of the ACNC, as an independent regulator, to look into the operations to establish that the charity is operating in accordance with the ACNC Governance Standards.
On 29 January 2020, the ACNC Commissioner publicly indicated that he will be conducting audits of charities specifically related to bushfire activities within the next twelve months.

I trust this information addresses the concerns of the petitioners, and demonstrates the degree of regulatory and government oversight that currently already exists, not only for charities involved in bushfire recovery efforts, but for all charities.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Finance, Charities and Electoral Matters, Senator Seselja (Petition No. EN1475)
COVID-19
Dear Chair

I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1481 asking the Australian Government to define the objectives and the measures of success of the COVID-19 response and the criteria for lifting restrictions.

The Government has taken a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID.,19, based on the latest and best medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and guided by the Australian Health Sector Emergency Response Plan for COVID-,19, which is available on my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au. My Department undertakes continuous work around future planning to inform the national strategy for the management ofCOVID-19. Among those things considered in future planning are domestic and international epidemiology (including epidemiological forecasting), available scientific evidence, health care system capacity, social and economic factors, and community response to public health measures.

On 8 May 2020, the National Cabinet agreed a three-step framework (framework) to gradually remove restrictions to prepare Australians to go back to work in a COVID-19 safe environment and get the economy back to a more sustainable level. This framework is available at: www.health.gov.au using the search term '3-step framework'. The framework provides a pathway for states and territories to move towards COVID-safe communities at a pace that best suits their individual circumstances.

The Pandemic Health Intelligence Plan (Plan) provides a framework for collecting the information required to support decision making about COVID-19. The Plan includes elements such as an epidemiological disease surveillance plan, modelling inputs to planning, and measures of health system, testing and public health capacity. It is supported by documents detailing the status of measures against relevant thresholds. Further information about the Plan is available at: www.health.gov.au using the search term 'Pandemic Health Intelligence Plan'.
We must remain vigilant to prevent a 'second wave' of infection as public health-related restrictions are relaxed and as necessary respond quickly to any local outbreaks.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1481)
Organic Food
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1485. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Australian Government recognises that people choose to consume organic foods for many reasons including environmental benefits, the reduced use of chemicals and a taste preference. The Australian Dietary Guidelines (Guidelines) provide evidence-based advice on the types and amounts of foods that Australians should eat for good health and the prevention of chronic conditions. The Guidelines do not specifically recommend eating organic foods, as both organic and conventionally grown foods provide the required amounts of nutrients for a healthy balanced diet. There is no consistent evidence that organic foods have a significant health benefit over conventionally farmed foods.

Australia also has a world-class food safety and food regulation system. Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) protect the health and safety of the people in Australia and New Zealand by maintaining a safe food supply. FSANZ is a bi-national independent statutory authority which develops food standards for composition, labelling and contaminants, including microbiological limits. These standards apply to all foods produced or imported for sale in Australia and New Zealand.

Many organic businesses choose to be certified by an organic certification body to underpin truth in labelling requirements, promote consumer confidence and ensure they are export-ready. The organic standards used in Australia are generally owned and managed by private certification bodies. These bodies certify to a minimum of the National Standard for Organic and Biodynamic Produce Edition 3.7 September 2016 (the organic standard) which is owned by the Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment.

As of 2018, there were 4,802 third party certified organic operators in Australia that have been certified to Australian Government standards to export organic products (figures from the Australian Organic Market Report 2019). There is no mandatory requirement for certification of organic product sold domestically in Australia, and these figures may not include all organic enterprises.

Through these frameworks, the Government is supporting consumers and producers to make informed decisions about the foods they eat or produce, and is not inclined to provide preferential treatment for one form of production as suggested by the petition. Even if the Government wanted to support a specific form of food production, providing producers with access to a highly concessional tax regime is rarely the most effective way to support an industry.

The Government has an ongoing responsibility to balance both the generosity and the sustainability of concessions in the tax system. Ensuring that tax is applied to a broad base contributes to this aim and reduces distortions to the tax system.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar (Petition No. EN1485)
Space Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 15 June 2020, where you referred to me the petition EN1489 presented to the House of Representatives. I would like to assure you that the Government is committed to the responsible use of outer space.

Participating in the global space sector will create jobs for the future and improve many aspects of our lives. This includes for farming, disaster management, modern communications and online transactions. Earth observation, which includes using satellites to monitor, predict and manage the environment can involve mapping changes in Antarctic sea ice, monitoring pollution and oil spills, forecasting the weather, and managing bushfires. The Australian Government's Advancing Space: Australian Civil Space Strategy 2019-2028 (the Strategy), sets the path for responsibly growing the space sector to improve the lives of Australians.

The Space (Launches and Returns) Act 2018 sets a framework to ensure the appropriate consideration of the environment when accessing space. For example, environmental approvals are required and, for assets in space, companies need to detail how they will appropriately manage space debris. The Australian Government supports the long-term sustainability of outer space activities through the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space.

Australia ratified the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer (the Montreal Protocol) in 1989, which is an international agreement made in 1987 to help protect the ozone layer. The latest scientific assessment for the Montreal Protocol specifies that rocket launches have a small effect—much less than 0.1 per cent—on total stratospheric ozone1.

Proactive efforts are nevertheless being made in Australia and internationally to reduce possible environmental impacts of rocket emissions. This includes industry-led development of new engines and rocket fuels that are more environmentally friendly and efficient.

We are also actively sharing space assets among nations. For example, Australia has a ten per cent share of time to use the advanced Earth-imaging satellite NovaSAR-1, allowing researchers to monitor environmental challenges and map land use across the country.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Mrs Andrews (Petition No. EN1489)
COVID-19
Dear Chair

I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1494 asking the Australian Government to assess the viability of quarantining large population centres to enable easing of restrictions in lower risk areas. I note that Australia's situation concerning the pandemic has changed substantially since the petition was initiated.

The Government took a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest and best medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee. The measures taken have successfully contained the spread of COVID-19 in the community and placed Australia in a good position globally.

Our response to COVID-19 places a high priority on supporting rural and regional communities and there has been differences in how this pandemic has spread between states and territories. National Cabinet agreed to a three-step plan (the plan) on 8 May 2020 to gradually remove baseline restrictions that takes into account and allows for localised responses to any outbreaks. A roadmap outlining each step of the plan can be found in the media update of 8 May 2020 available at: www.pm.gov.au. National Cabinet will regularly review and assess our progress so we can continue to move forward safely.

Under the plan, states and territories may move through steps at different speeds. Local circumstances may prompt states and territories to introduce additional measures for a period to further control community transmission. These local decisions are based on the advice of the state Chief Health Officer, informed by local epidemiology at the time.

Our success in keeping our communities safe as restrictions ease depends on all of us continuing to practice physical distancing. We need to stay home when unwell and make enhanced hygiene part of our daily lives. When Australians leave home in any region, they will need to think about how to keep themselves, their family and their local communities safe.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1494)
COVID-19: Health Care
Dear Chair

I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1502 requesting the Australian Government approve access to Chinese Medicines (CM) through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) for the treatment of COVID-19.

Under the National Health Act 1953 (Act), a new medicine cannot be listed on the PBS unless the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC)—an independent, expert advisory body—makes a recommendation in favour of listing.

The PBAC's consideration is generally initiated by the pharmaceutical company responsible for a medicine (sponsor) making an application for the medicine to be considered for PBS listing. It is usually the pharmaceutical company that holds the scientific data and other information necessary to inform the PBAC's consideration.

Medicines are not generally made available on the PBS to treat conditions for which they have not been approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA). The PBS listing process relies in part on the scientific assessment of evidence regarding safety and clinical effectiveness that serves as the basis for TGA approval.
Sponsors of CM that are interested in pursuing a PBS listing must first make an application to the TGA for registration (if they haven't already), followed by a submission to the PBAC.

It is also important to note that CM practitioners are not approved to prescribe pharmaceutical benefits under the Act. Patients must obtain a valid PBS prescription from an approved prescriber (doctor, dentist, optometrist, midwife or nurse practitioner) to obtain a medicine through the PBS.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1502)
Vaccination
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020 to the Minister for Health, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, concerning petition number EN1505 requesting the Australian Government revoke the requirement for people to receive an influenza vaccination to visit residential aged care facilities. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians with portfolio responsibility for this matter.

The Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) has made a number of recommendations in relation to COVID-19 and residential aged care facilities on 17 March 2020, 21 April 2020 and most recently 19 June 2020. The AHPPC recommended a number of restrictions be placed on entry into and visitors to residential aged care facilities to protect vulnerable older people in residential aged care. These recommendations were endorsed by the National Cabinet.

The measures recommended by the AHPPC recognised that COVID-19 is a significant health risk particularly for the elderly and individuals with co-morbidities or low immunity. The measures also recognise that avoidance of exposure is the single most important measure for preventing COVID-19 in residential aged care facilities. The recommendations from AHPPC and decisions of the National Cabinet are applied and operationalised by state and territory governments through directions under their emergency management provisions. States and territories have released directions that set out requirements with regard to visitors to and entry into residential aged care facilities.

The state and territory directions set out that individuals must not enter or remain on the premises of a residential aged care facility if the person does not meet certain requirements. This includes a requirement in relation to influenza vaccination, consistent with the recommendations from the AHPPC.

The entry restrictions generally apply to most individuals entering a residential aged care facility, including staff, visitors, health practitioners, volunteers and others. It is important to note that while states and territories have established entry restrictions to residential aged care facilities for individuals that do not meet certain vaccination requirements, immunisation is not compulsory and people maintain the right to choose whether to receive an influenza vaccination.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians, Senator Colbeck (Petition No. EN1505)
All-Terrain Vehicles
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition Ministerial Referral (EN1506)- a request to repeal the mandatory requirement for Operator Protection Devices (OPD) on ATVs. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

I note the concerns raised regarding the consultation process for, and the availability of quad bikes following, the introduction of the Consumer Goods (Quad Bikes) Safety Standard 2019 (the Standard).

The Standard is the result of a comprehensive investigation by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) focused on increasing quad bike safety and extensive consultation with both industry and government stakeholders. These stakeholders included major quad bike manufacturers and their Australian and US representative bodies, Australian quad bike importers, academics, farming groups, health, medical and legal sectors, individual consumers and famers, researchers, OPD manufacturers and local and international government agencies with an interest in quad bike safety.

I recognise that some major manufacturers have stated they will cease supply of quad bikes in the Australian market once the Standard comes into effect. While I appreciate their decision to exit the market will have an impact on Australian businesses, the Australian Government is committed to ensuring that Australian consumers have access to safe quad bikes.
A number of quad bike suppliers have indicated that they are committed to the Australian market and are making the necessary arrangements to get ready to comply with the Standard.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar (Petition No. EN1506)
COVID-19: Health Care
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020 originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1509 to introduce a hazard allowance and tax holiday for healthcare workers, particularly for pharmacists and pharmacy workers. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Australian Government has acted decisively to support households and businesses and address the significant economic consequences of the Coronavirus. The Government's economic support package provides timely support to workers, households and businesses through a difficult time and has positioned the Australian economy to recover strongly.

A total of $259 billion is being injected into the economy to keep Australians in work and businesses in business. The package is designed to support businesses across all sectors to retain jobs and manage short-term cash flow challenges, provide support to individuals, severely affected communities and regions, and to ensure the continued flow of credit in the Australian economy.

Community pharmacies have played a central role in supporting their community during the recent bushfires and have kept their doors open to support patients during the COVID-19 pandemic. In June 2020, the Government finalised the Seventh Community Pharmacy Agreement (7CPA), which is expected to provide $18.3 billion over five years and ensure Australians have access to more than 200 million subsidised prescriptions each year through their community pharmacy of choice.

The 7CPA demonstrates the Government's ongoing support for patients and community pharmacy. It also acknowledges that Australia's community pharmacies will continue to be crucial to the Government's efforts to improve the health of all Australians.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar (Petition No. EN1509)
COVID-19: Pensions and Benefits
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN1510 relating to support payments for self-funded retirees. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I have responsibility for this matter.

The Morrison Government recognises the valuable contribution self-funded retirees make to Australia's economy and the steps they have taken during their working lives to provide for their retirement. We salute their thrift and personal responsibility.

We also appreciate the impact that volatility in financial markets is having on the retirement savings of retirees. In recognition of the economic impacts of the Coronavirus, and to provide retirees with more flexibility on how they manage their superannuation assets, the Government is temporarily reducing the minimum drawdown requirements by 50 per cent for the 2019-20 and 2020-21 income years. This will reduce the need to sell assets that may be in a loss position.

It is important to note that superannuation balances are expected to be drawn down and spent in the retirement phase and the superannuation system is designed in the full expectation that tax-free pension balances will reduce over time. This is a deliberate design feature to ensure superannuation is being used for its core purpose of providing a nest egg to spend during retirement.

As superannuation balances decline over the course of retirement, the generous social security safety net available to all Australians will kick in. At a certain point this will begin providing a part pension, scaling up as superannuation balances are drawn down. A part Aged Pension begins to be available once assets drop below $869,500 for a combined home owner, or $578,250 for a single home owner.

Further, self-funded retirees who temporarily find themselves in an 'asset rich, cash(flow) poor' position may also be interested to explore the flexibility provided by the Pension Loans Scheme. This provides access to a fortnightly tax-free income stream of up to 150 percent of the full amount of the Aged Pension to supplement their retirement income, via a Government-backed voluntary reverse equity mortgage.

The Government has widened Scheme eligibility to now include those who have too many assets to qualify for the Aged Pension. Payments may be made for a short period of time while an individual's income and assets are being rearranged, or may be made for an indefinite period. For details, see: www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/services/centrelink/pension-loans-scheme.

Finally, I note that the Morrison Government, as part of its Economic Response to Coronavirus Package, is providing two separate $750 payments to social security, veteran and other income support recipients and eligible concession card holders. This includes holders of Commonwealth Seniors Health Card, which is available to self-funded retirees of Age Pension age who do not receive the Age Pension, but meet a higher income test.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and Financial Technology, Senator Hume (Petition No. EN1510)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Dear Chair

I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1514 asking the Australian Government to revoke the emergency measures instituted on 18 March 2020 under the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Act).

The Government has taken a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the medical advice provided by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and the Communicable Diseases Network Australia.

COVID-19 represents a severe and immediate threat to human health in Australia and has the ability to cause high levels of morbidity and mortality. COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease that has entered Australian territory and can be fatal. COVID-19 would have spread quickly if control measures were not in place. Australia's case fatality rate has been low (1.4 per cent), but this is still significantly higher than the estimated rate for seasonal influenza which is usually below 0.1 per cent. There is no vaccine or antiviral medicine that can be used to prevent transmission or treat the disease.

The relatively low number of COVID-19 cases in Australia is the result of our swift and successful implementation of public health measures. Early forecasts, based on the AHPPC's observations of the international experience and modelling of domestic outbreak scenarios, indicated a worst case scenario should no public health measures be implemented.

Despite our actions, we have had more than 7,400 cases and sadly 104 deaths (as at 26 June 2020). It is now evident that those countries where public health measures were either not implemented at all, or were implemented later in the pandemic, have experienced very high case numbers and mortality, which is in stark contrast to Australia's current epidemiology.

On 18 March 2020, the Governor-General declared under the Act that a human biosecurity emergency exists regarding the listed human disease 'human coronavirus with pandemic potential'. The Governor-General's declaration and the emergency requirements that I have determined under the Act have been necessary and appropriate to prevent or control the entry, emergence, establishment and/or spread of COVID-19 in Australia. The Government has acted and continues to act with appropriate urgency and immediacy to protect the human health and life of Australians during the COVID-19 pandemic.

I acknowledge that our public health actions have come at an economic and social cost, affecting businesses and individuals. However, these costs sit against the potential costs, individual and economic, associated with widespread disease - in terms of lives lost, an overwhelmed healthcare system, and a loss of consumer confidence if governments had not acted.

Australia's Pandemic Health Intelligence Plan establishes precedent conditions to guide adjustments of public health measures. On 8 May 2020, the National Cabinet agreed a three-step plan to gradually remove restrictions to allow Australians to return to work in a COVID-19 safe environment and get the economy back to a more sustainable level.

As announced by the Prime Minister on 26 June 2020, through the National Cabinet, states and territories are continuing to move towards COVID-safe communities in ways that best suit their particular circumstances, reflecting the fact that each jurisdiction is at different stages of the pandemic response.
Thank you for writing on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1514)
COVID-19
Dear Chair

1 refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1515 asking the Australian Government to review the response to the COVID-19 pandemic, including containment measures, our relationship with international bodies and our approach to vaccination.

The Government has taken a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on medical advice provided by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and the Communicable Diseases Network Australia.

The Government is fully committed to keeping Australians as safe and well as possible during this pandemic. The public health measures implemented have resulted in a relatively low number of COVID-19 cases in Australia. It is now evident that those countries where public health measures were either not implemented at all, or were implemented later in the pandemic have experienced very high case numbers and mortality, which is in stark contrast to Australia's current epidemiology.

On 18 March 2020, the Governor-General declared under the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Act) that a human biosecurity emergency exists regarding the listed human disease 'human coronavirus with pandemic potential'. The Governor-General's declaration and other emergency requirements that I have determined under the Act have been necessary and appropriate to prevent or control the entry, emergence, establishment and/or spread of COVID-19 in Australia. The Government has acted and continues to act with appropriate urgency and immediacy to protect the human health and life of Australians during the COVID-19 pandemic.

State and territory governments have responded to the pandemic based on medical advice from their Chief Health Officers. A range of emergency measures has been enacted to manage COVID-19 in each jurisdiction.

Australia's recent multilateral audit found the United Nations (UN) delivers outcomes vital for Australia's national interests. The UN underpins global rules and norms, facilitates international cooperation in key sectors for Australia's economy, promotes universal values such as human rights, and plays critical a role in responding to emerging global challenges, as we have seen recently with the recent COVID-19 pandemic and the role of the World Health Organization (WHO). The WHO has played a central role in supporting COVID-19 preparedness in our region and the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, has acknowledged the WHO's important work in the Pacific.

As COVID-19 has demonstrated, now more than ever, it is critical that the UN and international standard setting bodies are fit-for-purpose and accountable to member states. Notwithstanding the limitations of the UN and other international institutions identified in the multilateral audit, Australia's interests are not served by stepping away and leaving others to shape global order. Australia will continue to play an active role in influencing and shaping global institutions and their efforts to address global challenges, including pursuing reform of global bodies, where required. Australia made a principled call for an independent evaluation of the COVID-19 outbreak and WHO's response to ensure we can act on lessons learned in the wake of the unprecedented economic and social costs of this pandemic. We will continue to work closely with the international community to take this forward.

As the leading authority for health within the LIN the WHO is the cornerstone of an effective rules-based international collaborative effort for health. The WHO is crucial to coordinating the global response to the pandemic, and the Government does not plan end its engagement with this important global health organisation.

The Government supports immunisation in recognition that it is a safe way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death. However, immunisation is not compulsory and people maintain the right to choose whether or not to be immunised.

A vaccine for COVID-19 is not currently available. If and when a vaccine becomes available, it will be rigorously tested, evaluated and approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration to ensure it meets stringent safety and efficacy guidelines. Vaccines continue to be tested after their introduction via additional clinical trials, surveillance and monitoring of vaccine adverse events.

Australia has been highly successful so far in 'flattening the curve'. Australian governments are now taking a measured approach, implementing a three-step plan that gradually removes restrictions to allow work and social activities to resume in a COVID-safe environment. States and territories are moving towards COVID-safe communities in a way that best suits their individual circumstances, reflecting the fact that they are at different stages of the pandemic response.
Thank you for writing on this- matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1515)
Family Law
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 15 June 2020 enclosing Petition Ministerial Referral EN1518, concerning family law property division.

The petition suggests the adoption of prope1ty settlement rules, including the use of prenuptial conventions, such as those from Roman Law countries. The petition states this would bring equality and responsibility into couples' financial affairs.

The Family Law Act 1975 provides the legal framework for resolving arrangements for prope1ty following a relationship breakdown. As far as is practicable and fair, the Act provides for the financial relationship between separated couples to be brought to an end, bringing certainty for the parties in the future. The court may make an order altering the property interests of the parties, including splitting their superannuation interests, when it is satisfied that in all the circumstances it is just and equitable to do so. The court takes into consideration the contributions that each party has made to the relationship (including financial and non-financial contributions) and the future needs of each party (including whether they have care of any children).

The Family Law Act also provides for couples to make a binding financial agreement about how their property will be dealt with in the event the relationship comes to an end. A financial agreement can be made before, during or after the relationship. It can also include an agreement about splitting the parties' superannuation interests. A financial agreement ousts the jurisdiction of the court to make orders about property that is dealt with in the agreement. The Act also provides for parties to make an agreement about paying spousal maintenance.

The Australian Government is committed to ongoing improvements to the family law, courts and ·legal assistance systems to ensure they help families separate in a safe, child-centred, accessible and timely way. That is why the Government has established a Joint Select Committee to inquire into the family law system.

For those going through the family law system, it is imp011ant that the systems they have to go through work as best as they can. The terms of reference for the inquiry are broad, and allow for the examination of a range of matters that have a real and practical impact on Australian families, including the potential use of pre-nuptial agreements and their enforceability to minimise future prope11y disputes. The Committee is scheduled to rep011 by 7 October 2020.

The Government is also carefully considering the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission's review of the family law system, which are largely focused on the legislation governing family law, including the prope11y decision-making framework.
Thank you again for bringing the petitioners' concerns to the Government's attention.·
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter (Petition No. EN1518)
Vaccination
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1528 asking the Australian Government to remove all federal directives mandating influenza vaccination in order to visit aged care facilities.
The Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) has made a number of recommendations in relation to COVID-19 and residential aged care facilities on

17 March 2020, 21 April 2020 and most recently 19 June 2020. The AHPPC recommended a number of restrictions be placed on entry into and visitors to residential aged care facilities to protect vulnerable older people in residential aged care. These recommendations were endorsed by the National Cabinet.

The measures recommended by the AHPPC recognised that COVID-19 is a significant health risk particularly for the elderly and individuals with co-morbidities or low immunity. The measures also recognise that avoidance of exposure is the single most important measure for preventing COVID-19 in residential aged care facilities.

The recommendations from AHPPC and decisions of the National Cabinet are applied and operationalised by state and territory governments through directions under their emergency management provisions. States and territories have released directions that set out requirements with regard to visitors to and entry into residential aged care facilities.

The state and territory directions set out that individuals must not enter or remain on the premises of a residential aged care facility if the person does not meet certain requirements. This includes a requirement in relation to influenza vaccination, consistent with the recommendations from the AHPPC.

The Government is a strong supporter of immunisation in that it is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of vaccine preventable diseases, including seasonal influenza. Annual vaccination is the most important measure to prevent influenza and its complications. It is recommended for all people aged six months and over (unless contraindicated).

Vaccines are only made available in Australia and included on the National Immunisation Program after they have been rigorously tested, evaluated and approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) to ensure they meet stringent safety and efficacy guidelines.

Vaccines continue to be tested after their introduction via additional clinical trials, surveillance and monitoring of vaccine adverse events. Vaccines, like any other medicines can have side effects, however all ,vaccines used within Australia provide benefits which greatly outweigh their risks.

A number of organisations including the Australian Academy of Science, an independent scientific body, have found that vaccinating against diseases is safer and more effective than being infected with those diseases. You may be interested in The Science of Immunisation: Questions and Answers available at: www.science.org.au/education/immunisation-climate-change-genetic-modification/science-immunisation. This information is produced by the Academy of Science.

AusVaxSafety actively monitors vaccine safety throughout Australia and current results are available at: www.ausvaxsafety.org.au/safety-data. Parents/carers and immunisation providers can also report adverse events to the TGA via the Adverse Event Management System at: www.tga.gov.au/reporting-adverse-events.

The Government's policies on immunisation are based on advice from independent expert clinical advisory groups - the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Aged Care and Senior Australians, Senator Colbeck (Petition No. EN1528
COVID-19
Dear Chair

I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1530 asking the Australian Government to lift all COVID-19 related restrictions on businesses and individuals in Australia. I note that Australia's situation concerning the pandemic has changed substantially since the petition was initiated.

The Government took a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest and best medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee. The measures taken have successfully contained the spread of COVID-19 in the community and placed Australia in an enviable place globally.

The Government is fully committed to keeping Australians as safe and well as possible during this pandemic. I appreciate this has been a difficult time for many. We sought to balance health and economic objectives, keeping the economy open and supporting the livelihoods of Australians through individual and business support measures. Our uniquely Australian approach has been highly successful in 'flattening the curve'.

We are now following a three-step plan, agreed by National Cabinet, to gradually remove restrictions to prepare Australians to go back to work in a COVID-19 safe environment and get the economy back to a more sustainable level. A roadmap outlining each step can be found at: www.health.gov.au/resources/publications/3-step-framework-for-a-covidsafe-australia.
The three-step plan provides a pathway for states and territories to move towards

COVID-safe communities at a pace that best suits their individual circumstances. Governments are regularly reviewing the impact of changes to determine the pace at which restrictions are relaxed and to enable a prompt response to any resurgence.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1530)
Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your letter of 15 June 2020 concerning petition number EN1531, asking the Australian Government to investigate influenza vaccination for the maintenance of employment.

As you are aware, the Government is a strong supporter of immunisation in that it is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of vaccine preventable diseases, including seasonal influenza. Annual vaccination is the most important measure to prevent influenza and its complications. Childcare and Aged Care workers are being urged to get their influenza vaccination now ahead of the season in a bid to protect themselves and the people they care for. However, immunisation is not compulsory and people maintain the right to choose whether to receive an influenza vaccination. It is recommended that employees discuss specific vaccination requirements with their employer. Should an employee need to determine the legitimacy of an employer's requirement to be vaccinated to maintain their employment, the employee may choose to obtain legal advice at their own expense.

This year it is even more important to be vigilant about influenza because of the COVID-19 pandemic. We do not yet have a vaccine for COVID-19, but we do have vaccines to protect against influenza. While vaccinating against influenza will not prevent or protect against COVID-19, it will help to reduce the severity and spread of influenza, which can lower a person's immunity making them susceptible to other illnesses; and demand on the healthcare system, in particular hospitals, in the peak influenza transmission period typically from June to September in Australia.

Vaccines, like any other medicines can have side effects, however all vaccines used within Australia provide benefits which greatly outweigh their risks. Vaccines are only made available in Australia after they have been rigorously tested, evaluated and approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) to ensure they meet stringent safety and efficacy guidelines. Vaccines continue to be tested after their introduction via additional clinical trials, surveillance and monitoring of vaccine adverse events.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN1531)
Tourism
Dear Mr O'Brien

Thank you for your email of 11 February 2020 enclosing Petition PN0453 concerning funding for the transition of state forests near Lithgow to a state conservation area reserve to strengthen Lithgow's tourism economy.

Tourism is important to the Australian economy, it is a $152 billion industry that directly employs over 660,000 Australians, or 5.2 per cent of the Australian workforce. It is our largest service export industry, contributing $39. l billion to the Australian economy, an 8.2 per cent share of all goods and services exports. The benefits of tourism are spread across the country, with 44 cents in every tourism dollar being spent in regional Australia. According to Tourism Research Australia's National Visitor Survey, in the year ending September 2019, 45 million overnight visitors participated in outdoor and nature activities during their travels.

Since the time of your email, Australia has been struck by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Australian Government's priority since the emergence of the pandemic has been to protect the health of all Australians. Measures put in place to suppress the virus, such as travel restrictions, social distancing and limits on social gatherings, have largely been successful in flattening the curve and slowing the growth of cases in Australia. The task now is to ensure Australians can return to work in a COVID-safe workplace.

The National Cabinet, including state and territory governments, outlined a three-step plan on 8 May to get Australians back to work in a COVID safe economy. The plan includes a graduated lifting of restrictions and state and territory governments will move through these steps at different times depending on local conditions. The National Cabinet will review the steps every three weeks. It is our aspiration that in July we will have moved through these three steps.

The global response to the health crisis has had devastating impacts on the Australian and global economies. That is why the Government has implemented an unprecedented package of economic support and relief including JobKeeper and JobSeeker payments. A core feature of the Government's economic package is the provision of a $1 billion Relief and Recovery Fund to support those sectors, regions and communities that have been disproportionately affected by the economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, including those heavily reliant on industries such as tourism. Our business.gov.au and treasury.gov.au/coronavirus websites provide further details of support available.

In partnership with industry and state and territory governments, we are now determining what the post-COVID economy is going to look like globally and domestically. We are determined to make sure that we use Australia's advantages in areas like tourism and our export sector to come out of this crisis strongly.

We will implement targeted measures to promote tourism when it is appropriate to do so. When we can relax some travel restrictions within Australia, we will strongly encourage those who can afford to do so to support tourism regions that are struggling because of the loss of business through the current crisis. This will include visits to State forests. We are also conscious of the need to continue to assist those regions affected by the summer bushfires as well.

State forests are the responsibility of the New South Wales Government. NSW forests are made up of public and privately owned plantation and natural forests that are managed for economic, social and environmental benefits, and cultural heritage values. The NSW Department of Primary Industries leads forest policy and research.

Australia has a long-standing reputation as a popular, safe, and welcoming holiday destination. The Government's plan of responding to the health and economic impacts of COVID-19 is about ensuring that as global demand recovers and travel restrictions ease, Australian tourism businesses can capture a recovering global tourism market.
Our tourism industry is incredibly resilient and has bounced back in the past from other crises. I have no doubt that will be the case again, even in these unprecedented times.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment, Senator Birmingham (Petition No. PN0453)
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for correspondence concerning Petition PN0457 originally directed by the previous Chair, Mr Llew O'Brien MP to the Treasurer. The Treasurer has asked me to respond to you.

The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) has an important role supervising prudentially-regulated banking, insurance and superannuation entities and promoting financial system stability in Australia. In 2019, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) released a comprehensive review of Australia's financial system as part of its Financial Sector Assessment Program. Overall, the IMF noted that Australian authorities - including APRA - have taken positive steps in recent years to strengthen the financial system.

The Government has no plans to introduce Glass-Steagall legislation in Australia. Glass-Steagall legislation was introduced in the United States following the Great Depression and legally ensured the separation of retail and investment banking, with the intent of reducing risk of failure in the US banking sector. This is much less relevant in the context of Australian banks business models and market structure. In addition, depositors' claims are explicitly protected by the Banking Act 1959. In the unlikely event of a bank failure, depositors have priority claim on the assets of a failed authorised deposit-taking institution (ADI) ahead of other unsecured creditors. Depositors are also protected by the Financial Claims Scheme, which guarantees deposits up to a cap of $250,000 per person, per ADI.
The Morrison Government has no plans to establish a national bank. I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Superannuation, Financial Services and Financial Technology, Senator Hume (Petition No. PN0457)
Kashmir
Dear Chair
I am writing in response to your predecessor Mr Llew O'Brien MP's email of 11 February 2020 about petition PN0461.
Australia's long-held position is that the Kashmir dispute is a bilateral matter for India and Pakistan to resolve peacefully through dialogue.
The Australian Government urges all countries to respect human rights and civil liberties. We have encouraged the Indian Government to open the space for a peaceful political dialogue in Kashmir.
We are closely monitoring developments in Kashmir and will continue to do so.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne (Petition No. PN0461)
Falun Gong
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter regarding petition number PN0467. The petition raised concerns about the treatment of Falun Gong practitioners and reports of organ harvesting and trafficking in China.

Australia is committed to promoting and protecting human rights, including freedom of religion and freedom of belief for all people. We remain concerned that religious groups in China, including Falun Gong practitioners, continue to be targeted on the basis of their beliefs. We have regularly raised our concerns about this issue with China, including at ministerial level, both directly and in international fora. We will continue to do so while serious human rights abuses continue.

The Government is aware of reports of illegal organ harvesting in China. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) is carefully monitoring developments on this issue, and regularly reviews available evidence as new reports are published. We are aware that organs have been harvested from executed prisoners in China for use in medical transplants, at least prior to 2015. Australia strongly opposes this practice.

Australia is committed to preventing organ trafficking. Since 2004, the Government has had a comprehensive strategy to combat such crimes and is committed to ensuring that Australia's response to organ trafficking and transplant tourism remains as effective as possible. Australia's States and Territories have robust frameworks in place to regulate lawful donation and transplants of human organs and tissue for therapeutic purposes. In November 2018, the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade (JSCFADT) Human Rights Sub-Committee produced the report 'Compassion Not Commerce: An inquiry into Human Organ Trafficking and Organ Transplant Tourism'. This report delivered 12 recommendations, which are currently under consideration by the Government. The Department of Home Affairs is leading the Government's response.

The petition you referred to requests the sanctioning of individuals involved in the persecution of Falun Gong practitioners. We regularly review our sanctions settings to ensure they remain suitable and effective. At my request, the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is inquiring into the merits of a 'Magnitsky-style' human rights-based sanctions regime for Australia. I look forward to receiving the Committee's report in due course, and will consider its recommendations carefully. I take very seriously the question of whether Australia should introduce a human rights-based sanctions regime and consider it important that we properly understand the implications of such a regime. At present, the Migration Act allows the Government to prevent individuals involved in human rights abuses from visiting Australia. We will continue to monitor closely reports of mistreatment and restrictions against religious groups in China, and seek opportunities to respond strongly to these abuses.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne (Petition No. PN0467)
Newstart Allowance
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 9 April 2020 concerning Petition number PN0469 presented to the House of Representatives, regarding the rate of JobSeeker Payment (formerly Newstart Allowance).
This petitioner asks the House of Representatives to increase the rate of JobSeeker Payment and similar Centrelink payments by at least $75 per week.

The Australian social security system aims to support the basic living standards of all Australians and increase their social and economic participation. The Australian Government is committed to a welfare system that supports the most vulnerable, encourages those who are able to work or study, and is sustainable for future generations. Working age payments such as JobSeeker Payment are designed to provide a safety net for people who require financial assistance, while maintaining incentives for people to join or return to the workforce. The Government has always focussed on creating pathways into employment.

The Government believes that work, along with family and community, gives meaning to life. Employment participation is a foundation of social inclusion, it creates opportunities for financial independence and personal fulfilment. Everyone who can work should have the opportunity to do so and those who are unable to work should be adequately supported.

The Government understands that the next six months will be challenging for individuals, the labour market and the economy. The Government has acted to support households and businesses and address the significant economic consequences of the coronavirus.

As a result, the Government has announced an economic response totalling $320 billion over the next four years to 2023-24 to protect the economy by maintaining confidence, supporting investment and keeping people in jobs.

As part of this measure, an Economic Support Payment (ESP) is being made to around 6.5 million Australians to provide financial assistance to help them through this uncertain time and support economic activity. Payment of the ESP was delivered to eligible recipients from 31 March 2020 on a progressive basis. The ESP will not count as income for social security purposes and is a tax-free, one-off $750 payment to social security, veteran and other income support recipients and eligible concession card holders, including the Pensioner Concession Card and Commonwealth Seniors Health Card.

The Government is also temporarily expanding eligibility to certain income support payments and establishing a new, time-limited Corona virus Supplement to be paid at a rate of $550 per fortnight. This is part of the unprecedented action the Government is taking to strengthen the safety net available to Australians who are stood down or lose their jobs.

The Coronavirus Supplement commenced from 27 April 2020 and will be paid to both existing and new recipients of the eligible payment categories. Anyone who receives any amount of an eligible income support payments will receive the full amount of the Coronavirus Supplement, which would be taxable.

From 13 July 2020, a second ESP of $750 will also be paid automatically to social security and veteran income support recipients and eligible concession card holders, except for those who are receiving the new Coronavirus Supplement. A person can be eligible to receive both a first and second support payment. However, they can only receive one $750 payment in each round of payments.

I would like to acknowledge and thank the many not-for-profit, community based organisations like the petitioner, Cam Care, that are helping Australians who are facing personal hardship or difficult life circumstances.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston (Petition No. PN0469)
Falun Gong
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter regarding Petition Number PN0470. The petition raised concerns about the treatment of Falun Gong practitioners and reports of organ harvesting and trafficking in China.

from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne (Petition No. PN0470)
Corruption
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 June 2020 regarding Petition PN0477, which requests that the House of Representatives supports the passage of a Bill to establish a Federal Integrity Commission that upholds the Beechworth Principles established by the Member for lndi, Dr Helen Haines MP. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition, and note that the information below is consistent with the advice I provided for Petition EN1412 on the same issue.

The Australian Government condemns corruption in all its forms. The Government is committed to ensuring our federal integrity framework is as robust as possible to maximise public confidence in our national institutions.

That is why the Government has committed to establishing a Commonwealth Integrity Commission (CIC) to enhance national integrity arrangements across the federal public sector. The CIC will comprise a public sector integrity division and a law enforcement integrity division, ensuring targeted attention to corruption across the entirety of the public sector.

I note the petitioners' support for an anti-corruption body that upholds the Beechworth Principles of 'broad jurisdiction, common rules, appropriate powers, fair hearings, and accountability to the people.' The proposed CIC is broadly consistent with these principles. Specifically, the CIC will be an independent statutory agency with an extensive jurisdiction and a broad suite of coercive and investigative powers. Existing integrity agencies will be able to refer matters to the CIC, and vice versa. In appropriate circumstances, the CIC will be able to conduct joint investigations with other agencies, including state and territory anti-corruption commissions.

Through the CIC, the Government is intending to target serious criminal corruption that presents a threat to good public administration. The CIC will not duplicate the roles of existing bodies, but instead it will provide an expert investigative capability to respond to allegations of serious criminal corruption across the public sector.

While the CIC must be equipped with strong powers to effectively address corruption, I am committed to ensuring the model also provides due process of law and natural justice to those who fall within the CIC's jurisdiction. In relation to the Beechworth Principle promoting public hearings, hearings will only be able to be held in public when dealing with law enforcement corruption issues, not when dealing with other corruption issues. This will promote natural justice in investigations and preserve the role of the courts as arbiters of a person's guilt or innocence.

The public sector division will focus on investigating suspected criminal corrupt conduct, while maintaining the role of existing integrity agencies and mechanisms for dealing with less serious forms of misconduct. This will ensure that the jurisdiction of the CIC and other integrity agencies is clear and that the CIC's significant powers are reserved for use in appropriately serious cases.

The Government has been consulting widely to ensure that the model for the new Commission strengthens federal integrity arrangements without . compromising fundamental principles of our criminal justice system. The Government is focused on ensuring that the CIC is properly designed, appropriately resourced and informed by thorough consultation. To that end, we will be releasing a draft of the CIC legislation for public consultation. The petitioners may wish to consider the draft and provide further comments once it is made available.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Porter (Petition No. PN0477)
PETITIONS
Statements

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:20): This presentation of petitions and ministerial responses is exceptionally large. This is partly due to changes in the sitting pattern because of the COVID-19 pandemic, but also because of the high level of public engagement with petitioning that we continue to experience, which is great to see.

The 79 petitions presented here today represent the diverse Australian community and their genuine concerns. Some petitions address contemporary issues, such as COVID-19, and others are concerned about longstanding issues like technology advances, taxes, education and immigration, to name but a few.

By initiating, signing or promoting a petition through the e-petitioning system, or by signing a paper petition at a community event, local church or shopping centre, each person that has had involvement in these petitions has actively engaged with parliament.

As a committee we encourage this engagement, safely distanced of course, and also call on our fellow members of parliament to continue in their support of the right of a citizen to petition the House. Fellow members, if you are contacted by a constituent regarding a petition, you may consider presenting the petition on your constituent's behalf. You may also contact the secretariat for assistance in facilitating this process or to obtain advice for your constituent on the correct form and content for a petition. They are there and willing to help, and these actions will further assist in promoting citizens' engagement with parliament, and to allow individual voices to be heard.
Thank you, Mr Speaker. I look forward to further updating the House on the work of the committee.
PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS
Social Housing
Ms CLAYDON (Newcastle) (10:23): I move:
That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) more than 140,000 Australians were on social housing waitlists in June 2018;
(b) the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute has identified a shortfall of 433,000 social housing dwellings over the next 20 years;
(c) much of Australia's existing social housing stock is in dire need of maintenance and repairs; and

(d) the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has urged the Government to consider investment in social housing as a means of protecting Australia's economy from the impacts of COVID-19;

(2) recognises the success of Labor's $5 billion investment to build 20,000 new social housing dwellings and renovate a further 80,000, as a key economic stimulus measure during the global financial crisis; and
(3) calls on the Government to:
(a) ensure that stimulus measures are focused on delivering maximum ongoing public benefit; and
(b) work with the private and community sectors and superannuation funds to invest in more social housing and repair existing social housing.

Report after report has shown that investment in social housing is critical to Australia's post-COVID-19 social and economic recovery. That's why I have moved this motion. Social housing is in urgent need of direct public investment, and we need national leadership to make this happen.

Australians are currently living through some of the most dire social and economic conditions in living memory. We are facing what could be the deepest recession in a century. More than half a million jobs have disappeared already and, based on the government's own projections, we're set to lose another 400,000 jobs by Christmas. Key industries have been smashed. The housing construction sector, an important marker of the health of any economy, is heading for a 27 per cent collapse according to Master Builders Australia. Tragically, the Morrison government's attempt at a housing stimulus package—the so-called HomeBuilder scheme—has been almost completely ineffectual.
